85e7a56l-81me-1698-05ux-8e124ik66y50.name: Medusa
85e7a56l-81me-1698-05ux-8e124ik66y50.description:
A security focused observability tool designed to help security teams and possibly other teams to prioritise weaknesses within their entire environment at a glance.  

This tool is designed to have a complete views of a companies entire tech stack (Infrastructure, Applications, Networking, etc.) along with traceability of ownership of each element of the tech stack for the organisation. 

The vision is to integrate into tooling that organisations use and surface the findings together. While individual components can be chosen the priority is to group them at a Service level for a complete picture of the environment. 

The tool will mainly integrate into other tools for data, metrics, vulnerabilities, etc. The intention is to not build a scanner but to combine all the data into easily actionable data at a glance.

project.name: Medusa
project.description:
A security focused observability tool designed to help security teams and possibly other teams to prioritise weaknesses within their entire environment at a glance.  

This tool is designed to have a complete views of a companies entire tech stack (Infrastructure, Applications, Networking, etc.) along with traceability of ownership of each element of the tech stack for the organisation. 

The vision is to integrate into tooling that organisations use and surface the findings together. While individual components can be chosen the priority is to group them at a Service level for a complete picture of the environment. 

The tool will mainly integrate into other tools for data, metrics, vulnerabilities, etc. The intention is to not build a scanner but to combine all the data into easily actionable data at a glance.

pool:
  name: "Links pool"
stages:
- stage: TerraformPlan
  displayName: "Terraform Plan Stage"
  jobs:
  - job: Plan
    displayName: "Run Terraform Init and Plan"
    pool:
      name: "Links pool"
    steps:
    - task: AzureCLI@2
      displayName: "Terraform Init and Plan"
      inputs:
        azureSubscription: Development(9152143d-w081-3657-y338-kg11w276500y)
        scriptType: bash
        addSpnToEnvironment: true
        scriptLocation: inlineScript
        inlineScript: |
          # Export Azure authentication environment variables
          export ARM_CLIENT_ID=$servicePrincipalId
          export ARM_CLIENT_SECRET=$servicePrincipalKey
          export ARM_TENANT_ID=$tenantId

                echo "
                     __====-_  _-====___
                    _--^^^*****//      \\*****^^^--_
                 _-^**********// (    ) \\**********^-_
                -************//  |\^^/|  \\************-
              _/************//   (@::@)   \\************\\_
             /*************((     \\//     ))*************\\
            -***************\\    (oo)    //***************-
           -*****************\\  / UUU \\  //*****************-
          -*******************\\/  (   )  \//*******************-
          _*/|**********/\******(   /   \   )******/\**********|\*_
          |/ |*/\*/\*/\/  \*/\**\  /     \  /**/\*/  \/\*/\*/\| \
             |/  V  |/     |/  |/         \|  |/     \|  |/  | "

          cd terraform

          # Initialize and plan Terraform
          terraform init
          terraform plan -out=tfplan
- stage: TerraformApply
  displayName: "Terraform Apply"
  jobs:
  - job: Apply
    displayName: "Run Terraform Apply"
    pool:
      vmImage: 'ubuntu-latest'
    steps:
    - task: AzureCLI@2
      displayName: "Terraform Apply"
      inputs:
        azureSubscription: Development(9152143d-w081-3657-y338-kg11w276500y)
        scriptType: bash
        addSpnToEnvironment: true
        scriptLocation: inlineScript
        inlineScript: |
          # Export Azure authentication environment variables
          export ARM_CLIENT_ID=$servicePrincipalId
          export ARM_CLIENT_SECRET=$servicePrincipalKey
          export ARM_TENANT_ID=$tenantId

          cd terraform

          # Initialize Terraform and apply the plan
          terraform init
          terraform apply -auto-approve

inputs.inlineScript:
# Export Azure authentication environment variables
export ARM_CLIENT_ID=$servicePrincipalId
export ARM_CLIENT_SECRET=$servicePrincipalKey
export ARM_TENANT_ID=$tenantId

cd terraform

# Initialize Terraform and apply the plan
terraform init
terraform apply -auto-approve

trigger:
  enabled: false
resources:
  repositories:
  - repository: webgoat
    name: webGoat/WebGoat
    endpoint: github.com_Bru456
    ref: main
    type: github
stages:
- stage: build_and_deploy
  displayName: Build and Deploy webgoat
  pool:
    vmImage: ubuntu-latest
  jobs:
  - job: build
    displayName: Build WebGoat
    uses:
      repositories:
      - webgoat
    steps:
    - task: 6d15af64-176c-496d-b583-fd2ae21d4df4@1
      inputs:
        repository: webgoat
    - task: CmdLine@2
      inputs:
        script: wget https://aka.ms/download-jdk/microsoft-jdk-21.0.5-linux-x64.tar.gz -O /tmp/microsoft-jdk-21.0.5-linux-x64.tar.gz
    - task: JavaToolInstaller@0
      inputs:
        versionSpec: '21'
        jdkArchitectureOption: 'x64'
        jdkSourceOption: 'LocalDirectory'
        jdkFile: '/tmp/microsoft-jdk-21.0.5-linux-x64.tar.gz'
        jdkDestinationDirectory: '$(agent.toolsDirectory)/jdk21'
        cleanDestinationDirectory: true
        createExtractDirectory: true
    - task: Maven@4
      displayName: Maven Build
      inputs:
        mavenPomFile: 'pom.xml'
        mavenOptions: '-Xmx3072m'
        javaHomeOption: 'JDKVersion'
        jdkVersionOption: 1.21
        jdkArchitectureOption: 'x64'
        goals: 'package'
    - task: Docker@2
      displayName: Build Webgoat Image
      inputs:
        command: 'build'
        Dockerfile: './Dockerfile'
        buildContext: '.'
        tags: |
          $(Build.BuildId)
        repository: webgoat
        container: localhost
    - task: Bash@3
      displayName: Save Docker Image
      inputs:
        targetType: 'inline'
        script: |
          docker save docker.io/library/webgoat:$(Build.BuildId) -o $(Pipeline.Workspace)/webgoat.tar
    - task: PublishPipelineArtifact@1
      inputs:
        targetPath: '$(Pipeline.Workspace)/webgoat.tar'
        artifact: 'webgoat_container'
        publishLocation: 'pipeline'
  - deployment: deploy
    displayName: Deploy Webgoat
    dependsOn:
    - build
    pool:
      name: Links Pool
    environment:
      name: Links-build-agent
    strategy:
      runOnce:
        deploy:
          steps:
          - task: DownloadPipelineArtifact@2
            inputs:
              artifact: webgoat_container
          - task: CmdLine@2
            inputs:
              script: |
                #tar -xvf $(Pipeline.Workspace)/webgoat_container/webgoat.tar -C webgoat-image
                whoami
                sudo docker load -i $(Pipeline.Workspace)/webgoat_container/webgoat.tar
                sudo docker image ls

inputs.script:
#tar -xvf $(Pipeline.Workspace)/webgoat_container/webgoat.tar -C webgoat-image
whoami
sudo docker load -i $(Pipeline.Workspace)/webgoat_container/webgoat.tar
sudo docker image ls

inputs.script:
# Write your commands here

echo 'Hello world'

project.name: Medusa
project.description:
A security focused observability tool designed to help security teams and possibly other teams to prioritise weaknesses within their entire environment at a glance.  

This tool is designed to have a complete views of a companies entire tech stack (Infrastructure, Applications, Networking, etc.) along with traceability of ownership of each element of the tech stack for the organisation. 

The vision is to integrate into tooling that organisations use and surface the findings together. While individual components can be chosen the priority is to group them at a Service level for a complete picture of the environment. 

The tool will mainly integrate into other tools for data, metrics, vulnerabilities, etc. The intention is to not build a scanner but to combine all the data into easily actionable data at a glance.

project.name: Medusa
project.description:
A security focused observability tool designed to help security teams and possibly other teams to prioritise weaknesses within their entire environment at a glance.  

This tool is designed to have a complete views of a companies entire tech stack (Infrastructure, Applications, Networking, etc.) along with traceability of ownership of each element of the tech stack for the organisation. 

The vision is to integrate into tooling that organisations use and surface the findings together. While individual components can be chosen the priority is to group them at a Service level for a complete picture of the environment. 

The tool will mainly integrate into other tools for data, metrics, vulnerabilities, etc. The intention is to not build a scanner but to combine all the data into easily actionable data at a glance.

          echo See https://aka.ms/yaml

builds.yaml:
trigger:
  enabled: false
resources:
  repositories:
  - repository: webgoat
    name: webGoat/WebGoat
    endpoint: github.com_Bru456
    ref: main
    type: github
stages:
- stage: build_and_deploy
  displayName: Build and Deploy webgoat
  pool:
    vmImage: ubuntu-latest
  jobs:
  - job: build
    displayName: Build WebGoat
    uses:
      repositories:
      - webgoat
    steps:
    - task: 6d15af64-176c-496d-b583-fd2ae21d4df4@1
      inputs:
        repository: webgoat
    - task: CmdLine@2
      inputs:
        script: wget https://aka.ms/download-jdk/microsoft-jdk-21.0.5-linux-x64.tar.gz -O /tmp/microsoft-jdk-21.0.5-linux-x64.tar.gz
    - task: JavaToolInstaller@0
      inputs:
        versionSpec: '21'
        jdkArchitectureOption: 'x64'
        jdkSourceOption: 'LocalDirectory'
        jdkFile: '/tmp/microsoft-jdk-21.0.5-linux-x64.tar.gz'
        jdkDestinationDirectory: '$(agent.toolsDirectory)/jdk21'
        cleanDestinationDirectory: true
        createExtractDirectory: true
    - task: Maven@4
      displayName: Maven Build
      inputs:
        mavenPomFile: 'pom.xml'
        mavenOptions: '-Xmx3072m'
        javaHomeOption: 'JDKVersion'
        jdkVersionOption: 1.21
        jdkArchitectureOption: 'x64'
        goals: 'package'
    - task: Docker@2
      displayName: Build Webgoat Image
      inputs:
        command: 'build'
        Dockerfile: './Dockerfile'
        buildContext: '.'
        tags: |
          $(Build.BuildId)
        repository: webgoat
        container: localhost
    - task: Bash@3
      displayName: Save Docker Image
      inputs:
        targetType: 'inline'
        script: |
          docker save docker.io/library/webgoat:$(Build.BuildId) -o $(Pipeline.Workspace)/webgoat.tar
    - task: PublishPipelineArtifact@1
      inputs:
        targetPath: '$(Pipeline.Workspace)/webgoat.tar'
        artifact: 'webgoat_container'
        publishLocation: 'pipeline'
  - deployment: deploy
    displayName: Deploy Webgoat
    dependsOn:
    - build
    pool:
      name: Links Pool
    environment:
      name: Links-build-agent
    strategy:
      runOnce:
        deploy:
          steps:
          - task: DownloadPipelineArtifact@2
            inputs:
              artifact: webgoat_container
          - task: CmdLine@2
            inputs:
              script: |
                #tar -xvf $(Pipeline.Workspace)/webgoat_container/webgoat.tar -C webgoat-image
                docker load -i $(Pipeline.Workspace)/webgoat_container/webgoat.tar
                docker image ls

      inputs:
        targetPath: '$(Pipeline.Workspace)/WebGoat.tar'
        artifact: 'MY_ARTIFACT'
        publishLocation: 'pipeline'

tasks.name: PowerShell

tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: targetType
inputs.label: Type
inputs.helpMarkDown: Target script type: File Path or Inline

inputs.name: filePath
inputs.label: Script Path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path of the script to execute. Must be a fully qualified path or relative to $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory).

inputs.name: arguments
inputs.label: Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Arguments passed to the PowerShell script. Either ordinal parameters or named parameters.

inputs.name: script
inputs.label: Script
inputs.defaultValue:
# Write your PowerShell commands here.

Write-Host "Hello World"

inputs.name: errorActionPreference
inputs.label: ErrorActionPreference
inputs.helpMarkDown: When not `Default`, prepends the line `$ErrorActionPreference = 'VALUE'` at the top of your script.

inputs.name: warningPreference
inputs.label: WarningPreference
inputs.helpMarkDown: When not `Default`, prepends the line `$WarningPreference = 'VALUE'` at the top of your script.

inputs.name: informationPreference
inputs.label: InformationPreference
inputs.helpMarkDown: When not `Default`, prepends the line `$InformationPreference = 'VALUE'` at the top of your script.

inputs.name: verbosePreference
inputs.label: VerbosePreference
inputs.helpMarkDown: When not `Default`, prepends the line `$VerbosePreference = 'VALUE'` at the top of your script.

inputs.name: debugPreference
inputs.label: DebugPreference
inputs.helpMarkDown: When not `Default`, prepends the line `$DebugPreference = 'VALUE'` at the top of your script.

inputs.name: progressPreference
inputs.label: ProgressPreference
inputs.helpMarkDown: When not `Default`, prepends the line `$ProgressPreference = 'VALUE'` at the top of your script.

inputs.name: failOnStderr
inputs.label: Fail on Standard Error
inputs.helpMarkDown: If this is true, this task will fail if any errors are written to the error pipeline, or if any data is written to the Standard Error stream. Otherwise the task will rely on the exit code to determine failure.

inputs.name: showWarnings
inputs.label: Show warnings as Azure DevOps warnings
inputs.helpMarkDown: If this is true, and your script writes a warnings - they are shown as warnings also in pipeline logs

inputs.name: ignoreLASTEXITCODE
inputs.label: Ignore $LASTEXITCODE
inputs.helpMarkDown: If this is false, the line `if ((Test-Path -LiteralPath variable:\LASTEXITCODE)) { exit $LASTEXITCODE }` is appended to the end of your script. This will cause the last exit code from an external command to be propagated as the exit code of powershell. Otherwise the line is not appended to the end of your script.

inputs.name: pwsh
inputs.label: Use PowerShell Core
inputs.helpMarkDown: If this is true, then on Windows the task will use pwsh.exe from your PATH instead of powershell.exe.

inputs.name: workingDirectory
inputs.label: Working Directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Working directory where the script is run.

inputs.name: runScriptInSeparateScope
inputs.label: Run script in the separate scope
inputs.helpMarkDown: This input allows executing PowerShell scripts using '&' operator instead of the default '.'. If this input set to the true script will be executed in separate scope and globally scoped PowerShell variables won't be updated

tasks.description: Run scripts and make changes to a MySQL Database
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: TaskNameSelector
inputs.label: Deploy MySql Using
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select one of the options between Script File & Inline Script.

inputs.name: SqlFile
inputs.label: MySQL Script
inputs.helpMarkDown: Full path of the script file on the automation agent or on a UNC path accessible to the automation agent like,  \\\\BudgetIT\DeployBuilds\script.sql. Also, predefined system variables like, $(agent.releaseDirectory) can also be used here. A file containing SQL statements can be used here.​

inputs.name: SqlInline
inputs.label: Inline MySQL Script
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter the MySQL script to execute on the Database selected above.

inputs.name: ServerName
inputs.label: Host Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Server name of 'Database for MySQL'.Example: localhost. When you connect using MySQL Workbench, this is the same value that is used for 'Hostname' in 'Parameters'

inputs.name: DatabaseName
inputs.label: Database Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of database, if you already have one, on which the below script is needed to be run, else the script itself can be used to create the database.

inputs.name: SqlUsername
inputs.label: MySQL User Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: When you connect using MySQL Workbench, this is the same value that is used for 'Username' in 'Parameters'.

inputs.name: SqlPassword
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Password for MySQL Database.
It can be variable defined in the pipeline. Example : $(password).
Also, you may mark the variable type as 'secret' to secure it.

inputs.name: SqlAdditionalArguments
inputs.label: Additional Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Additional options supported by MySQL simple SQL shell. These options will be applied when executing the given file on the Database for MySQL.​
Example: You can change to default tab separated output format to HTML or even XML format. Or if you have problems due to insufficient memory for large result sets, use the --quick option.​

inputs.helpMarkDown: Select endpoints to authenticate outside this organization.

inputs.name: onlyAddExtraIndex
inputs.label: Don't set primary index URL
inputs.helpMarkDown: If this is set to true, no feed will be set as the primary index URL. All of the configured feeds/endpoints will be set as extra index URLs. Defaults to false.

tasks.name: PipAuthenticate
tasks.description: Authentication task for the pip client used for installing Python distributions
tasks.helpMarkDown: [Learn more about this task](https://pip.pypa.io/en/stable/reference/pip_install/) or [see the pip documentation](https://pip.pypa.io/)
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: feedList
inputs.label: My feeds (select below)
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select feeds to authenticate present in this organization

inputs.name: externalSources
inputs.label: Feeds from external organizations
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select endpoints to authenticate outside this organization.

tasks.name: Maven
tasks.description: Build, test, and deploy with Apache Maven
tasks.helpMarkDown: [Learn more about this task](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=613723) or [see the Maven documentation](http://maven.apache.org/guides/index.html)
tasks.releaseNotes: Configuration of the SonarQube analysis was moved to the [SonarQube](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=SonarSource.sonarqube) or [SonarCloud](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=SonarSource.sonarcloud) extensions, in task `Prepare Analysis Configuration`
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: ConnectedServiceName
inputs.label: Azure Resource Manager connection
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select an Azure Resource Manager service connection

inputs.name: mavenPOMFile
inputs.label: Maven POM file
inputs.helpMarkDown: Relative path from the repository root to the Maven POM file.

inputs.name: publishJUnitResults
inputs.label: Publish to Azure Pipelines
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select this option to publish JUnit test results produced by the Maven build to Azure Pipelines. Each test results file matching `Test Results Files` will be published as a test run in Azure Pipelines.

inputs.name: testResultsFiles
inputs.label: Test results files
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the path and pattern of test results files to publish. Wildcards can be used ([more information](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=856077)). For example, `**/TEST-*.xml` for all XML files whose name starts with `TEST-`. If no root path is specified, files are matched beneath the default working directory, the value of which is available in the variable: $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory).  For example, a value of '**/TEST-*.xml' will actually result in matching files from '$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/**/TEST-*.xml'.

inputs.name: testRunTitle
inputs.label: Test run title
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a name for the test run.

inputs.name: allowBrokenSymbolicLinks
inputs.label: Allow broken symbolic links
inputs.helpMarkDown: Set false to fail build when task finds broken symbolic link during publishing tests result

inputs.name: codeCoverageTool
inputs.label: Code coverage tool
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the code coverage tool.

inputs.name: classFilter
inputs.label: Class inclusion/exclusion filters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Comma-separated list of filters to include or exclude classes from collecting code coverage. For example: +:com.*,+:org.*,-:my.app*.*.

inputs.name: classFilesDirectories
inputs.label: Class files directories
inputs.helpMarkDown: This field is required for a multi-module project. Specify a comma-separated list of relative paths from the Maven POM file to directories containing class files and archive files (JAR, WAR, etc.). Code coverage is reported for class files in these directories. For example: target/classes,target/testClasses.

inputs.name: srcDirectories
inputs.label: Source files directories
inputs.helpMarkDown: This field is required for a multi-module project. Specify a comma-separated list of relative paths from the Maven POM file to source code directories. Code coverage reports will use these to highlight source code. For example: src/java,src/Test.

inputs.name: failIfCoverageEmpty
inputs.label: Fail when code coverage results are missing
inputs.helpMarkDown: Fail the build if code coverage did not produce any results to publish.

inputs.name: restoreOriginalPomXml
inputs.label: Restore original pom.xml after task execution
inputs.helpMarkDown: Code coverage modifies pom.xml to produce results. Use this option if you need to keep original pom.xml.

inputs.name: javaHomeSelection
inputs.label: Set JAVA_HOME by
inputs.helpMarkDown: Sets JAVA_HOME either by selecting a JDK version that will be discovered during builds or by manually entering a JDK path.

inputs.name: jdkVersion
inputs.label: JDK version
inputs.helpMarkDown: Will attempt to discover the path to the selected JDK version and set JAVA_HOME accordingly.

inputs.name: jdkUserInputPath
inputs.label: JDK path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Sets JAVA_HOME to the given path.

inputs.name: jdkArchitecture
inputs.label: JDK architecture
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optionally supply the architecture (x86, x64) of the JDK.

inputs.name: mavenVersionSelection
inputs.label: Maven version
inputs.helpMarkDown: Uses either the default Maven version or the version in the specified custom path.

inputs.name: mavenPath
inputs.label: Maven path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Supply the custom path to the Maven installation (e.g., /usr/share/maven).

inputs.name: mavenSetM2Home
inputs.label: Set M2_HOME variable
inputs.helpMarkDown: Sets the M2_HOME variable to a custom Maven installation path.

inputs.name: mavenOpts
inputs.label: Set MAVEN_OPTS to
inputs.helpMarkDown: Sets the MAVEN_OPTS environment variable, which is used to send command-line arguments to start the JVM. The -Xmx flag specifies the maximum memory available to the JVM.

inputs.name: mavenFeedAuthenticate
inputs.label: Authenticate with Artifacts feeds
inputs.helpMarkDown: Automatically authenticates with Azure Artifacts feeds. If Artifacts feeds are not in use, deselect this option for faster builds.

inputs.name: skipEffectivePom
inputs.label: Skip generating effective POM while authenticating with Artifacts feeds
inputs.helpMarkDown: Authenticates with Artifacts feeds using the POM only.

inputs.name: sqAnalysisEnabled
inputs.label: Run SonarQube or SonarCloud analysis
inputs.helpMarkDown: This option has changed from version 1 of the **Maven** task to use the [SonarQube](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=SonarSource.sonarqube) and [SonarCloud](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=SonarSource.sonarcloud) marketplace extensions.  Enable this option to run [SonarQube or SonarCloud analysis](http://redirect.sonarsource.com/doc/install-configure-scanner-tfs-ts.html) after executing goals in the **Goals** field. The **install** or **package** goal should run first. You must also add a **Prepare Analysis Configuration** task from one of the extensions to the build pipeline before this Maven task.

inputs.name: isJacocoCoverageReportXML
inputs.label: Use XML Jacoco reports for SonarQube analysis
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use XML Jacoco reports for SonarQube analysis. [More info](https://docs.sonarqube.org/latest/analysis/coverage/)

options.pom: Use version declared in your pom.xml

inputs.name: sqMavenPluginVersionChoice
inputs.label: SonarQube scanner for Maven version
inputs.helpMarkDown: The SonarQube Maven plugin version to use. You can use latest version, or rely on the version in your pom.xml.

inputs.name: checkstyleAnalysisEnabled
inputs.label: Run Checkstyle
inputs.helpMarkDown: Run the Checkstyle tool with the default Sun checks. Results are uploaded as build artifacts.

inputs.name: pmdAnalysisEnabled
inputs.label: Run PMD
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use the PMD static analysis tool to look for bugs in the code. Results are uploaded as build artifacts.

inputs.name: findbugsAnalysisEnabled
inputs.label: Run FindBugs
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use the FindBugs static analysis tool to look for bugs in the code. Results are uploaded as build artifacts.

inputs.name: spotBugsAnalysisEnabled
inputs.label: Run SpotBugs analysis
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enable this option to run spotBugs code analysis plugin. [More info](https://spotbugs.github.io/spotbugs-maven-plugin)

inputs.name: spotBugsMavenPluginVersion
inputs.label: Version number
inputs.helpMarkDown: Refer to https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/com.github.spotbugs/spotbugs-maven-plugin for all available versions.

options.spotbugs: "spotbugs" - Creates a report on found bugs
options.check: "check" - Pipeline fails if bugs were detected

inputs.name: spotBugsGoal
inputs.label: The goal for the spotbugs plugin
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the goal of the plugin. Refer https://spotbugs.readthedocs.io/en/stable/maven.html#goals-of-spotbugs-maven-plugin to for more detailed description.

inputs.name: spotBugsFailWhenBugsFound
inputs.label: Fail when bugs are found with spotbugs:check
inputs.helpMarkDown: Fail when the bugs found when check goal specified. Refers to https://spotbugs.github.io/spotbugs-maven-plugin/check-mojo.html#failonerror for more detailed description.

inputs.helpMarkDown: SonarQube server 5.1 and lower only. Enter the database connection setting (i.e. sonar.jdbc.url). For example: jdbc:jtds:sqlserver://localhost/sonar;SelectMethod=Cursor

inputs.name: sqDbUsername
inputs.label: Db Username
inputs.helpMarkDown: SonarQube server 5.1 and lower only. Enter the username for the database user (i.e. sonar.jdbc.username).

inputs.name: sqDbPassword
inputs.label: Db User Password
inputs.helpMarkDown: SonarQube server 5.1 and lower only. Enter the password for the database user i.e. sonar.jdbc.password

inputs.name: sqAnalysisIncludeFullReport
inputs.label: Include full analysis report in the build summary (SQ 5.3+)
inputs.helpMarkDown: This option will delay the build until the SonarQube analysis is completed.

inputs.name: sqAnalysisBreakBuildIfQualityGateFailed
inputs.label: Fail the build on quality gate failure (SQ 5.3+)
inputs.helpMarkDown: This option is only available when using a SonarQube server 5.3 or above. It will introduce delays as the build must wait for SonarQube to complete the analysis. [More information](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=722407)

inputs.name: checkstyleAnalysisEnabled
inputs.label: Run Checkstyle
inputs.helpMarkDown: Run the Checkstyle tool with the default Sun checks. Results are uploaded as build artifacts.

inputs.name: pmdAnalysisEnabled
inputs.label: Run PMD
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use the PMD static analysis tool to look for bugs in the code. Results are uploaded as build artifacts.

inputs.name: findbugsAnalysisEnabled
inputs.label: Run FindBugs
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use the FindBugs static analysis tool to look for bugs in the code. Results are uploaded as build artifacts.

tasks.name: DotNetCoreCLI
tasks.description: Build, test, package, or publish a dotnet application, or run a custom dotnet command
tasks.helpMarkDown: [Learn more about this task](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=832194) or [see the .NET Core documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/)
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

groups.name: generalAdvanced
groups.visibleRule: command != pack && command != push && command != restore

inputs.name: ConnectedServiceName
inputs.label: Azure Resource Manager connection
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select an Azure Resource Manager service connection

inputs.name: command
inputs.label: Command
inputs.helpMarkDown: The dotnet command to run. Select 'Custom' to add arguments or use a command not listed here.

inputs.name: publishWebProjects
inputs.label: Publish web projects
inputs.helpMarkDown: If true, the task will try to find the web projects in the repository and run the publish command on them. Web projects are identified by presence of either a web.config file or wwwroot folder in the directory.

inputs.name: projects
inputs.label: Path to project(s) or solution(s)
inputs.helpMarkDown: The path to the csproj or sln file(s) to use. You can use wildcards (e.g. **/*.csproj for all .csproj files in all subfolders). **This field follows glob pattern, and is run against root of the repository at all times irrespective of Working Directory.**
inputs.visibleRule: command = build || command = restore || command = run || command = test || command = custom || publishWebProjects = false

inputs.name: custom
inputs.label: Custom command
inputs.helpMarkDown: The command to pass to dotnet.exe for execution.

inputs.name: arguments
inputs.label: Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Arguments to the selected command. For example, build configuration, output folder, runtime. The arguments depend on the command selected.
inputs.visibleRule: command = build || command = publish || command = run || command = test || command = custom

inputs.name: restoreArguments
inputs.label: Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Write the additional arguments to be passed to **restore** command.

inputs.name: publishTestResults
inputs.label: Publish test results and code coverage
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Enabling this option will generate a test results TRX file in `$(Agent.TempDirectory)` and results will be published to the server.
This option appends `--logger trx --results-directory $(Agent.TempDirectory)` to the command line arguments.

Code coverage can be collected by adding `--collect "Code coverage"` option to the command line arguments. This is currently only available on the Windows platform.

inputs.name: testRunTitle
inputs.label: Test run title
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a name for the test run.

inputs.name: zipAfterPublish
inputs.label: Zip published projects
inputs.helpMarkDown: If true, folder created by the publish command will be zipped.

inputs.name: modifyOutputPath
inputs.label: Add project's folder name to publish path
inputs.helpMarkDown: If true, folders created by the publish command will have project's folder name prefixed to their folder names when output path is specified explicitly in arguments. This is useful if you want to publish multiple projects to the same folder.

inputs.name: selectOrConfig
inputs.label: Feeds to use
inputs.helpMarkDown: You can either select a feed from Azure Artifacts and/or NuGet.org here, or commit a nuget.config file to your source code repository and set its path here.

inputs.name: feedRestore
inputs.label: Use packages from this Azure Artifacts feed. Select from the dropdown or enter [project name/]feed name.
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Include the selected feed in the generated NuGet.config.

Format:
* For organization-scoped feeds: `FeedName`
* For project-scoped feeds: `ProjectName/FeedName`

inputs.name: includeNuGetOrg
inputs.label: Use packages from NuGet.org
inputs.helpMarkDown: Include NuGet.org in the generated NuGet.config.

inputs.name: nugetConfigPath
inputs.label: Path to NuGet.config
inputs.helpMarkDown: The NuGet.config in your repository that specifies the feeds from which to restore packages.

inputs.name: externalEndpoints
inputs.label: Credentials for feeds outside this organization/collection
inputs.helpMarkDown: Credentials to use for external registries located in the selected NuGet.config. For feeds in this organization/collection, leave this blank; the build’s credentials are used automatically.

inputs.name: noCache
inputs.label: Disable local cache
inputs.helpMarkDown: Prevents NuGet from using packages from local machine caches.

inputs.name: packagesDirectory
inputs.label: Destination directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies the folder in which packages are installed. If no folder is specified, packages are restored into the default NuGet package cache.

inputs.name: verbosityRestore
inputs.label: Verbosity
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies the amount of detail displayed in the output.

inputs.name: searchPatternPush
inputs.label: Path to NuGet package(s) to publish
inputs.helpMarkDown: The pattern to match or path to nupkg files to be uploaded. Multiple patterns can be separated by a semicolon.

inputs.name: feedPublish
inputs.label: Target feed
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a feed hosted in this organization. You must have Azure Artifacts installed and licensed to select a feed here.

inputs.name: publishPackageMetadata
inputs.label: Publish pipeline metadata
inputs.helpMarkDown: Associate this build/release pipeline’s metadata (run #, source code information) with the package

inputs.name: externalEndpoint
inputs.label: NuGet server
inputs.helpMarkDown: The NuGet service connection that contains the external NuGet server’s credentials.

inputs.name: searchPatternPack
inputs.label: Path to csproj or nuspec file(s) to pack
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Pattern to search for csproj or nuspec files to pack.

You can separate multiple patterns with a semicolon, and you can make a pattern negative by prefixing it with '!'. Example: `**/*.csproj;!**/*.Tests.csproj`

inputs.name: configurationToPack
inputs.label: Configuration to Package
inputs.helpMarkDown: When using a csproj file this specifies the configuration to package

inputs.name: outputDir
inputs.label: Package Folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Folder where packages will be created. If empty, packages will be created alongside the csproj file.

inputs.name: nobuild
inputs.label: Do not build
inputs.helpMarkDown: Don't build the project before packing. Corresponds to the --no-build command line parameter.

inputs.name: includesymbols
inputs.label: Include Symbols
inputs.helpMarkDown: Additionally creates symbol NuGet packages. Corresponds to the --include-symbols command line parameter.

inputs.name: includesource
inputs.label: Include Source
inputs.helpMarkDown: Includes source code in the package. Corresponds to the --include-source command line parameter.

inputs.name: versioningScheme
inputs.label: Automatic package versioning
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Cannot be used with include referenced projects. If you choose 'Use the date and time', this will generate a [SemVer](http://semver.org/spec/v1.0.0.html)-compliant version formatted as `X.Y.Z-ci-datetime` where you choose X, Y, and Z.

If you choose 'Use an environment variable', you must select an environment variable and ensure it contains the version number you want to use.

If you choose 'Use the build number', this will use the build number to version your package. **Note:** Under Options set the build number format to be '[$(BuildDefinitionName)_$(Year:yyyy).$(Month).$(DayOfMonth)$(Rev:.r)](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=627416)'.

inputs.name: versionEnvVar
inputs.label: Environment variable
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter the variable name without $, $env, or %.

inputs.name: requestedMajorVersion
inputs.label: Major
inputs.helpMarkDown: The 'X' in version [X.Y.Z](http://semver.org/spec/v1.0.0.html)

inputs.name: requestedMinorVersion
inputs.label: Minor
inputs.helpMarkDown: The 'Y' in version [X.Y.Z](http://semver.org/spec/v1.0.0.html)

inputs.name: requestedPatchVersion
inputs.label: Patch
inputs.helpMarkDown: The 'Z' in version [X.Y.Z](http://semver.org/spec/v1.0.0.html)

inputs.name: buildProperties
inputs.label: Additional build properties
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies a list of token = value pairs, separated by semicolons, where each occurrence of $token$ in the .nuspec file will be replaced with the given value. Values can be strings in quotation marks.

inputs.name: verbosityPack
inputs.label: Verbosity
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies the amount of detail displayed in the output.

inputs.name: workingDirectory
inputs.label: Working directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Current working directory where the script is run. Empty is the root of the repo (build) or artifacts (release), which is $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory). The project search pattern is **NOT** relative to working directory.
inputs.visibleRule: command != restore && command != push && command != pack

inputs.name: requestTimeout
inputs.label: Set timeout for package download request
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a timeout value for HTTP requests that the task makes to obtain the .NET package. The value is in milliseconds. Default is 300000 milliseconds (5 minutes). Cannot be more than 600000 milliseconds (10 minutes).

tasks.name: DotNetCoreCLI
tasks.description: Build, test and publish using dotnet core command-line.

inputs.name: projects
inputs.label: Project(s)
inputs.helpMarkDown: Relative path of the project.json file(s) from repo root. Wildcards can be used. For example, **/project.json for all project.json files in all the sub folders.

inputs.name: arguments
inputs.label: Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Arguments to the selected command. For example, build configuration, output folder, rutime. The arguments depend on the command selected.

inputs.name: zipAfterPublish
inputs.label: Zip Published Projects
inputs.helpMarkDown: If true, folder created by the publish command will be zipped.

inputs.name: email

tasks.name: AzureRmWebAppDeployment
tasks.description: Deploy to Azure App Service a web, mobile, or API app using Docker, Java, .NET, .NET Core, Node.js, PHP, Python, or Ruby
tasks.releaseNotes:
What's new in version 4.*
Supports Zip Deploy, Run From Package, War Deploy [Details here](https://aka.ms/appServiceDeploymentMethods)
Supports App Service Environments
Improved UI for discovering different App service types supported by the task
Run From Package is the preferred deployment method, which makes files in wwwroot folder read-only
Click [here](https://aka.ms/azurermwebdeployreadme) for more information.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

groups.name: FileTransformsAndVariableSubstitution
groups.visibleRule: WebAppKind != webAppContainer && WebAppKind != webAppHyperVContainer && WebAppkind != functionAppContainer && WebAppKind != webAppLinux && webAppKind != functionAppLinux && Package NotEndsWith .war

groups.name: AdditionalDeploymentOptions
groups.visibleRule: ConnectionType = AzureRM && WebAppKind != webAppLinux && WebAppKind != webAppContainer && WebAppKind != webAppHyperVContainer && WebAppkind != functionAppContainer && webAppKind != functionAppLinux && WebAppKind != "" && Package NotEndsWith .war && Package NotEndsWith .jar

groups.name: PostDeploymentAction
groups.visibleRule: ConnectionType = AzureRM && WebAppKind != "" && WebAppKind != webAppContainer && WebAppKind != webAppHyperVContainer && WebAppkind != functionAppContainer

inputs.name: ConnectionType
inputs.label: Connection type
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Select the service connection type to use to deploy the Web App.
Select Publish Profile for using Visual Studio created Publish profile. [More Information](https://aka.ms/vsPublishProfile).

inputs.name: ConnectedServiceName
inputs.label: Azure subscription
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the Azure Resource Manager subscription for the deployment.

inputs.name: PublishProfilePath
inputs.label: Publish profile path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path of the Publish profile created from Visual Studio

inputs.name: PublishProfilePassword
inputs.label: Publish profile password
inputs.helpMarkDown: It is recommended to store password in a secret variable and use that variable here e.g. $(Password).

options.functionApp: Function App on Windows (Not Recommended, Use Azure Functions Task)
options.functionAppLinux: Function App on Linux (Not Recommended, Use Azure Functions Task)
options.functionAppContainer: Function App for Containers (Linux) (Not Recommended, Use Azure Functions for container Task)

inputs.name: WebAppKind
inputs.label: App Service type
inputs.helpMarkDown: Choose from Web App On Windows, Web App On Linux, Web App for Containers, Function App, Function App on Linux, Function App for Containers and Mobile App.

inputs.name: WebAppName
inputs.label: App Service name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter or Select the name of an existing Azure App Service. App services based on selected app type will only be listed.

inputs.name: DeployToSlotOrASEFlag
inputs.label: Deploy to Slot or App Service Environment
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Select the option to deploy to an existing deployment slot or Azure App Service Environment.
For both the targets, the task needs Resource group name.
In case the deployment target is a slot, by default the deployment is done to the production slot. Any other existing slot name can also be provided.
In case the deployment target is an Azure App Service environment, leave the slot name as ‘production’ and just specify the Resource group name.

inputs.name: ResourceGroupName
inputs.label: Resource group
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The Resource group name is required when the deployment target is either a deployment slot or an App Service Environment.
Enter or Select the Azure Resource group that contains the Azure App Service specified above.

inputs.name: SlotName
inputs.label: Slot
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter or Select an existing Slot other than the Production slot.

inputs.name: DockerNamespace
inputs.label: Registry or Namespace
inputs.helpMarkDown:
A globally unique top-level domain name for your specific registry or namespace.
Note: Fully qualified image name will be of the format: '`/`:`'. For example, 'myregistry.azurecr.io/nginx:latest'.
inputs.visibleRule: WebAppKind = webAppContainer || WebAppkind = functionAppContainer || WebAppKind = webAppHyperVContainer

inputs.name: DockerRepository
inputs.label: Image
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Name of the repository where the container images are stored.
Note: Fully qualified image name will be of the format: '`/`:`'. For example, 'myregistry.azurecr.io/nginx:latest'.
inputs.visibleRule: WebAppKind = webAppContainer || WebAppkind = functionAppContainer || WebAppKind = webAppHyperVContainer

inputs.name: DockerImageTag
inputs.label: Tag
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Tags are optional, it is the mechanism that registries use to give Docker images a version.
Note: Fully qualified image name will be of the format: '`/`:`'. For example, 'myregistry.azurecr.io/nginx:latest'.
inputs.visibleRule: WebAppKind = webAppContainer || WebAppkind = functionAppContainer || WebAppKind = webAppHyperVContainer

inputs.name: VirtualApplication
inputs.label: Virtual application
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the name of the Virtual application that has been configured in the Azure portal. The option is not required for deployments to the App Service root.
inputs.visibleRule: WebAppKind != webAppLinux && WebAppKind != webAppContainer && WebAppKind != webAppHyperVContainer && WebAppkind != functionAppContainer && WebAppKind != functionApp && webAppKind != functionAppLinux && WebAppKind != ""

inputs.name: Package
inputs.label: Package or folder
inputs.helpMarkDown:
File path to the package or a folder containing app service contents generated by MSBuild or a compressed zip or war file.
Variables ( [Build](https://docs.microsoft.com/vsts/pipelines/build/variables) | [Release](https://docs.microsoft.com/vsts/pipelines/release/variables#default-variables)), wildcards are supported.
For example, $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/\*\*/\*.zip or $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/\*\*/\*.war.
inputs.visibleRule: ConnectionType = PublishProfile || WebAppKind = webApp || WebAppKind = apiApp || WebAppKind = functionApp || WebAppKind = mobileApp || WebAppKind = webAppLinux || webAppKind = functionAppLinux

inputs.name: RuntimeStack
inputs.label: Runtime Stack
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the framework and version.

inputs.name: RuntimeStackFunction
inputs.label: Runtime Stack
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the framework and version. Refer [this doc](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/azure-functions/functions-versions#languages) for supported runtime versions. Old values like `DOCKER|microsoft/azure-functions-*` are deprecated, please use the new values from dropdown.

inputs.name: StartupCommand
inputs.label: Startup command
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Enter the start up command. For ex.
dotnet exec filename.dll
dotnet filename.dll
inputs.visibleRule: WebAppKind = webAppLinux || WebAppKind = webAppContainer || WebAppkind = functionAppContainer || WebAppKind = functionAppLinux || WebAppKind = webAppHyperVContainer

options: Select deployment script type (inline or file)

inputs.name: ScriptType
inputs.label: Deployment script type
inputs.helpMarkDown: Customize the deployment by providing a script that will run on the Azure App service once the task has completed the deployment successfully . For example restore packages for Node, PHP, Python applications. [Learn more](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=843471).

inputs.name: InlineScript
inputs.label: Inline Script
inputs.defaultValue: :: You can provide your deployment commands here. One command per line.

inputs.name: WebConfigParameters
inputs.label: Generate web.config parameters for Python, Node.js, Go and Java apps
inputs.helpMarkDown: A standard Web.config will be generated and deployed to Azure App Service if the application does not have one. The values in web.config can be edited and vary based on the application framework. For example for node.js application, web.config will have startup file and iis_node module values. This edit feature is only for the generated web.config. [Learn more](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=843469).

inputs.name: AppSettings
inputs.label: App settings
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Edit web app application settings following the syntax -key value . Value containing spaces should be enclosed in double quotes.
Example : -Port 5000 -RequestTimeout 5000
-WEBSITE_TIME_ZONE "Eastern Standard Time"

inputs.name: ConfigurationSettings
inputs.label: Configuration settings
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Edit web app configuration settings following the syntax -key value. Value containing spaces should be enclosed in double quotes.
Example : -phpVersion 5.6 -linuxFxVersion: node|6.11

inputs.name: UseWebDeploy
inputs.label: Select deployment method
inputs.helpMarkDown:
If unchecked we will auto-detect the best deployment method based on your app type, package format and other parameters.
Select the option to view the supported deployment methods and choose one for deploying your app.

inputs.name: DeploymentType
inputs.label: Deployment method
inputs.helpMarkDown: Choose the deployment method for the app.

inputs.name: TakeAppOfflineFlag
inputs.label: Take App Offline
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to take the Azure App Service offline by placing an app_offline.htm file in the root directory of the App Service before the sync operation begins. The file will be removed after the sync operation completes successfully.

inputs.name: SetParametersFile
inputs.label: SetParameters file
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optional: location of the SetParameters.xml file to use.

inputs.name: RemoveAdditionalFilesFlag
inputs.label: Remove additional files at destination
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Select the option to delete files on the Azure App Service that have no matching files in the App Service package or folder.

Note: This will also remove all files related to any extension installed on this Azure App Service. To prevent this, select 'Exclude files from App_Data folder' checkbox.

inputs.name: ExcludeFilesFromAppDataFlag
inputs.label: Exclude files from the App_Data folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to prevent files in the App_Data folder from being deployed to/ deleted from the Azure App Service.

inputs.name: AdditionalArguments
inputs.label: Additional arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Additional Web Deploy arguments following the syntax -key:value .
These will be applied when deploying the Azure App Service. Example: -disableLink:AppPoolExtension -disableLink:ContentExtension.
For more examples of Web Deploy operation settings, refer to [this](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=838471).

inputs.name: RenameFilesFlag
inputs.label: Rename locked files
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to enable msdeploy flag MSDEPLOY_RENAME_LOCKED_FILES=1 in Azure App Service application settings. The option if set enables msdeploy to rename locked files that are locked during app deployment

inputs.name: XmlTransformation
inputs.label: XML transformation
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The config transforms will be run for `*.Release.config` and `*..config` on the `*.config file`.
Config transforms will be run prior to the Variable Substitution.
XML transformations are supported only for Windows platform.

inputs.name: XmlVariableSubstitution
inputs.label: XML variable substitution
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Variables defined in the build or release pipelines will be matched against the 'key' or 'name' entries in the appSettings, applicationSettings, and connectionStrings sections of any config file and parameters.xml. Variable Substitution is run after config transforms.

Note: If same variables are defined in the release pipeline and in the environment, then the environment variables will supersede the release pipeline variables.

inputs.name: JSONFiles
inputs.label: JSON variable substitution
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide new line separated list of JSON files to substitute the variable values. Files names are to be provided relative to the root folder.
To substitute JSON variables that are nested or hierarchical, specify them using JSONPath expressions.

For example, to replace the value of ‘ConnectionString’ in the sample below, you need to define a variable as ‘Data.DefaultConnection.ConnectionString’ in the build or release pipeline (or release pipeline's environment).
{
  "Data": {
    "DefaultConnection": {
      "ConnectionString": "Server=(localdb)\SQLEXPRESS;Database=MyDB;Trusted_Connection=True"
    }
  }
}
Variable Substitution is run after configuration transforms.

Note: pipeline variables are excluded in substitution.

inputs.name: ConnectionType
inputs.label: Connection type
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Select the service connection type to use to deploy the Web App.
Select Publish Profile for using Visual Studio created Publish profile. [More Information](https://aka.ms/vsPublishProfile).

inputs.name: ConnectedServiceName
inputs.label: Azure subscription
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the Azure Resource Manager subscription for the deployment.

inputs.name: PublishProfilePath
inputs.label: Publish profile path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path of the Publish profile created from Visual Studio

inputs.name: PublishProfilePassword
inputs.label: Publish profile password
inputs.helpMarkDown: It is recommended to store password in a secret variable and use that variable here e.g. $(Password).

options.functionApp: Function App on Windows (Not Recommended, Use Azure Functions Task)
options.functionAppLinux: Function App on Linux (Not Recommended, Use Azure Functions Task)
options.functionAppContainer: Function App for Containers (Linux) (Not Recommended, Use Azure Functions for container Task)

inputs.name: WebAppKind
inputs.label: App Service type
inputs.helpMarkDown: Choose from Web App On Windows, Web App On Linux, Web App for Containers, Function App, Function App on Linux, Function App for Containers and Mobile App.

inputs.name: WebAppName
inputs.label: App Service name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter or Select the name of an existing Azure App Service. App services based on selected app type will only be listed.

inputs.name: DeployToSlotOrASEFlag
inputs.label: Deploy to Slot or App Service Environment
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Select the option to deploy to an existing deployment slot or Azure App Service Environment.
For both the targets, the task needs Resource group name.
In case the deployment target is a slot, by default the deployment is done to the production slot. Any other existing slot name can also be provided.
In case the deployment target is an Azure App Service environment, leave the slot name as ‘production’ and just specify the Resource group name.

inputs.name: ResourceGroupName
inputs.label: Resource group
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The Resource group name is required when the deployment target is either a deployment slot or an App Service Environment.
Enter or Select the Azure Resource group that contains the Azure App Service specified above.

inputs.name: SlotName
inputs.label: Slot
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter or Select an existing Slot other than the Production slot.

inputs.name: DockerNamespace
inputs.label: Registry or Namespace
inputs.helpMarkDown:
A globally unique top-level domain name for your specific registry or namespace.
Note: Fully qualified image name will be of the format: '`/`:`'. For example, 'myregistry.azurecr.io/nginx:latest'.
inputs.visibleRule: WebAppKind = webAppContainer || WebAppkind = functionAppContainer || WebAppKind = webAppHyperVContainer

inputs.name: DockerRepository
inputs.label: Image
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Name of the repository where the container images are stored.
Note: Fully qualified image name will be of the format: '`/`:`'. For example, 'myregistry.azurecr.io/nginx:latest'.
inputs.visibleRule: WebAppKind = webAppContainer || WebAppkind = functionAppContainer || WebAppKind = webAppHyperVContainer

inputs.name: DockerImageTag
inputs.label: Tag
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Tags are optional, it is the mechanism that registries use to give Docker images a version.
Note: Fully qualified image name will be of the format: '`/`:`'. For example, 'myregistry.azurecr.io/nginx:latest'.
inputs.visibleRule: WebAppKind = webAppContainer || WebAppkind = functionAppContainer || WebAppKind = webAppHyperVContainer

inputs.name: VirtualApplication
inputs.label: Virtual application
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the name of the Virtual application that has been configured in the Azure portal. The option is not required for deployments to the App Service root.
inputs.visibleRule: WebAppKind != webAppLinux && WebAppKind != webAppContainer && WebAppKind != webAppHyperVContainer && WebAppkind != functionAppContainer && WebAppKind != functionApp && webAppKind != functionAppLinux && WebAppKind != ""

inputs.name: Package
inputs.label: Package or folder
inputs.helpMarkDown:
File path to the package or a folder containing app service contents generated by MSBuild or a compressed zip or war file.
Variables ( [Build](https://docs.microsoft.com/vsts/pipelines/build/variables) | [Release](https://docs.microsoft.com/vsts/pipelines/release/variables#default-variables)), wildcards are supported.
For example, $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/\*\*/\*.zip or $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/\*\*/\*.war.
inputs.visibleRule: ConnectionType = PublishProfile || WebAppKind = webApp || WebAppKind = apiApp || WebAppKind = functionApp || WebAppKind = mobileApp || WebAppKind = webAppLinux || webAppKind = functionAppLinux

inputs.name: RuntimeStack
inputs.label: Runtime Stack
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the framework and version.

inputs.name: RuntimeStackFunction
inputs.label: Runtime Stack
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the framework and version. Refer [this doc](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/azure-functions/functions-versions#languages) for supported runtime versions. Old values like `DOCKER|microsoft/azure-functions-*` are deprecated, please use the new values from dropdown.

inputs.name: StartupCommand
inputs.label: Startup command
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Enter the start up command. For ex.
dotnet exec filename.dll
dotnet filename.dll
inputs.visibleRule: WebAppKind = webAppLinux || WebAppKind = webAppContainer || WebAppkind = functionAppContainer || WebAppKind = functionAppLinux || WebAppKind = webAppHyperVContainer

options: Select deployment script type (inline or file)

inputs.name: ScriptType
inputs.label: Deployment script type
inputs.helpMarkDown: Customize the deployment by providing a script that will run on the Azure App service once the task has completed the deployment successfully . For example restore packages for Node, PHP, Python applications. [Learn more](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=843471).

inputs.name: InlineScript
inputs.label: Inline Script
inputs.defaultValue: :: You can provide your deployment commands here. One command per line.

inputs.name: WebConfigParameters
inputs.label: Generate web.config parameters for Python, Node.js, Go and Java apps
inputs.helpMarkDown: A standard Web.config will be generated and deployed to Azure App Service if the application does not have one. The values in web.config can be edited and vary based on the application framework. For example for node.js application, web.config will have startup file and iis_node module values. This edit feature is only for the generated web.config. [Learn more](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=843469).

inputs.name: AppSettings
inputs.label: App settings
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Edit web app application settings following the syntax -key value . Value containing spaces should be enclosed in double quotes.
Example : -Port 5000 -RequestTimeout 5000
-WEBSITE_TIME_ZONE "Eastern Standard Time"

inputs.name: ConfigurationSettings
inputs.label: Configuration settings
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Edit web app configuration settings following the syntax -key value. Value containing spaces should be enclosed in double quotes.
Example : -phpVersion 5.6 -linuxFxVersion: node|6.11

inputs.name: UseWebDeploy
inputs.label: Select deployment method
inputs.helpMarkDown:
If unchecked we will auto-detect the best deployment method based on your app type, package format and other parameters.
Select the option to view the supported deployment methods and choose one for deploying your app.

inputs.name: DeploymentType
inputs.label: Deployment method
inputs.helpMarkDown: Choose the deployment method for the app.

inputs.name: TakeAppOfflineFlag
inputs.label: Take App Offline
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to take the Azure App Service offline by placing an app_offline.htm file in the root directory of the App Service before the sync operation begins. The file will be removed after the sync operation completes successfully.

inputs.name: SetParametersFile
inputs.label: SetParameters file
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optional: location of the SetParameters.xml file to use.

inputs.name: RemoveAdditionalFilesFlag
inputs.label: Remove additional files at destination
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Select the option to delete files on the Azure App Service that have no matching files in the App Service package or folder.

Note: This will also remove all files related to any extension installed on this Azure App Service. To prevent this, select 'Exclude files from App_Data folder' checkbox.

inputs.name: ExcludeFilesFromAppDataFlag
inputs.label: Exclude files from the App_Data folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to prevent files in the App_Data folder from being deployed to/ deleted from the Azure App Service.

inputs.name: AdditionalArguments
inputs.label: Additional arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Additional Web Deploy arguments following the syntax -key:value .
These will be applied when deploying the Azure App Service. Example: -disableLink:AppPoolExtension -disableLink:ContentExtension.
For more examples of Web Deploy operation settings, refer to [this](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=838471).

inputs.name: RenameFilesFlag
inputs.label: Rename locked files
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to enable msdeploy flag MSDEPLOY_RENAME_LOCKED_FILES=1 in Azure App Service application settings. The option if set enables msdeploy to rename locked files that are locked during app deployment

inputs.name: XmlTransformation
inputs.label: XML transformation
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The config transforms will be run for `*.Release.config` and `*..config` on the `*.config file`.
Config transforms will be run prior to the Variable Substitution.
XML transformations are supported only for Windows platform.

inputs.name: XmlVariableSubstitution
inputs.label: XML variable substitution
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Variables defined in the build or release pipelines will be matched against the 'key' or 'name' entries in the appSettings, applicationSettings, and connectionStrings sections of any config file and parameters.xml. Variable Substitution is run after config transforms.

Note: If same variables are defined in the release pipeline and in the environment, then the environment variables will supersede the release pipeline variables.

inputs.name: JSONFiles
inputs.label: JSON variable substitution
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide new line separated list of JSON files to substitute the variable values. Files names are to be provided relative to the root folder.
To substitute JSON variables that are nested or hierarchical, specify them using JSONPath expressions.

For example, to replace the value of ‘ConnectionString’ in the sample below, you need to define a variable as ‘Data.DefaultConnection.ConnectionString’ in the build or release pipeline (or release pipeline's environment).
{
  "Data": {
    "DefaultConnection": {
      "ConnectionString": "Server=(localdb)\SQLEXPRESS;Database=MyDB;Trusted_Connection=True"
    }
  }
}
Variable Substitution is run after configuration transforms.

Note: pipeline variables are excluded in substitution.

inputs.name: DeploymentTypeLinux
inputs.label: Deployment method
inputs.helpMarkDown: Choose the deployment method for the app.

inputs.name: CleanDeploymentFlag
inputs.label: Enable clean deployment
inputs.helpMarkDown: Deployment mode for complete sync (clean) deployment

tasks.releaseNotes:
What's new in Version 3.0:
  Supports File Transformations (XDT)
  Supports Variable Substitutions(XML, JSON)
Click [here](https://aka.ms/azurermwebdeployreadme) for more information.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

tasks.name: PowerShellOnTargetMachines
tasks.description: Execute PowerShell scripts on remote machines using PSSession and Invoke-Command for remoting
tasks.releaseNotes:
Use PSSession and invoke-command to perform remoting on target machines.

* Added support for inline script execution.

* Default and Credssp authentication are supported.

* Added options for error handling: ErrorActionPreference, ignoreLASTEXITCODE and Fail on Standard Error.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: Machines
inputs.label: Machines
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide a comma separated list of machine IP addresses or FQDNs along with ports. Port is defaulted based on the selected protocol.
Eg: dbserver.fabrikam.com,dbserver_int.fabrikam.com:5986,192.168.12.34:5986
Or provide build or release variables. Eg: $(variableName)
If you are using HTTPS, name/IP of machine should match the CN in the certificate.

inputs.name: UserName
inputs.label: Username
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Username for the target machines. The user should be a part of Administrators group or WinRM remote management users group.
Eg: Format: Domain\Admin User, Admin User@Domain, .\Admin User

inputs.name: UserPassword
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown:
password for the target machines.
It can accept variable defined in build or release pipelines as '$(passwordVariable)'.
You may mark variable type as 'secret' to secure it.

inputs.name: ScriptType
inputs.label: Script Type
inputs.helpMarkDown: The type of script to execute: Inline or File Path

inputs.name: ScriptPath
inputs.label: Script File Path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Location of the PowerShell script on the target machines or on a UNC path like C:\BudgetIT\Web\Deploy\Website.ps1 which should be accessible from the target machine.

inputs.name: InlineScript
inputs.label: Script
inputs.defaultValue:
# Write your powershell commands here.

Write-Output "Hello World"

inputs.name: ScriptArguments
inputs.label: Script Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Arguments for the PowerShell script. Can be ordinal parameters or named parameters like -testParam test

inputs.name: InitializationScript
inputs.label: Initialization script
inputs.helpMarkDown: Location of the data script for DSC on the target machines or on a UNC path like C:\BudgetIT\Web\Deploy\WebsiteConfiguration.ps1

inputs.name: SessionVariables
inputs.label: Session Variables
inputs.helpMarkDown: Set common session variables for both the scripts. Variable assignments should be valid PowerShell statements.

inputs.name: CommunicationProtocol
inputs.label: Protocol
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the protocol to use for the WinRM service connection with the machine(s). Default is HTTPS.

inputs.name: AuthenticationMechanism
inputs.label: Authentication
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the authentication mechanism to be used for creating the pssession. For 'CredSSP' authentication, username and password fields are mandatory.

inputs.name: NewPsSessionOptionArguments
inputs.label: Session Option parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Advanced options for remote session (New-PSSessionOption). For example, -SkipCACheck, -SkipCNCheck, -SkipRevocationCheck etc. For a complete list of all session options, see [this](https://aka.ms/Vsts_PS_TM_v3_NewPSSessionOptions)

inputs.name: ErrorActionPreference
inputs.label: ErrorActionPreference
inputs.helpMarkDown: Prepends the line `$ErrorActionPreference = 'VALUE'` at the top of your script.

inputs.name: failOnStderr
inputs.label: Fail on Standard Error
inputs.helpMarkDown: If this is true, this task will fail if any errors are written to the error pipeline, or if any data is written to the Standard Error stream. Otherwise the task will rely on the exit code to determine failure.

inputs.name: ignoreLASTEXITCODE
inputs.label: Ignore $LASTEXITCODE
inputs.helpMarkDown: If this is false, the line `if ((Test-Path -LiteralPath variable:\LASTEXITCODE)) { exit $LASTEXITCODE }` is executed at the end of your script. This will cause the last exit code from an external command to be propagated as the exit code of powershell. Otherwise the line is not executed to the end of your script.

inputs.name: WorkingDirectory
inputs.label: Working Directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Working directory where the script is run.

inputs.name: RunPowershellInParallel
inputs.label: Run PowerShell in Parallel
inputs.helpMarkDown: Setting it to true will run the PowerShell scripts in parallel on the target machines.

tasks.name: PowerShellOnTargetMachines
tasks.description: Execute PowerShell scripts on remote machine(s)
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: EnvironmentName
inputs.label: Machines
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide a comma separated list of machine IP addresses or FQDNs along with ports. Port is defaulted based on the selected protocol.
Eg: dbserver.fabrikam.com,dbserver_int.fabrikam.com:5986,192.168.12.34:5986
Or provide output variable of other tasks. Eg: $(variableName)
If you are using HTTPS, name/IP of machine should match the CN in the certificate.

inputs.name: AdminUserName
inputs.label: Admin Login
inputs.helpMarkDown: Administrator login for the target machines.

inputs.name: AdminPassword
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Administrator password for the target machines.
It can accept variable defined in Build/Release definitions as '$(passwordVariable)'.
You may mark variable type as 'secret' to secure it.

inputs.name: Protocol
inputs.label: Protocol
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the protocol to use for the WinRM connection with the machine(s). Default is HTTPS.

inputs.name: TestCertificate
inputs.label: Test Certificate
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to skip validating the authenticity of the machine's certificate by a trusted certification authority. The parameter is required for the WinRM HTTPS protocol.

inputs.name: ScriptPath
inputs.label: PowerShell Script
inputs.helpMarkDown: Location of the PowerShell script on the target machines or on a UNC path like C:\BudgetIT\Web\Deploy\Website.ps1

inputs.name: ScriptArguments
inputs.label: Script Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Arguments for the PowerShell script. Can be ordinal parameters or named parameters like -testParam test

inputs.name: InitializationScriptPath
inputs.label: Initialization Script
inputs.helpMarkDown: Location of the data script for DSC on the target machines or on a UNC path like C:\BudgetIT\Web\Deploy\WebsiteConfiguration.ps1

inputs.name: SessionVariables
inputs.label: Session Variables
inputs.helpMarkDown: Set common session variables for both the scripts. For example, $variable = value, $var1 = "value, 123"

inputs.name: RunPowershellInParallel
inputs.label: Run PowerShell in Parallel
inputs.helpMarkDown: Setting it to true will run the PowerShell scripts in parallel on the target machines.

inputs.name: ResourceFilteringMethod
inputs.label: Select Machines By
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optionally, select a subset of machines either by providing machine names or tags.

inputs.name: MachineNames
inputs.label: Filter Criteria
inputs.helpMarkDown: This input is valid only for machine groups or output variables and is not supported for flat list of machines yet. Provide a list of machines like, dbserver.fabrikam.com, webserver.fabrikam.com, 192.168.12.34, or tags like, Role:DB; OS:Win8.1. If multiple tags are provided, then the task will run in all the machines with the specified tags. The default is to run the task in all machines.

tasks.name: PowerShellOnTargetMachines

inputs.name: EnvironmentName

inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide a comma separated list of machine IP addresses or FQDNs along with ports. Port is defaulted based on the selected protocol.
Eg: dbserver.fabrikam.com,dbserver_int.fabrikam.com:5986,192.168.12.34:5986
Or provide output variable of other tasks. Eg: $(variableName)
If you are using HTTPS, name/IP of machine should match the CN in the certificate.

inputs.name: AdminUserName
inputs.label: Admin Login
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Administrator login for the target machines.
Eg: Format: Domain\Admin User, Admin User@Domain, .\Admin User

inputs.name: AdminPassword
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Administrator password for the target machines.
It can accept variable defined in build or release pipelines as '$(passwordVariable)'.
You may mark variable type as 'secret' to secure it.

inputs.name: Protocol
inputs.label: Protocol
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the protocol to use for the WinRM service connection with the machine(s). Default is HTTPS.

inputs.name: TestCertificate
inputs.label: Test Certificate
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to skip validating the authenticity of the machine's certificate by a trusted certification authority. The parameter is required for the WinRM HTTPS protocol.

inputs.name: ScriptPath
inputs.label: PowerShell Script
