inputs.name: ScriptArguments
inputs.label: Script Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Arguments for the PowerShell script. Can be ordinal parameters or named parameters like -testParam test

inputs.name: InitializationScriptPath
inputs.label: Initialization Script
inputs.helpMarkDown: Location of the data script for DSC on the target machines or on a UNC path like C:\BudgetIT\Web\Deploy\WebsiteConfiguration.ps1

inputs.name: SessionVariables
inputs.label: Session Variables
inputs.helpMarkDown: Set common session variables for both the scripts. For example, $variable = value, $var1 = "value, 123"

inputs.name: RunPowershellInParallel
inputs.label: Run PowerShell in Parallel
inputs.helpMarkDown: Setting it to true will run the PowerShell scripts in parallel on the target machines.

inputs.name: ResourceFilteringMethod
inputs.label: Select Machines By
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optionally, select a subset of machines either by providing machine names or tags.

inputs.name: MachineNames
inputs.label: Filter Criteria
inputs.helpMarkDown: This input is valid only for machine groups or output variables and is not supported for flat list of machines yet. Provide a list of machines like, dbserver.fabrikam.com, webserver.fabrikam.com, 192.168.12.34, or tags like, Role:DB; OS:Win8.1. If multiple tags are provided, then the task will run in all the machines with the specified tags. The default is to run the task in all machines.

tasks.name: PublishCodeCoverageResults
tasks.description: Publish Cobertura or JaCoCo code coverage results from a build
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: codeCoverageTool
inputs.label: Code coverage tool
inputs.helpMarkDown: The tool with which code coverage results are generated.

inputs.name: summaryFileLocation
inputs.label: Summary file
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path of the summary file containing code coverage statistics, such as line, method, and class coverage. The value may contain minimatch patterns. For example: `$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/MyApp/**/site/cobertura/coverage.xml`

inputs.name: pathToSources
inputs.label: Path to Source files
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Path to source files is required when coverage XML reports do not contain absolute path to source files. For e.g., JaCoCo reports do not use absolute paths and when publishing JaCoCo coverage for Java apps, the pattern would be similar to `$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/MyApp/src/main/java/`.
This input is also needed if tests are run in a docker container. This input should point to absolute path to source files on the host. For e.g., `$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/MyApp/`

inputs.name: reportDirectory
inputs.label: Report directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path of the code coverage HTML report directory. The report directory is published for later viewing as an artifact of the build. The value may contain minimatch patterns. For example: `$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/MyApp/**/site/cobertura`

inputs.name: additionalCodeCoverageFiles
inputs.label: Additional files
inputs.helpMarkDown: File path pattern specifying any additional code coverage files to be published as artifacts of the build. The value may contain minimatch patterns. For example: `$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/**/*.exec`

inputs.name: failIfCoverageEmpty
inputs.label: Fail when code coverage results are missing
inputs.helpMarkDown: Fail the task if code coverage did not produce any results to publish.

tasks.name: PublishCodeCoverageResults
tasks.description: Publish any of the code coverage results from a build
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: summaryFileLocation
inputs.label: Path to summary files
inputs.helpMarkDown: Paths to summary files containing code coverage statistics, such as line, method, and class coverage. Multiple summary files will be merged into a single report. Supports multiple lines of minimatch patterns. [More information](https://aka.ms/minimatchexamples)

inputs.name: pathToSources
inputs.label: Path to Source files
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Path to source files is required when coverage XML reports do not contain absolute path to source files. For e.g., JaCoCo reports do not use absolute paths and when publishing JaCoCo coverage for Java apps, the pattern would be similar to `$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/MyApp/src/main/java/`.
This input is also needed if tests are run in a docker container. This input should point to absolute path to source files on the host. For e.g., `$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/MyApp/`

inputs.name: failIfCoverageEmpty
inputs.label: Fail if code coverage results are missing
inputs.helpMarkDown: Fail the task if code coverage did not produce any results to publish.

tasks.name: RunVisualStudioTestsusingTestAgent
tasks.description: Deprecated: This task and it’s companion task (Visual Studio Test Agent Deployment) are deprecated. Use the 'Visual Studio Test' task instead. The VSTest task can run unit as well as functional tests. Run tests on one or more agents using the multi-agent job setting. Use the 'Visual Studio Test Platform' task to run tests without needing Visual Studio on the agent. VSTest task also brings new capabilities such as automatically rerunning failed tests.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: testMachineGroup
inputs.label: Machines
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a comma separated list of machine IP addresses or FQDNs. Eg: `dbserver.fabrikam.com or 192.168.12.34` Or provide output variable of other tasks. Eg: `$(variableName)` Or provide a Machine Group Name

inputs.name: dropLocation
inputs.label: Test Drop Location
inputs.helpMarkDown: Location where the test binaries have been dropped in the agent machine(s) as part of the 'Windows Machine File Copy' or 'Azure File Copy' task. System Environment Variables can also be used in location string. e.g., `%systemdrive%\Tests`, `%temp%\DropLocation` etc.

inputs.name: testSelection
inputs.label: Test Selection
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the way you want to run tests : using Test Assemblies or using Test Plan.

inputs.name: testPlan
inputs.label: Test Plan
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a Test Plan.

inputs.name: testSuite
inputs.label: Test Suite
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select Test Suites from the Test Plan.

inputs.name: testConfiguration
inputs.label: Test Configuration
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select Test Configuration.

inputs.name: sourcefilters
inputs.label: Test Assembly
inputs.helpMarkDown: Test binaries to run tests on. Wildcards can be used. For example, `**\*test*.dll;` for all dlls containing 'test' in their name.

inputs.name: testFilterCriteria
inputs.label: Test Filter criteria
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optionally specify the test case filter criteria. For example, `Owner=james&Priority=1`

inputs.name: runSettingsFile
inputs.label: Run Settings File
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to runsettings or testsettings file to use with the tests.

inputs.name: overrideRunParams
inputs.label: Override Test Run Parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Override parameters defined in the `TestRunParameters` section of runsettings file or `Properties` section of testsettings file. For example: `AppURL=$(DeployURL);Port=8080`. Note: Properties specified in testsettings file can be accessed via the TestContext using Test Agent 2017 Update 4 or higher.

inputs.name: codeCoverageEnabled
inputs.label: Code Coverage Enabled
inputs.helpMarkDown: Whether code coverage needs to be enabled.

inputs.name: customSlicingEnabled
inputs.label: Distribute tests by number of machines
inputs.helpMarkDown: Tests will be distributed based on the number of machines provided instead of number of test containers. Note that tests within a dll might also be distributed to multiple machines.

inputs.name: testRunTitle
inputs.label: Test Run Title
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a name for the Test Run.

inputs.name: platform
inputs.label: Platform
inputs.helpMarkDown: Platform against which the tests should be reported. If you have defined a variable for platform in your build task, use that here.

inputs.name: configuration
inputs.label: Configuration
inputs.helpMarkDown: Configuration against which the tests should be reported. If you have defined a variable for configuration in your build task, use that here.

inputs.name: testConfigurations
inputs.label: Test Configurations
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optionally associate a test case filter against a test configuration ID. Syntax: <Filter1>:<Id1>;DefaultTestConfiguration:<Id3>. For example: `FullyQualifiedName~Chrome:12`

inputs.name: autMachineGroup
inputs.label: Application Under Test Machines
inputs.helpMarkDown: Comma separated list of machines or output variable or Machine Group Name on which server processes such as W3WP.exe is running

tasks.name: ManualIntervention

inputs.name: emailRecipients

inputs.name: onTimeout
inputs.label: On timeout
inputs.helpMarkDown: Reject or resume this manual intervention automatically after it is pending for the specified timeout or 60 days, whichever is earlier.

tasks.name: Docker
tasks.description: Build, tag, push, or run Docker images, or run a Docker command
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: containerregistrytype
inputs.label: Container Registry Type
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select 'Azure Container Registry' to connect to it by using an Azure Service Connection. Select 'Container registry' to connect to Docker Hub or any other private container registry.

inputs.name: dockerRegistryEndpoint
inputs.label: Docker Registry Service Connection
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a Docker registry service connection. Required for commands that need to authenticate with a registry.

inputs.name: azureSubscriptionEndpoint
inputs.label: Azure subscription
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select an Azure subscription

inputs.name: azureContainerRegistry
inputs.label: Azure Container Registry
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select an Azure Container Registry in the selected Azure Subscription. The container image will be built and pushed to this container registry.

inputs.name: action
inputs.label: Action
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a Docker action.

inputs.name: dockerFile
inputs.label: Docker File
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to the Dockerfile.

inputs.name: addBaseImageData
inputs.label: Add base image metadata to image(s)
inputs.helpMarkDown: By default base image data like base image name and digest are added which helps with traceability. You can opt out of this default behavior by using this input.

inputs.name: buildArguments
inputs.label: Build Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Build-time variables for the Docker file. Specify each name=value pair on a new line.

inputs.name: defaultContext
inputs.label: Use Default Build Context
inputs.helpMarkDown: Set the build context to the directory that contains the Docker file.

inputs.name: context
inputs.label: Build Context
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to the build context.
inputs.visibleRule: action = Build an image && defaultContext = false

inputs.name: imageName
inputs.label: Image Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Name of the Docker image to build, push, or run.
inputs.visibleRule: action == Build an image || action == Push an image || action == Run an image

inputs.name: imageNamesPath
inputs.label: Image Names Path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to a text file that contains the names of the Docker images to tag or push. Each image name is contained on its own line.
inputs.visibleRule: action == Tag images || action == Push images

inputs.name: qualifyImageName
inputs.label: Qualify Image Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Qualify the image name with the Docker registry service connection's hostname if not otherwise specified.
inputs.visibleRule: action = Build an image || action = Tag images || action = Push an image || action = Push images || action = Run an image

inputs.name: additionalImageTags
inputs.label: Additional Image Tags
inputs.helpMarkDown: Additional tags for the Docker image being built or pushed.
inputs.visibleRule: action = Build an image || action = Tag images || action = Push an image || action = Push images

inputs.name: includeSourceTags
inputs.label: Include Source Tags
inputs.helpMarkDown: Include Git tags when building or pushing the Docker image.
inputs.visibleRule: action = Build an image || action = Tag image || action = Push an image || action = Push images

inputs.name: includeLatestTag
inputs.label: Include Latest Tag
inputs.helpMarkDown: Include the 'latest' tag when building or pushing the Docker image.
inputs.visibleRule: action = Build an image || action = Push an image || action = Push images

inputs.name: imageDigestFile
inputs.label: Image Digest File
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to a file that is created and populated with the full image repository digest of the Docker image that was pushed.
inputs.visibleRule: action = Push an image || action = Push images

inputs.name: containerName
inputs.label: Container Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Name of the Docker container to run.

inputs.name: ports
inputs.label: Ports
inputs.helpMarkDown: Ports in the Docker container to publish to the host. Specify each host-port:container-port binding on a new line.

inputs.name: volumes
inputs.label: Volumes
inputs.helpMarkDown: Volumes to mount from the host. Specify each host-dir:container-dir on a new line.

inputs.name: envVars
inputs.label: Environment Variables
inputs.helpMarkDown: Environment variables for the Docker container. Specify each name=value pair on a new line.

inputs.name: workDir
inputs.label: Working Directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: The working directory for the Docker container.

inputs.name: entrypoint
inputs.label: Entry Point Override
inputs.helpMarkDown: Override the default entry point for the Docker container.

inputs.name: containerCommand
inputs.label: Command
inputs.helpMarkDown: The docker run command first creates a writeable container layer over the specified image, and then starts it by using the specified run command. For example, if the image contains a simple Python Flask web application you can specify 'python app.py' to launch the web application.

inputs.name: detached
inputs.label: Run In Background
inputs.helpMarkDown: Run the Docker container in the background.

inputs.name: restartPolicy
inputs.label: Restart Policy
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a restart policy.
inputs.visibleRule: action = Run an image && detached = true

inputs.name: restartMaxRetries
inputs.label: Maximum Restart Retries
inputs.helpMarkDown: The maximum number of restart retries the Docker daemon attempts.
inputs.visibleRule: action = Run an image && detached = true && restartPolicy = onFailure

inputs.name: customCommand
inputs.label: Command
inputs.helpMarkDown: Docker command to execute, with arguments. For example, 'rmi -f image-name' to force remove an image.

inputs.name: dockerHostEndpoint
inputs.label: Docker Host Service Connection
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a Docker host service connection. Defaults to the agent's host.

inputs.name: enforceDockerNamingConvention
inputs.label: Force image name to follow Docker naming convention
inputs.helpMarkDown: If enabled docker image name will be modified to follow Docker naming convention. Converts upper case character to lower case and removes spaces in image name.

inputs.name: cwd
inputs.label: Working Directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Working directory for the Docker command.

inputs.name: memory
inputs.label: Memory limit
inputs.helpMarkDown: The maximum amount of memory available to the container as a integer with optional suffixes like '2GB'.

outputVariables.name: DockerOutput
outputVariables.description: Stores the output of the docker command

outputVariables.name: DockerOutputPath
outputVariables.description: The path of the file which contains the output of the build command.

inputs.name: containerCommand
inputs.label: Container command
inputs.helpMarkDown: The docker run command first creates a writeable container layer over the specified image, and then starts it by using the specified run command. For example, if the image contains a simple Python Flask web application you can specify 'python app.py' to launch the web application.
inputs.visibleRule: command = Run an image || command = run

inputs.name: runInBackground
inputs.label: Run in background
inputs.helpMarkDown: Run the Docker container in the background.
inputs.visibleRule: command = Run an image || command = run

inputs.name: restartPolicy
inputs.label: Restart policy
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a restart policy.

inputs.name: maxRestartRetries
inputs.label: Maximum restart retries
inputs.helpMarkDown: The maximum number of restart retries the Docker daemon attempts.

inputs.name: dockerHostEndpoint
inputs.label: Docker host service connection
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a Docker host service connection. Defaults to the agent's host.

inputs.name: enforceDockerNamingConvention
inputs.label: Force image name to follow Docker naming convention
inputs.helpMarkDown: If enabled Docker image name will be modified to follow Docker naming convention. Converts upper case character to lower case and removes spaces in image name.

inputs.name: memoryLimit
inputs.label: Memory limit
inputs.helpMarkDown: The maximum amount of memory available to the container as a integer with optional suffixes like '2GB'.

outputVariables.name: DockerOutput
outputVariables.description: The path of the file(s) which contains the output of the command. This contains two file paths (separated by newline characters) in case of buildAndPush command, and one file path for any other command.

tasks.name: Docker
tasks.description: Build or push Docker images, login or logout, start or stop containers, or run a Docker command
tasks.helpMarkDown: [Learn more about this task](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=848006) or [see the Docker documentation](https://docs.docker.com/)
tasks.releaseNotes:
Simplified the task YAML by:
 - Removing the Container registry type input
 - Removing complex inputs as they can be passed as arguments to the command.

inputs.name: containerRegistry

inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a Docker registry service connection. Required for commands that need to authenticate with a registry.

inputs.name: repository

inputs.name: Dockerfile

inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to the Dockerfile.

inputs.name: buildContext
inputs.label: Build context
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to the build context. Pass ** to specify the directory that contains the Dockerfile.

inputs.name: tags

inputs.helpMarkDown:
A list of tags in separate lines. These tags are used in build, push and buildAndPush commands. Ex:

beta1.1
latest

inputs.name: arguments
inputs.label: Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Docker command options. Ex:
For build command,
--build-arg HTTP_PROXY=http://10.20.30.2:1234 --quiet
inputs.visibleRule: command != login && command != logout && command != buildAndPush

inputs.name: addPipelineData
inputs.label: Add Pipeline metadata to image(s)
inputs.helpMarkDown: By default pipeline data like source branch name, build id are added which helps with traceability. For example you can inspect an image to find out which pipeline built the image. You can opt out of this default behavior by using this input.

inputs.name: addBaseImageData
inputs.label: Add base image metadata to image(s)
inputs.helpMarkDown: By default base image data like base image name and digest are added which helps with traceability. You can opt out of this default behavior by using this input.

inputs.name: container
inputs.label: Container
inputs.helpMarkDown: Name of the container. For use with start and stop commands.

tasks.name: JenkinsQueueJob
tasks.description: Queue a job on a Jenkins server
tasks.helpMarkDown: This step queues a job on a [Jenkins](https://jenkins.io/) server. Full integration capabilities require installation of the [Team Foundation Server Plugin](https://wiki.jenkins-ci.org/display/JENKINS/Team+Foundation+Server+Plugin) on Jenkins. [More Information](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=816956).
tasks.author: Microsoft

inputs.name: serverEndpoint
inputs.label: Jenkins service endpoint
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the service endpoint for your Jenkins instance.  To create one, click the Manage link and create a new Jenkins service endpoint.

inputs.name: jobName
inputs.label: Job name
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the Jenkins job to queue.  This must exactly match the job name on the Jenkins server.

inputs.name: isMultibranchJob
inputs.label: Job is of Multibranch Pipeline type
inputs.helpMarkDown: This job is of Multibranch Pipeline type.  If selected, enter the appropriate branch name. Requires Team Foundation Server Plugin for Jenkins v5.3.4 or later.

inputs.name: multibranchPipelineBranch
inputs.label: Multibranch Pipeline Branch
inputs.helpMarkDown: Queue this Multibranch Pipeline job on the specified branch. Requires Team Foundation Server Plugin for Jenkins v5.3.4 or later.

inputs.name: captureConsole
inputs.label: Capture console output and wait for completion
inputs.helpMarkDown: If selected, this step will capture the Jenkins build console output, wait for the Jenkins build to complete, and succeed/fail based on the Jenkins build result.  Otherwise, once the Jenkins job is successfully queued, this step will successfully complete without waiting for the Jenkins build to run.

inputs.name: capturePipeline
inputs.label: Capture pipeline output and wait for pipeline completion
inputs.helpMarkDown: If selected, this step will capture the full Jenkins build pipeline console output, wait for the full Jenkins build pipeline to complete, and succeed/fail based on the Jenkins build pipeline result.  Otherwise, once the first Jenkins job completes, this step will successfully complete without waiting for full Jenkins build pipeline to run.

inputs.name: parameterizedJob
inputs.label: Parameterized job
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select if the Jenkins job accepts parameters. This should be selected even if all default parameter values are used and no parameters are actually specified.

inputs.name: jobParameters
inputs.label: Job parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specify job parameters, one per line, in the form `=`

To set a parameter to an empty value (useful for overriding a default value), leave off the parameter value. For example, specify `=`

Variables are supported. For example, to set a `commitId` parameter value to the Git commit ID of the build, use: `commitId=$(Build.SourceVersion)`. See the [documentation on variables](https://www.visualstudio.com/docs/build/define/variables) for more details.

Supported Jenkins parameter types are:

  • `Boolean`
  • `Choice`
  • `Password`
  • `String`

outputVariables.name: JENKINS_JOB_ID
outputVariables.description: The ID of the Jenkins job instance queued by this task. Use this variable in the Jenkins Download Artifacts task to download the artifacts for this particular job instance.

inputs.name: failOnUnstableResult

inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies strictness of a success definition: whether to consider unstable as a failure or not. False for non-strict, and true for strict version.

inputs.name: retryCount

inputs.name: delayBetweenRetries

tasks.name: FtpUpload
tasks.description: Upload files using FTP
tasks.helpMarkDown: Upload files to a remote machine using the File Transfer Protocol (FTP), or securely with FTPS.  [More Information](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=809084).
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: credsType
inputs.label: Authentication Method
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use FTP service connection or enter connection credentials.

inputs.name: serverEndpoint
inputs.label: FTP Service Connection
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Select the service connection for your FTP server. To create one, click the Manage link and create a new Generic service connection, enter the FTP server URL for the server URL, e.g. `ftp://server.example.com`, and required credentials.

Secure connections will always be made regardless of the specified protocol (`ftp://` or `ftps://`) if the target server supports FTPS. To allow only secure connections, use the `ftps://` protocol, e.g. `ftps://server.example.com`. Connections to servers not supporting FTPS will fail if `ftps://` is specified.

inputs.name: rootFolder
inputs.label: Root folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: The source folder to upload files from.

inputs.name: filePatterns
inputs.label: File patterns
inputs.helpMarkDown: File paths or patterns of the files to upload.  Supports multiple lines of minimatch patterns.  [More Information](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=800269)

inputs.name: remotePath
inputs.label: Remote directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Upload files to this directory on the remote FTP server.

inputs.name: clean
inputs.label: Delete remote directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Delete the remote directory including its contents before uploading.

inputs.name: cleanContents
inputs.label: Clear remote directory contents
inputs.helpMarkDown: Recursively delete all contents of the remote directory before uploading.  The existing directory will not be deleted.  For better performance, consider using `Delete remote directory` instead.

inputs.name: overwrite
inputs.label: Overwrite
inputs.helpMarkDown: Overwrite existing files in the remote directory.

inputs.name: preservePaths
inputs.label: Preserve file paths
inputs.helpMarkDown:
If selected, the relative local directory structure is recreated under the remote directory where files are uploaded. Otherwise, files are uploaded directly to the remote directory without creating additional subdirectories.

For example, suppose your source folder is: `/home/user/source/` and contains the file: `foo/bar/foobar.txt`, and your remote directory is: `/uploads/`.
If selected, the file is uploaded to: `/uploads/foo/bar/foobar.txt`. Otherwise, to: `/uploads/foobar.txt`.

inputs.name: trustSSL
inputs.label: Trust server certificate
inputs.helpMarkDown: Selecting this option results in the FTP server's SSL certificate being trusted with ftps://, even if it is self-signed or cannot be validated by a Certificate Authority (CA).

inputs.name: customCmds

inputs.helpMarkDown: Optional FTP Commands that will be sent to the remote FTP server upon connection.

tasks.name: WindowsMachineFileCopy
tasks.description: Copy files to remote Windows machines
tasks.releaseNotes:
What's new in Version 2.0:
  Proxy support is being added.
   Removed support of legacy DTL machines.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: SourcePath
inputs.label: Source
inputs.helpMarkDown: Absolute path of the source folder or file on the local machine, or a UNC Share like c:\fabrikamfiber or \\\\fabrikamshare\fabrikamfiber.

inputs.name: MachineNames
inputs.label: Machines
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide a comma separated list of machine IP addresses or FQDNs.
Eg: dbserver.fabrikam.com,192.168.12.34
Or provide output variable of other tasks. Eg: $(variableName)

inputs.name: AdminUserName
inputs.label: Admin Login
inputs.helpMarkDown: Administrator login for the target machines.

inputs.name: AdminPassword
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Password for administrator login for the target machines.
It can accept a variable defined in build or release pipelines as '$(passwordVariable)'.
You may mark the variable as 'secret' to secure it.

inputs.name: TargetPath
inputs.label: Destination Folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Local Path on the target machines or an accessible UNC path for copying the files from the source like d:\fabrikam or \\\\fabrikam\Web.

inputs.name: CleanTargetBeforeCopy
inputs.label: Clean Target
inputs.helpMarkDown: Selecting it will clean the destination folder before copying the files.

inputs.name: CopyFilesInParallel
inputs.label: Copy Files in Parallel
inputs.helpMarkDown: Selecting it will copy files in parallel to the machines.

inputs.name: AdditionalArguments
inputs.label: Additional Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Additional robocopy arguments that will be applied when copying files like, /min:33553332 /l.

tasks.name: IISWebAppDeploymentOnMachineGroup
tasks.description: Deploy a website or web application using Web Deploy
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.label: Website Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the name of an existing website on the machine group machines

inputs.name: VirtualApplication
inputs.label: Virtual Application
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the name of an already existing Virtual Application on the target Machines

inputs.name: Package
inputs.label: Package or Folder
inputs.helpMarkDown:
File path to the package or a folder generated by MSBuild or a compressed archive file.
Variables ( [Build](https://docs.microsoft.com/vsts/pipelines/build/variables) | [Release](https://docs.microsoft.com/vsts/pipelines/release/variables#default-variables)), wildcards are supported.
For example, $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)\\\*\*\\\*.zip.

inputs.name: SetParametersFile
inputs.label: SetParameters File
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optional: location of the SetParameters.xml file to use.

inputs.name: RemoveAdditionalFilesFlag
inputs.label: Remove Additional Files at Destination
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to delete files on the Web App that have no matching files in the Web App zip package.

inputs.name: ExcludeFilesFromAppDataFlag
inputs.label: Exclude Files from the App_Data Folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to prevent files in the App_Data folder from being deployed to the Web App.

inputs.name: TakeAppOfflineFlag
inputs.label: Take App Offline
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to take the Web App offline by placing an app_offline.htm file in the root directory of the Web App before the sync operation begins. The file will be removed after the sync operation completes successfully.

inputs.name: AdditionalArguments
inputs.label: Additional Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Additional Web Deploy arguments that will be applied when deploying the Azure Web App like,-disableLink:AppPoolExtension -disableLink:ContentExtension.

inputs.name: XmlTransformation
inputs.label: XML transformation
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The config transforms will be run for `*.Release.config` and `*..config` on the `*.config file`.
Config transforms will be run prior to the Variable Substitution.
XML transformations are supported only for Windows platform.

inputs.name: XmlVariableSubstitution
inputs.label: XML variable substitution
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Variables defined in the build or release pipeline will be matched against the 'key' or 'name' entries in the appSettings, applicationSettings, and connectionStrings sections of any config file and parameters.xml. Variable Substitution is run after config transforms.

Note: If same variables are defined in the release pipeline and in the environment, then the environment variables will supersede the release pipeline variables.

inputs.name: JSONFiles
inputs.label: JSON variable substitution
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide new line separated list of JSON files to substitute the variable values. Files names are to be provided relative to the root folder.
To substitute JSON variables that are nested or hierarchical, specify them using JSONPath expressions.

For example, to replace the value of ‘ConnectionString’ in the sample below, you need to define a variable as ‘Data.DefaultConnection.ConnectionString’ in the build or release pipeline (or release pipeline's stage).
{
  "Data": {
    "DefaultConnection": {
      "ConnectionString": "Server=(localdb)\SQLEXPRESS;Database=MyDB;Trusted_Connection=True"
    }
  }
}
Variable Substitution is run after configuration transforms.

Note: pipeline variables are excluded in substitution.

Run the [Use Python Version](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=871498) task to add a version of Python to PATH.

inputs.helpMarkDown: The working directory where the script will run. If not specified, the value of `System.DefaultWorkingDirectory` will be used. For builds, this variable defaults to the root of the repository. For releases, it defaults to the root of the artifacts directory.

inputs.name: failOnStderr

inputs.name: ConnectedServiceName
inputs.label: Azure subscription
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the Azure Subscription for the Azure App Configuration instance.

inputs.name: AppConfigurationEndpoint
inputs.label: App Configuration Endpoint
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the endpoint of an existing [Azure App Configuration](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-app-configuration/concept-key-value).

validation.message: Provide a valid app configuration endpoint.

inputs.name: SelectionMode
inputs.label: Selection Mode
inputs.helpMarkDown: Selection mode specifies how the key-values read from a configuration store are selected. The 'Default' selection mode allows the use of key and label filters. The 'Snapshot' selection mode allows key-values to be selected from a snapshot.

inputs.name: KeyFilter
inputs.label: Key Filter
inputs.helpMarkDown: The filter can be used to select what key-values are requested from Azure App Configuration. A value of '*' will select all key-values. [Reference for key-values query](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-app-configuration/concept-key-value#query-key-values).

inputs.name: Label
inputs.label: Label
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies which label should be used when selecting key-values from App Configuration. If no label is provided then key-values with the _null_ label will be retrieved. The following characters are not allowed: `,` `*`.

validation.message: The following characters are not allowed: '*', ','

inputs.name: SnapshotName
inputs.label: Snapshot name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies snapshot from which key-values should be retrieved in Azure App Configuration

inputs.name: TrimKeyPrefix
inputs.label: Trim Key Prefix
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies one or more prefixes that should be trimmed from App Configuration keys before setting them as variables. Multiple prefixes can be separated by a new-line character.

inputs.name: SuppressWarningForOverriddenKeys
inputs.label: Suppress warning for overridden keys
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies whether or not to suppress the warning shown when existing keys are overridden.

inputs.name: TreatKeyVaultErrorsAsWarning
inputs.label: Treat key vault resolution errors as warnings
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies whether to display key vault resolution errors as warning. By default, the task fails when encountering key vault resolution errors.

inputs.name: deployToSlotOrASE

inputs.helpMarkDown:
Select the option to deploy to an existing deployment slot or Azure App Service Environment.
For both the targets, the task needs Resource group name.
In case the deployment target is a slot, by default the deployment is done to the production slot. Any other existing slot name can also be provided.
In case the deployment target is an Azure App Service environment, leave the slot name as ‘production’ and just specify the Resource group name.

File path to the package or a folder containing app service contents generated by MSBuild or a compressed zip or war file.
Variables ( [Build](https://docs.microsoft.com/vsts/pipelines/build/variables) | [Release](https://docs.microsoft.com/vsts/pipelines/release/variables#default-variables)), wildcards are supported.
For example, $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/\*\*/\*.zip or $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/\*\*/\*.war.

inputs.label: Runtime stack
inputs.helpMarkDown: Refer [this doc](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/azure-functions/functions-versions#languages) for supported runtime versions.  Old values like `DOCKER|microsoft/azure-functions-*` are deprecated, please use the new values from dropdown.

-WEBSITE_TIME_ZONE "Eastern Standard Time"

E.g. if the template has a variable named "drop-location", then add a parameter here with name "drop-location" and a value which you want to use. You can link the value to a release variable as well. To view/edit the additional parameters in a grid, click on "…" next to text box.

inputs.label: Storage location
inputs.helpMarkDown: Location for storing the built machine image. This location will also be used to create a temporary VM for the purpose of building image.

inputs.name: storageAccountName
inputs.label: Storage account
inputs.helpMarkDown: Storage account for storing the built machine image. This storage account must be pre-existing in the location selected.

inputs.name: azureResourceGroup
inputs.label: Resource group
inputs.helpMarkDown: Azure Resource group that contains the selected storage account.

inputs.name: baseImageSource
inputs.label: Base image source
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the source of base image. You can either choose from a curated gallery of OS images or provide URL of your custom image.

inputs.name: baseImage
inputs.label: Base image
inputs.helpMarkDown: Choose from curated list of OS images. This will be used for installing pre-requisite(s) and application(s) before capturing machine image.

inputs.name: customImageUrl
inputs.label: Base image URL
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify URL of base image. This will be used for installing pre-requisite(s) and application(s) before capturing machine image.

inputs.name: packagePath
inputs.label: Deployment Package
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specify the path for deployment package directory relative to $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory). Supports minimatch pattern. Example path: FrontendWebApp/**/GalleryApp
Please note that this package will be copied to temporary virtual machine which Packer creates. If the package contains large number of files and/or the files are very large in size, the upload can take quite long time (possibly running into few hours). To optimize the upload time, please see if size of the package can be meaningfully reduced. Another alternative is to use an intermediary Azure storage account. Upload the package to a storage account prior to running this task. And for this task, use a package containing a script which will download the required package from the storage account.

inputs.name: deployScriptPath
inputs.label: Deployment script
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the relative path to powershell script(for Windows) or shell script(for Linux) which deploys the package. This script should be contained in the package path selected above. Supports minimatch pattern. Example path: deploy/**/scripts/windows/deploy.ps1

inputs.name: deployScriptArguments
inputs.label: Deployment script arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the arguments to be passed to deployment script.

inputs.name: additionalBuilderParameters
inputs.label: Additional Builder parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown:
In auto generated Packer template mode the task creates a Packer template with an Azure builder. This builder is used to generate a machine image. You can add keys to the Azure builder to customize the generated Packer template. For example setting ssh_tty=true in case you are using a CentOS base image and you need to have a tty to run sudo.
To view/edit the additional parameters in a grid, click on “…” next to text box.

inputs.name: skipTempFileCleanupDuringVMDeprovision
inputs.label: Skip temporary file cleanup during deprovision
inputs.helpMarkDown: During deprovisioning of VM, skip clean-up of temporary files uploaded to VM. Refer [here](https://www.packer.io/docs/builders/azure.html#skip_clean)

inputs.name: imageUri
inputs.label: Image URL
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a name for the output variable which will store generated machine image URL.

Please note that this package will be copied to temporary virtual machine which Packer creates. If the package contains large number of files and/or the files are very large in size, the upload can take quite long time (possibly running into few hours). tasks.name: NuGetPackager
tasks.description: Deprecated: use the “NuGet” task instead. It works with the new Tool Installer framework so you can easily use new versions of NuGet without waiting for a task update, provides better support for authenticated feeds outside this organization/collection, and uses NuGet 4 by default.
tasks.helpMarkDown: [Learn more about this task](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=627416) or [see the NuGet documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/nuget/)
tasks.author: Lawrence Gripper

inputs.name: searchPattern
inputs.label: Path to csproj or nuspec file(s) to pack
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Pattern to search for csproj or nuspec files to pack.

You can separate multiple patterns with a semicolon, and you can make a pattern negative by prefixing it with '-:'. Example: `**\*.csproj;-:**\*.Tests.csproj`

inputs.name: outputdir
inputs.label: Package Folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Folder where packages will be created. If empty, packages will be created alongside the csproj or nuspec file.

inputs.name: includeReferencedProjects
inputs.label: Include referenced projects
inputs.helpMarkDown: Include referenced projects either as dependencies or as part of the package. Cannot be used with automatic package versioning. If a referenced project has a corresponding nuspec file that has the same name as the project, then that referenced project is added as a dependency. Otherwise, the referenced project is added as part of the package. [Learn more](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-pack).

inputs.name: versionByBuild
inputs.label: Automatic package versioning
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Cannot be used with include referenced projects. If you choose 'Use the date and time', this will generate a [SemVer](http://semver.org/spec/v1.0.0.html)-compliant version formatted as `X.Y.Z-ci-datetime` where you choose X, Y, and Z.

If you choose 'Use an environment variable', you must select an environment variable and ensure it contains the version number you want to use.

If you choose 'Use the build number', this will use the build number to version you package. **Note:** Under General set the build format to be '[$(BuildDefinitionName)_$(Year:yyyy).$(Month).$(DayOfMonth)$(Rev:.r)](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=627416)'.

inputs.name: versionEnvVar
inputs.label: Environment variable
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter the variable name without $, $env, or %.

inputs.name: requestedMajorVersion
inputs.label: Major
inputs.helpMarkDown: The 'X' in version [X.Y.Z](http://semver.org/spec/v1.0.0.html)

inputs.name: requestedMinorVersion
inputs.label: Minor
inputs.helpMarkDown: The 'Y' in version [X.Y.Z](http://semver.org/spec/v1.0.0.html)

inputs.name: requestedPatchVersion
inputs.label: Patch
inputs.helpMarkDown: The 'Z' in version [X.Y.Z](http://semver.org/spec/v1.0.0.html)

inputs.name: configurationToPack
inputs.label: Configuration to Package
inputs.helpMarkDown: When using a csproj file this specifies the configuration to package

inputs.name: buildProperties
inputs.label: Additional build properties
inputs.helpMarkDown: Semicolon delimited list of properties used to build the package.

inputs.name: nuGetAdditionalArgs
inputs.label: NuGet Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Additional arguments passed to NuGet.exe pack. [More Information](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-pack).

inputs.name: nuGetPath
inputs.label: Path to NuGet.exe
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optionally supply the path to NuGet.exe

tasks.name: AzureAppConfigurationSnapshot
tasks.description: Create a configuration snapshot in Azure App Configuration through build or deployment pipelines
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: ConnectedServiceName
inputs.label: Azure subscription
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the Azure Subscription for the Azure App Configuration instance.

inputs.name: AppConfigurationEndpoint
inputs.label: App Configuration Endpoint
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the endpoint of an existing [Azure App Configuration](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-app-configuration/concept-key-value).

validation.message: Provide a valid app configuration endpoint.

inputs.name: SnapshotName
inputs.label: Snapshot Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a name for the snapshot.

inputs.name: CompositionType
inputs.label: Composition Type
inputs.helpMarkDown:
'Key': The filters are applied in order for this composition type. Each key-value in the snapshot is uniquely identified by the key only. If there are multiple key-values with the same key and multiple labels, only one key-value will be retained based on the last applicable filter. 
 'Key-Label': Filters will be applied and every key-value in resulting snapshot will be uniquely identified by the key and label together.

inputs.name: Filters
inputs.label: Filters for key-values
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies snapshot filters that represent the key and label filters used to build an App Configuration snapshot. Filters should be of a valid JSON format. Example [{"key":"abc*", "label":"1.0.0"}]. At least 1 filter and max of 3 filters can be applied.

inputs.name: RetentionPeriod
inputs.label: Days to retain archived snapshot
inputs.helpMarkDown: Archived snapshots can be recovered during the retention period. Choose the number of days the snapshot will be retained after it is archived. The value cannot be changed after creation.

validation.message: Allowed range for the retention period is from 0 days (minimum) to 90 days (maximum)

inputs.name: Tags
inputs.label: Tags
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies one or more tags that should be added to a snapshot. Tags should be of a valid JSON format and can span multiple lines. Example: {"tag1": "value1", "tag2": "value2"}

tasks.name: DuffleInstaller

inputs.name: version

This is typically false unless you have a specific scenario to always get latest. This will cause it to incur download costs when potentially not necessary, especially with the hosted build pool.

inputs.name: compareType

inputs.name: buildNumber
inputs.label: Build Number
inputs.helpMarkDown: The build number for comparison.

inputs.name: versionBehavior

inputs.name: updateOnlyChanged
inputs.label: Update only if changed
inputs.helpMarkDown: Incrementally update only the packages that have changed. Use the [deterministic compiler flag](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=808668) to ensure builds with the same inputs produce the same outputs.

inputs.name: pkgArtifactName
inputs.label: Package Artifact Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the artifact containing the application package for comparison.

inputs.name: logAllChanges
inputs.label: Log all changes
inputs.helpMarkDown: Compare all files in every package and log if the file was added, removed, or if its content changed. Otherwise, compare files in a package only until the first change is found for faster performance.

inputs.name: imageNamesPath

inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to a text file that contains the names of the Docker images associated with the Service Fabric application that should be updated with digests. Each image name must be on its own line and must be in the same order as the digests in Image Digests file. If the images are created by the Service Fabric project, this file is generated as part of the Package target and its output location is controlled by the property BuiltDockerImagesFilePath.

inputs.name: imageDigestsPath
inputs.label: Image Digests Path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to a text file that contains the digest values of the Docker images associated with the Service Fabric application. This file can be output by the [Docker task](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=848006) when using the push action. The file should contain lines of text in the format of 'registry/image_name@digest_value'.

tasks.name: AzureNLBManagement
tasks.description: Connect or disconnect an Azure virtual machine's network interface to a Load Balancer's back end address pool
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: ConnectedServiceName
inputs.label: Azure Subscription
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the Azure Resource Manager subscription for the deployment.

inputs.name: ResourceGroupName
inputs.label: Resource Group
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the resource group name.

inputs.name: LoadBalancer
inputs.label: Load Balancer Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select or enter the load balancer.

inputs.name: Action
inputs.label: Action
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Disconnect:  Removes the virtual machine’s primary network interface from the load balancer’s backend pool. So that it stops receiving network traffic.

Connect: Adds the virtual machine’s primary network interface to load balancer backend pool. So that it starts receiving network traffic based on the load balancing rules for the load balancer resource.

The other commands only output one file.

inputs.name: app

inputs.helpMarkDown: Relative path from repo root of the app(s) to test.  Wildcards can be used ([more information](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=856077)).  For example, `**/*.apk` for all APK files in all subfolders.

inputs.name: dsym

inputs.helpMarkDown: To make crash logs easier to read, you can upload a dSYM file that is associated with your app. This field only applies to iOS apps. Provide path relative to the .ipa file. Wildcards can be used ([more information](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=856077)). For example: *.dSYM

inputs.name: teamApiKey
inputs.label: Team API key
inputs.helpMarkDown: Your Xamarin Test Cloud Team API key can be found under "Teams & Apps" at https://testcloud.xamarin.com/account.

inputs.name: user
inputs.label: User email
inputs.helpMarkDown: User name this test will run under.

inputs.name: devices
inputs.label: Devices
inputs.helpMarkDown: The devices string is generated by Xamarin Test Cloud. It can be found as the value of the --devices command line argument of a Test Cloud test run.

inputs.name: series
inputs.label: Series
inputs.helpMarkDown: The series name for organizing test runs (e.g. master, production, beta).

inputs.name: testDir
inputs.label: Test assembly directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Relative path to the folder containing the test assemblies, such as: SolutionName/TestsProjectName/bin/Release

inputs.name: locale
inputs.label: System language
inputs.helpMarkDown: If your language isn't displayed, select 'Other' and enter its locale below, such as en_US.

inputs.name: userDefinedLocale
inputs.label: Other locale
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter any two-letter ISO-639 language code along with any two-letter ISO 3166 country code in the format [language]_[country], such as en_US.

inputs.name: testCloudLocation
inputs.label: test-cloud.exe location
inputs.helpMarkDown: The path to test-cloud.exe.  Wildcards can be used, in which case the first occurrence of test-cloud.exe is used ([more information](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=856077)).

inputs.name: optionalArgs

inputs.name: publishNUnitResults

tasks.name: ServiceFabricDeploy
tasks.description: Deploy an Azure Service Fabric application to a cluster
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: applicationPackagePath
inputs.label: Application Package
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to the application package that is to be deployed. [Variables](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=550988) and wildcards can be used in the path.

inputs.name: serviceConnectionName
inputs.label: Cluster Service Connection
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select an Azure Service Fabric service connection to be used to connect to the cluster. The settings defined in this referenced service connection will override those defined in the publish profile. Choose 'Manage' to register a new service connection.

inputs.name: publishProfilePath
inputs.label: Publish Profile
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to the publish profile file that defines the settings to use. [Variables](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=550988) and wildcards can be used in the path.

inputs.name: applicationParameterPath
inputs.label: Application Parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to the application parameters file. [Variables](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=550988) and wildcards can be used in the path. If specified, this will override the value in the publish profile.

inputs.name: overrideApplicationParameter
inputs.label: Override Application Parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Variables defined in the build or release pipeline will be matched against the 'Parameter Name' entries in the application manifest file. 
 Example: If your application has a parameter defined as below. 
 <Parameters> 
 <Parameter Name="SampleApp_PartitionCount" Value="1" /> 
 <Parameter Name="SampleApp_InstanceCount" DefaultValue="-1" /> 
 </Parameters> 
 and you want to change the partition count to 2, you can define a release pipeline or an environment variable "SampleApp_PartitionCount" and its value as "2". 

 Note: If same variables are defined in the release pipeline and in the environment, then the environment variables will supersede the release pipeline variables.

inputs.name: compressPackage
inputs.label: Compress Package
inputs.helpMarkDown: Indicates whether the application package should be compressed before copying to the image store. If enabled, this will override the value in the publish profile.

inputs.name: copyPackageTimeoutSec
inputs.label: CopyPackageTimeoutSec
inputs.helpMarkDown: Timeout in seconds for copying application package to image store. If specified, this will override the value in the publish profile.

inputs.name: registerPackageTimeoutSec
inputs.label: RegisterPackageTimeoutSec
inputs.helpMarkDown: Timeout in seconds for registering or un-registering application package.

inputs.name: overwriteBehavior
inputs.label: Overwrite Behavior
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Overwrite Behavior: when upgrade is not configured and an Application with same name already exists in the cluster, then following actions are available => Never, Always, SameAppTypeAndVersion.
    Never will not remove the existing Application. This is the default behavior.
    Always will remove the existing Application even if its Application type and Version is different from the Application being created.
    SameAppTypeAndVersion will remove the existing Application only if its Application type and Version is same as the Application being created.

inputs.name: skipUpgradeSameTypeAndVersion
inputs.label: Skip upgrade for same Type and Version
inputs.helpMarkDown: Indicates whether an upgrade will be skipped if the same application type and version already exists in the cluster, otherwise the upgrade fails during validation. If enabled, re-deployments are idempotent.

inputs.name: skipPackageValidation
inputs.label: Skip package validation
inputs.helpMarkDown: Indicates whether the package should be validated or not before deployment.

inputs.name: useDiffPackage
inputs.label: Use Diff Package
inputs.helpMarkDown: Upgrade by using a diff package that contains only the updated application files, the updated application manifest, and the service manifest files.

inputs.name: overridePublishProfileSettings
inputs.label: Override All Publish Profile Upgrade Settings
inputs.helpMarkDown: This will override all upgrade settings with either the values specified below or the default value if not specified.

inputs.name: unregisterUnusedVersions
inputs.label: Unregister Unused Versions
inputs.helpMarkDown: Indicates whether all unused versions of the application type will be removed after an upgrade.

inputs.name: FailureAction
inputs.label: FailureAction
inputs.visibleRule: overridePublishProfileSettings = true && isUpgrade = true && upgradeMode = Monitored

inputs.name: HealthCheckRetryTimeoutSec
inputs.label: HealthCheckRetryTimeoutSec
inputs.visibleRule: overridePublishProfileSettings = true && isUpgrade = true && upgradeMode = Monitored

inputs.name: HealthCheckWaitDurationSec
inputs.label: HealthCheckWaitDurationSec
inputs.visibleRule: overridePublishProfileSettings = true && isUpgrade = true && upgradeMode = Monitored

inputs.name: HealthCheckStableDurationSec
inputs.label: HealthCheckStableDurationSec
inputs.visibleRule: overridePublishProfileSettings = true && isUpgrade = true && upgradeMode = Monitored

inputs.name: UpgradeDomainTimeoutSec
inputs.label: UpgradeDomainTimeoutSec
inputs.visibleRule: overridePublishProfileSettings = true && isUpgrade = true && upgradeMode = Monitored

inputs.name: ConsiderWarningAsError
inputs.label: ConsiderWarningAsError
inputs.visibleRule: overridePublishProfileSettings = true && isUpgrade = true && upgradeMode = Monitored

inputs.name: DefaultServiceTypeHealthPolicy
inputs.label: DefaultServiceTypeHealthPolicy
inputs.visibleRule: overridePublishProfileSettings = true && isUpgrade = true && upgradeMode = Monitored

inputs.name: MaxPercentUnhealthyDeployedApplications
inputs.label: MaxPercentUnhealthyDeployedApplications
inputs.visibleRule: overridePublishProfileSettings = true && isUpgrade = true && upgradeMode = Monitored

inputs.name: UpgradeTimeoutSec
inputs.label: UpgradeTimeoutSec
inputs.visibleRule: overridePublishProfileSettings = true && isUpgrade = true && upgradeMode = Monitored

inputs.name: ServiceTypeHealthPolicyMap
inputs.label: ServiceTypeHealthPolicyMap
inputs.visibleRule: overridePublishProfileSettings = true && isUpgrade = true && upgradeMode = Monitored

inputs.name: configureDockerSettings
inputs.label: Configure Docker settings
inputs.helpMarkDown: Configures the application with the specified Docker settings.

inputs.name: registryCredentials
inputs.label: Registry Credentials Source
inputs.helpMarkDown: Choose how credentials for the Docker registry will be provided.

inputs.name: dockerRegistryEndpoint
inputs.label: Docker Registry Service Connection
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Select a Docker registry service connection. Required for commands that need to authenticate with a registry.
Note: task will try to encrypt the registry secret before transmitting it to service fabric cluster. However, it needs cluster's server certiticate to be installed on agent machine in order to do so. If certificate is not present, secret will not be encrypted.

inputs.name: azureSubscriptionEndpoint
inputs.label: Azure subscription
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Select an Azure subscription.
Note: task will try to encrypt the registry secret before transmitting it to service fabric cluster. However, it needs cluster's server certiticate to be installed on agent machine in order to do so. If certificate is not present, secret will not be encrypted.

inputs.name: registryUserName
inputs.label: Registry User Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Username for the Docker registry

inputs.name: registryPassword
inputs.label: Registry Password
inputs.helpMarkDown: Password for the Docker registry. If the password is not encrypted, it is recommended that you use a custom release pipeline secret variable to store it.

inputs.name: passwordEncrypted
inputs.label: Password Encrypted
inputs.helpMarkDown: It is recommended to encrypt your password using [Invoke-ServiceFabricEncryptText](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/service-fabric/service-fabric-application-secret-management#encrypt-application-secrets). If you do not, and a certificate matching the Server Certificate Thumbprint in the Cluster Service Connection is installed on the build agent, it will be used to encrypt the password; otherwise an error will occur.

tasks.name: Xcode
tasks.description: Build, test, or archive an Xcode workspace on macOS. Optionally package an app.
tasks.helpMarkDown: [Learn more about this task](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=613730) or [see the Xcode documentation](https://developer.apple.com/xcode/)
tasks.releaseNotes: This version of the task is compatible with Xcode 8 - 13. Features that were solely to maintain compatibility with Xcode 7 have been removed. This task has better options for using Microsoft-hosted macOS agents.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: actions
inputs.label: Actions
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter a space-delimited list of actions. Some valid options are `build`, `clean`, `test`, `analyze`, and `archive`. For example,`clean build` will run a clean build.

inputs.name: configuration
inputs.label: Configuration
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter the Xcode project or workspace configuration to be built. The default value of this field is the variable `$(Configuration)`. When using a variable, make sure to specify a value (for example, `Release`) on the **Variables** tab.

inputs.name: sdk
inputs.label: SDK
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify an SDK to use when building the Xcode project or workspace. From the macOS Terminal application, run `xcodebuild -showsdks` to display the valid list of SDKs. The default value of this field is the variable `$(SDK)`. When using a variable, make sure to specify a value (for example, `iphonesimulator`) on the **Variables** tab.

inputs.name: xcWorkspacePath
inputs.label: Workspace or project path
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter a relative path from the root of the repository to the Xcode workspace or project. For example, `MyApp/MyApp.xcworkspace` or `MyApp/MyApp.xcodeproj`. Wildcards can be used ([more information](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=856077)).

inputs.name: scheme
inputs.label: Scheme
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter a scheme name defined in Xcode. It must be a shared scheme, with its Shared checkbox enabled under Managed Schemes in Xcode. If you specify a Workspace or project path above without specifying a scheme, and the workspace has a single shared scheme, it will be automatically used.

inputs.name: xcodeVersion
inputs.label: Xcode version
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specify the target version of Xcode. Select `Default` to use the default version of Xcode on the agent machine. Selecting a version number (e.g. `Xcode 9`) relies on environment variables being set on the agent machine for the version's location (e.g. `XCODE_9_DEVELOPER_DIR=/Applications/Xcode_9.0.0.app/Contents/Developer`). Select `Specify path` to provide a specific path to the Xcode developer directory.
Note: XCode 12 is installed on macOS-10.15 (or higher)

inputs.name: xcodeDeveloperDir
inputs.label: Xcode developer path
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter a path to a specific Xcode developer directory (e.g. `/Applications/Xcode_9.0.0.app/Contents/Developer`). This is useful when multiple versions of Xcode are installed on the agent machine.

inputs.name: packageApp
inputs.label: Create app package
inputs.helpMarkDown: Indicate whether an IPA app package file should be generated as a part of the build.

inputs.name: archivePath
inputs.label: Archive path
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Specify a directory where created archives should be placed.

inputs.name: exportPath
inputs.label: Export path
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Specify the destination for the product exported from the archive.

inputs.name: exportOptions
inputs.label: Export options
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a way of providing options for exporting the archive. When the default value of `Automatic` is selected, the export method is automatically detected from the archive. Select `Plist` to specify a plist file containing export options. Select `Specify` to provide a specific **Export method** and **Team ID**.

inputs.name: exportMethod
inputs.label: Export method
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter the method that Xcode should use to export the archive. For example: `app-store`, `package`, `ad-hoc`, `enterprise`, or `development`.

inputs.name: exportTeamId
inputs.label: Team ID
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter the 10-character team ID from the Apple Developer Portal to use during export.

inputs.name: exportOptionsPlist
inputs.label: Export options plist
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter the path to the plist file that contains options to use during export.

inputs.name: exportArgs
inputs.label: Export arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter additional command line arguments to be used during export.

inputs.name: signingOption
inputs.label: Signing style
inputs.helpMarkDown: Choose the method of signing the build. Select `Do not code sign` to disable signing. Select `Project defaults` to use only the project's signing configuration. Select `Manual signing` to force manual signing and optionally specify a signing identity and provisioning profile. Select `Automatic signing` to force automatic signing and optionally specify a development team ID. If your project requires signing, use the "Install Apple..." tasks to install certificates and provisioning profiles prior to the Xcode build.

inputs.name: signingIdentity
inputs.label: Signing identity
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter a signing identity override with which to sign the build. This may require unlocking the default keychain on the agent machine. If no value is entered, the Xcode project's setting will be used.

inputs.name: provisioningProfileUuid
inputs.label: Provisioning profile UUID
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter the UUID of an installed provisioning profile to be used for this build. Use separate build tasks with different schemes or targets to specify separate provisioning profiles by target in a single workspace (iOS, tvOS, watchOS).

inputs.name: provisioningProfileName
inputs.label: Provisioning profile name
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter the name of an installed provisioning profile to be used for this build. If specified, this takes precedence over the provisioning profile UUID. Use separate build tasks with different schemes or targets to specify separate provisioning profiles by target in a single workspace (iOS, tvOS, watchOS).

inputs.name: teamId
inputs.label: Team ID
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional, unless you are a member of multiple development teams.) Specify the 10-character development team ID.

inputs.name: destinationPlatformOption
inputs.label: Destination platform
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the destination device's platform to be used for UI Development when the generic build device isn't valid. Choose `Custom` to specify a platform not included in this list. When `Default` is selected, no simulators nor devices will be targeted.

inputs.name: destinationPlatform
inputs.label: Custom destination platform
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter a destination device's platform to be used for UI Development when the generic build device isn't valid.

inputs.name: destinationTypeOption
inputs.label: Destination type
inputs.helpMarkDown: Choose the destination type to be used for UI Development. Devices must be connected to the Mac performing the build via a cable or network connection. See Devices and Simulators in Xcode.

inputs.name: destinationSimulators
inputs.label: Simulator
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter an Xcode simulator name to be used for UI Development. For example, enter `iPhone X` (iOS and watchOS) or `Apple TV 4K` (tvOS). A target OS version is optional and can be specified in the format 'OS=versionNumber', such as `iPhone X,OS=11.1`. A list of simulators installed on the Hosted macOS agent can be [found here](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=875290).
inputs.visibleRule: destinationPlatformOption != default && destinationPlatformOption != macOS && destinationTypeOption == simulators

inputs.name: destinationDevices
inputs.label: Device
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter the name of the device to be used for UI Development, such as `Raisa's iPad`.
inputs.visibleRule: destinationPlatformOption != default && destinationPlatformOption != macOS && destinationTypeOption == devices

inputs.name: args
inputs.label: Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter additional command line arguments with which to build. This is useful for specifying `-target` or `-project` arguments instead of specifying a workspace/project and scheme.

inputs.name: cwd
inputs.label: Working directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter the working directory in which to run the build. If no value is entered, the root of the repository will be used.

inputs.name: useXcpretty
inputs.label: Use xcpretty
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify whether to use xcpretty to format xcodebuild output. Enabling this requires xcpretty to be installed on the agent machine. If xcpretty is not installed, raw xcodebuild output is shown. xcpretty is preinstalled on Azure Pipelines hosted build agents. See [xcpretty](https://github.com/supermarin/xcpretty) on GitHub.

inputs.name: xcprettyArgs
inputs.label: Xcpretty arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Additional arguments to pass to xcpretty.

inputs.name: publishJUnitResults
inputs.label: Publish test results to Azure Pipelines
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify whether to publish JUnit test results to Azure Pipelines. This requires xcpretty to be enabled to generate JUnit test results.

inputs.name: testRunTitle
inputs.label: Test run title
inputs.helpMarkDown: Title of the test run when publishing JUnit test results to Azure Pipelines.

inputs.name: teamId

Choose 'File Contents' to use a P12 certificate and provisioning profile. Choose 'Identifiers' to retrieve signing settings from the default Keychain and pre-installed profiles. Leave the corresponding fields blank if you do not wish to override default build settings.

inputs.name: iosSigningIdentity

inputs.helpMarkDown: Optional relative path to file containing provisioning profile override to be used for this build. Use separate build tasks with different Schemes or Targets to specify separate provisioning profiles by target in a single workspace (iOS, WatchKit, tvOS).

inputs.name: removeProfile
inputs.label: Remove Profile After Build
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies that the contents of the Provisioning Profile File should be removed from the build agent after the build is complete. **Only check if you are running one agent per user.**

inputs.label: Working Directory

tasks.name: Xcode
tasks.description: Build, test, or archive an Xcode workspace on macOS. Optionally package an app.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: actions
inputs.label: Actions
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter a space-delimited list of actions. Valid options are `build`, `clean`, `test`, `analyze`, and `archive`. For example,`clean build` will run a clean build. See the [xcodebuild man page](https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/documentation/Darwin/Reference/ManPages/man1/xcodebuild.1.html).

inputs.name: configuration
inputs.label: Configuration
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter the Xcode project or workspace configuration to be built. The default value of this field is the variable `$(Configuration)`. When using a variable, make sure to specify a value (for example, `Release`) on the **Variables** tab.

inputs.name: sdk
inputs.label: SDK
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify an SDK to use when building the Xcode project or workspace. From the macOS Terminal application, run `xcodebuild -showsdks` to display the valid list of SDKs. The default value of this field is the variable `$(SDK)`. When using a variable, make sure to specify a value (for example, `iphonesimulator`) on the **Variables** tab.

inputs.name: xcWorkspacePath
inputs.label: Workspace or project path
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter a relative path from the root of the repository to the Xcode workspace or project. For example, `MyApp/MyApp.xcworkspace` or `MyApp/MyApp.xcodeproj`.

inputs.name: scheme
inputs.label: Scheme
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter a scheme name defined in Xcode. It must be a shared scheme, with its Shared checkbox enabled under Managed Schemes in Xcode. If you specify a Workspace or project path above without specifying a scheme, and the workspace has a single shared scheme, it will be automatically used.

inputs.name: xcodeVersion
inputs.label: Xcode version
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the target version of Xcode. Select `Default` to use the default version of Xcode on the agent machine. Selecting a version number (e.g. `Xcode 9`) relies on environment variables being set on the agent machine for the version's location (e.g. `XCODE_9_DEVELOPER_DIR=/Applications/Xcode_9.0.0.app/Contents/Developer`). Select `Specify path` to provide a specific path to the Xcode developer directory.

inputs.name: xcodeDeveloperDir
inputs.label: Xcode developer path
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter a path to a specific Xcode developer directory (e.g. `/Applications/Xcode_9.0.0.app/Contents/Developer`). This is useful when multiple versions of Xcode are installed on the agent machine.

inputs.name: packageApp
inputs.label: Create app package
inputs.helpMarkDown: Indicate whether an IPA app package file should be generated as a part of the build.

inputs.name: archivePath
inputs.label: Archive path
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Specify a directory where created archives should be placed.

inputs.name: exportPath
inputs.label: Export path
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Specify the destination for the product exported from the archive.

inputs.name: exportOptions
inputs.label: Export options
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a way of providing options for exporting the archive. When the default value of `Automatic` is selected, the export method is automatically detected from the archive. Select `Plist` to specify a plist file containing export options. Select `Specify` to provide a specific **Export method** and **Team ID**.

inputs.name: exportMethod
inputs.label: Export method
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter the method that Xcode should use to export the archive. For example: `app-store`, `package`, `ad-hoc`, `enterprise`, or `development`.

inputs.name: exportTeamId
inputs.label: Team ID
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter the 10-character team ID from the Apple Developer Portal to use during export.

inputs.name: exportOptionsPlist
inputs.label: Export options plist
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter the path to the plist file that contains options to use during export.

inputs.name: exportArgs
inputs.label: Export arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter additional command line arguments to be used during export.

inputs.name: signingOption
inputs.label: Signing style
inputs.helpMarkDown: Choose the method of signing the build. Select `Do not code sign` to disable signing. Select `Project defaults` to use only the project's signing configuration. Select `Manual signing` to force manual signing and optionally specify a signing identity and provisioning profile. Select `Automatic signing` to force automatic signing and optionally specify a development team ID. If your project requires signing, use the "Install Apple..." tasks to install certificates and provisioning profiles prior to the Xcode build.

inputs.name: signingIdentity
inputs.label: Signing identity
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter a signing identity override with which to sign the build. This may require unlocking the default keychain on the agent machine. If no value is entered, the Xcode project's setting will be used.

inputs.name: provisioningProfileUuid
inputs.label: Provisioning profile UUID
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter the UUID of an installed provisioning profile to be used for this build. Use separate build tasks with different schemes or targets to specify separate provisioning profiles by target in a single workspace (iOS, tvOS, watchOS).

inputs.name: teamId
inputs.label: Team ID
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional, unless you are a member of multiple development teams.) Specify the 10-character development team ID.

inputs.name: destinationPlatformOption
inputs.label: Destination platform
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the destination device's platform to be used for UI Development when the generic build device isn't valid. Choose `Custom` to specify a platform not included in this list. When `Default` is selected, no simulators nor devices will be targeted.

inputs.name: destinationPlatform
inputs.label: Custom destination platform
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter a destination device's platform to be used for UI Development when the generic build device isn't valid.

inputs.name: destinationTypeOption
inputs.label: Destination type
inputs.helpMarkDown: Choose the destination type to be used for UI Development. Devices must be connected to the Mac performing the build via a cable or network connection. See Devices and Simulators in Xcode.

inputs.name: destinationSimulators
inputs.label: Simulator
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter an Xcode simulator name to be used for UI Development. For example, enter `iPhone X` (iOS and watchOS) or `Apple TV 4K` (tvOS). A target OS version is optional and can be specified in the format 'OS=versionNumber', such as `iPhone X,OS=11.1`. A list of simulators installed on the Hosted macOS Preview agent can be [found here](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/mobile-center/build/software).
inputs.visibleRule: destinationPlatformOption != default && destinationPlatformOption != macOS && destinationTypeOption == simulators

inputs.name: destinationDevices
inputs.label: Device
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter the name of the device to be used for UI Development, such as `Raisa's iPad`.
inputs.visibleRule: destinationPlatformOption != default && destinationPlatformOption != macOS && destinationTypeOption == devices

inputs.name: args
inputs.label: Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter additional command line arguments with which to build. This is useful for specifying `-target` or `-project` arguments instead of specifying a workspace/project and scheme. See the [xcodebuild man page](https://developer.apple.com/library/mac/documentation/Darwin/Reference/ManPages/man1/xcodebuild.1.html).

inputs.name: cwd
inputs.label: Working directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter the working directory in which to run the build. If no value is entered, the root of the repository will be used.

inputs.name: outputPattern
inputs.label: Output directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: (Optional) Enter a path relative to the working directory where build output (binaries) will be placed. Examples: `output/$(SDK)/$(Configuration)` or `output/$(TestSDK)/$(TestConfiguration)`. Archive and export paths are configured separately.

inputs.name: useXcpretty
inputs.label: Use xcpretty
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify whether to use xcpretty to format xcodebuild output and generate JUnit test results. Enabling this requires xcpretty to be installed on the agent machine. It is preinstalled on VSTS hosted build agents. See [xcpretty](https://github.com/supermarin/xcpretty) on GitHub.

inputs.name: publishJUnitResults
inputs.label: Publish test results to VSTS/TFS
inputs.helpMarkDown: If xcpretty is enabled above, specify whether to publish JUnit test results to VSTS/TFS.
