inputs.helpMarkDown: Additional parameters to pass to PowerShell.  Can be either ordinal or named parameters.

tasks.name: VSTest
tasks.description: Run tests with Visual Studio test runner
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: testAssembly
inputs.label: Test Assembly
inputs.helpMarkDown: Test binaries to run tests on.  Wildcards can be used.  For example, `**\*test*.dll;-:**\obj\**` for all dlls with test in name while excluding files in any sub-directory named obj.

inputs.name: testFiltercriteria
inputs.label: Test Filter criteria
inputs.helpMarkDown: Additional criteria to filter tests from Test assemblies. For example: `Priority=1|Name=MyTestMethod`

inputs.name: runSettingsFile
inputs.label: Run Settings File
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to runsettings file to use with the tests. Use `$(Build.SourcesDirectory)` to access the Project folder.

inputs.name: overrideTestrunParameters
inputs.label: Override TestRun Parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Override parameters defined in the TestRunParameters section of runsettings file. For example: `AppURL=$(DeployURL);Port=8080`

inputs.name: codeCoverageEnabled
inputs.label: Code Coverage Enabled
inputs.helpMarkDown: Collect code coverage information from the Test run.

inputs.name: runInParallel
inputs.label: Run In Parallel
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enable parallel execution of your tests.

inputs.name: vsTestVersion
inputs.label: VSTest version
inputs.helpMarkDown: The version of VSTest to use.

inputs.name: vstestLocation
inputs.label: Path to vstest.console.exe
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optionally supply the path to VSTest.

inputs.name: pathtoCustomTestAdapters
inputs.label: Path to Custom Test Adapters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Directory path to custom test adapters. Nuget restored adapters are automatically searched for.

inputs.name: otherConsoleOptions
inputs.label: Other console options
inputs.helpMarkDown: Other Console options that can be passed to vstest.console.exe. Click on the help link below for more details.

inputs.name: testRunTitle
inputs.label: Test Run Title
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a name for the Test Run.

inputs.name: platform
inputs.label: Platform
inputs.helpMarkDown: Platform against which the tests should be reported. If you have defined a variable for platform in your build task, use that here.

inputs.name: configuration
inputs.label: Configuration
inputs.helpMarkDown: Configuration against which the tests should be reported. If you have defined a variable for configuration in your build task, use that here.

inputs.name: publishRunAttachments
inputs.label: Upload Test Attachments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Opt in/out of publishing test run level attachments.

tasks.name: VSTest
tasks.description: Run unit and functional tests (Selenium, Appium, Coded UI test, etc.) using the Visual Studio Test (VsTest) runner. Test frameworks that have a Visual Studio test adapter such as MsTest, xUnit, NUnit, Chutzpah (for JavaScript tests using QUnit, Mocha and Jasmine), etc. can be run. Tests can be distributed on multiple agents using this task (version 2 and later).
tasks.releaseNotes:
• Run tests using an agent job: Unified agent across Build, Release and Test allows for automation agents to be used for Development purposes as well. You can distribute tests using the multi-agent job setting. The multi-config job setting can be used to replicate tests in different configurations. More information
  • Test Impact Analysis: Automatically select and run only the tests needed to validate the code change.
  • Use the Visual Studio Test Platform Installer task to run tests without needing a full Visual Studio installation.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: testSelector
inputs.label: Select tests using
inputs.helpMarkDown:
• Test assembly: Use this option to specify one or more test assemblies that contain your tests. You can optionally specify a filter criteria to select only specific tests.
  • Test plan: Use this option to run tests from your test plan that have an automated test method associated with it.
  • Test run: Use this option when you are setting up an environment to run tests from the Test hub. This option should not be used when running tests in a continuous integration / continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipeline.

inputs.name: testAssemblyVer2
inputs.label: Test files
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Run tests from the specified files.
Ordered tests and webtests can be run by specifying the .orderedtest and .webtest files respectively. To run .webtest, Visual Studio 2017 Update 4 or higher is needed.

The file paths are relative to the search folder. Supports multiple lines of minimatch patterns. [More information](https://aka.ms/minimatchexamples)

inputs.name: testPlan
inputs.label: Test plan
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a test plan containing test suites with automated test cases.

inputs.name: testSuite
inputs.label: Test suite
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select one or more test suites containing automated test cases. Test case work items must be associated with an automated test method. [Learn more.](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=847773

inputs.name: testConfiguration
inputs.label: Test configuration
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select Test Configuration.

inputs.name: tcmTestRun
inputs.label: Test Run
inputs.helpMarkDown: Test run based selection is used when triggering automated test runs from the test hub. This option cannot be used for running tests in the CI/CD pipeline.

inputs.name: searchFolder
inputs.label: Search folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Folder to search for the test assemblies.

inputs.name: resultsFolder
inputs.label: Test results folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Folder to store test results. When this input is not specified, results are stored in $(Agent.TempDirectory)/TestResults by default, which is cleaned at the end of a pipeline run. The results directory will always be cleaned up at the start of the vstest task before the tests are run. Relative folder path if provided will be considered relative to $(Agent.TempDirectory)

inputs.name: testFiltercriteria
inputs.label: Test filter criteria
inputs.helpMarkDown: Additional criteria to filter tests from Test assemblies. For example: `Priority=1|Name=MyTestMethod`. [More information](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/jj155796.aspx)

inputs.name: runOnlyImpactedTests
inputs.label: Run only impacted tests
inputs.helpMarkDown: Automatically select, and run only the tests needed to validate the code change. [More information](https://aka.ms/tialearnmore)

inputs.name: runAllTestsAfterXBuilds
inputs.label: Number of builds after which all tests should be run
inputs.helpMarkDown: Number of builds after which to automatically run all tests. Test Impact Analysis stores the mapping between test cases and source code. It is recommended to regenerate the mapping by running all tests, on a regular basis.

inputs.name: uiTests
inputs.label: Test mix contains UI tests
inputs.helpMarkDown:
To run UI tests, ensure that the agent is set to run in interactive mode. Setting up an agent to run interactively must be done before queueing the build / release. Checking this box does not configure the agent in interactive mode automatically. This option in the task is to only serve as a reminder to configure agent appropriately to avoid failures.

Hosted Windows agents from the VS 2015 and 2017 pools can be used to run UI tests.
[More information](https://aka.ms/uitestmoreinfo).

inputs.name: vsTestVersion
inputs.label: Test platform version
inputs.helpMarkDown: The version of Visual Studio test to use. If latest is specified it chooses latest Visual Studio version starting from VS2022 followed by VS2019, VS2017 and VS2015 depending on what is installed. Visual Studio 2013 is not supported. To run tests without needing Visual Studio on the agent, use the ‘Installed by tools installer’ option. Be sure to include the ‘Visual Studio Test Platform Installer’ task to acquire the test platform from nuget.

inputs.name: vstestLocation
inputs.label: Path to vstest.console.exe
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optionally supply the path to VSTest.

inputs.name: runSettingsFile
inputs.label: Settings file
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to runsettings or testsettings file to use with the tests.

inputs.name: overrideTestrunParameters
inputs.label: Override test run parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Override parameters defined in the `TestRunParameters` section of runsettings file or `Properties` section of testsettings file. For example: `-key1 value1 -key2 value2`. Note: Properties specified in testsettings file can be accessed via the TestContext using Visual Studio 2017 Update 4 or higher

inputs.name: pathtoCustomTestAdapters
inputs.label: Path to custom test adapters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Directory path to custom test adapters. Adapters residing in the same folder as the test assemblies are automatically discovered.

inputs.name: runInParallel
inputs.label: Run tests in parallel on multi-core machines
inputs.helpMarkDown: If set, tests will run in parallel leveraging available cores of the machine. This will override the MaxCpuCount if specified in your runsettings file. [Click here](https://aka.ms/paralleltestexecution) to learn more about how tests are run in parallel.

inputs.name: runTestsInIsolation
inputs.label: Run tests in isolation
inputs.helpMarkDown: Runs the tests in an isolated process. This makes vstest.console.exe process less likely to be stopped on an error in the tests, but tests might run slower. This option currently cannot be used when running with the multi-agent job setting.

inputs.name: codeCoverageEnabled
inputs.label: Code coverage enabled
inputs.helpMarkDown: Collect code coverage information from the test run.

inputs.name: otherConsoleOptions
inputs.label: Other console options
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Other console options that can be passed to vstest.console.exe, as documented here.

These options are not supported and will be ignored when running tests using the ‘Multi agent’ parallel setting of an agent job or when running tests using ‘Test plan’ or 'Test run' option or when a custom batching option is selected. The options can be specified using a settings file instead.

options.basedOnTestCases: Based on number of tests and agents
options.basedOnExecutionTime: Based on past running time of tests

inputs.name: distributionBatchType
inputs.label: Batch tests
inputs.helpMarkDown:
A batch is a group of tests. A batch of tests runs its tests at the same time and results are published for the batch. If the job in which the task runs is set to use multiple agents, each agent picks up any available batches of tests to run in parallel.

Based on the number of tests and agents: Simple batching based on the number of tests and agents participating in the test run.

Based on past running time of tests: This batching considers past running time to create batches of tests such that each batch has approximately equal running time.

Based on test assemblies: Tests from an assembly are batched together.

inputs.name: batchingBasedOnAgentsOption
inputs.label: Batch options
inputs.helpMarkDown: Simple batching based on the number of tests and agents participating in the test run. When the batch size is automatically determined, each batch contains `(total number of tests / number of agents)` tests. If a batch size is specified, each batch will contain the specified number of tests.

inputs.name: customBatchSizeValue
inputs.label: Number of tests per batch
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify batch size

inputs.name: batchingBasedOnExecutionTimeOption
inputs.label: Batch options
inputs.helpMarkDown: This batching considers past running time to create batches of tests such that each batch has approximately equal running time. Quick running tests will be batched together, while longer running tests may belong to a separate batch. When this option is used with the multi-agent job setting, total test time is reduced to a minimum.

inputs.name: customRunTimePerBatchValue
inputs.label: Running time (sec) per batch
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the running time (sec) per batch

inputs.name: dontDistribute
inputs.label: Replicate tests instead of distributing when multiple agents are used in the job
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Choosing this option will not distribute tests across agents when the task is running in a multi-agent job.
Each of the selected test(s) will be repeated on each agent.
The option is not applicable when the agent job is configured to run with no parallelism or with the multi-config option.

inputs.name: testRunTitle
inputs.label: Test run title
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a name for the test run.

inputs.name: platform
inputs.label: Build platform
inputs.helpMarkDown: Build platform against which the tests should be reported. If you have defined a variable for platform in your build task, use that here.

inputs.name: configuration
inputs.label: Build configuration
inputs.helpMarkDown: Build configuration against which the tests should be reported. If you have defined a variable for configuration in your build task, use that here.

inputs.name: publishRunAttachments
inputs.label: Upload test attachments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Opt in/out of publishing run level attachments.

inputs.name: failOnMinTestsNotRun
inputs.label: Fail the task if a minimum number of tests are not run.
inputs.helpMarkDown: Selecting this option will fail the task if specified minimum number of tests is not run.

inputs.name: minimumExpectedTests
inputs.label: Minimum # of tests
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the minimum # of tests that should be run for the task to succeed. Total tests executed is calculated as the sum of passed, failed and aborted tests.

inputs.name: diagnosticsEnabled
inputs.label: Collect advanced diagnostics in case of catastrophic failures
inputs.helpMarkDown: Collect advanced diagnostics in case of catastrophic failures.

inputs.name: collectDumpOn
inputs.label: Collect process dump and attach to test run report
inputs.helpMarkDown: Collect process dump and attach to test run report.

inputs.name: rerunFailedTests
inputs.label: Rerun failed tests
inputs.helpMarkDown: Selecting this option will rerun any failed tests until they pass or the maximum # of attempts is reached.

inputs.name: rerunType
inputs.label: Do not rerun if test failures exceed specified threshold
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Use this option to avoid rerunning tests when failure rate crosses the specified threshold. This is applicable if any environment issues leads to massive failures.
You can specify % failures or # of failed tests as a threshold.

inputs.name: rerunFailedThreshold
inputs.label: % failure
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use this option to avoid rerunning tests when failure rate crosses the specified threshold. This is applicable if any environment issues leads to massive failures.

inputs.name: rerunFailedTestCasesMaxLimit
inputs.label: # of failed tests
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use this option to avoid rerunning tests when number of failed test cases crosses specified limit. This is applicable if any environment issues leads to massive failures.

inputs.name: rerunMaxAttempts
inputs.label: Maximum # of attempts
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the maximum # of times a failed test should be retried. If a test passes before the maximum # of attempts is reached, it will not be rerun further.

tasks.name: VSTest
tasks.description: Run unit and functional tests (Selenium, Appium, Coded UI test, etc.) using the Visual Studio Test (VsTest) runner. Test frameworks that have a Visual Studio test adapter such as MsTest, xUnit, NUnit, Chutzpah (for JavaScript tests using QUnit, Mocha and Jasmine), etc. can be run. Tests can be distributed on multiple agents using this task (version 2 and later).
tasks.releaseNotes:
• Run tests using an agent job: Unified agent across Build, Release and Test allows for automation agents to be used for Development purposes as well. You can distribute tests using the multi-agent job setting. The multi-config job setting can be used to replicate tests in different configurations. More information
  • Test Impact Analysis: Automatically select and run only the tests needed to validate the code change.
  • Use the Visual Studio Test Platform Installer task to run tests without needing a full Visual Studio installation.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: ConnectedServiceName
inputs.label: Azure Resource Manager connection
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select an Azure Resource Manager service connection

inputs.name: testSelector
inputs.label: Select tests using
inputs.helpMarkDown:
• Test assembly: Use this option to specify one or more test assemblies that contain your tests. You can optionally specify a filter criteria to select only specific tests.
  • Test plan: Use this option to run tests from your test plan that have an automated test method associated with it.
  • Test run: Use this option when you are setting up an environment to run tests from the Test hub. This option should not be used when running tests in a continuous integration / continuous deployment (CI/CD) pipeline.

inputs.name: testAssemblyVer2
inputs.label: Test files
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Run tests from the specified files.
Ordered tests and webtests can be run by specifying the .orderedtest and .webtest files respectively. To run .webtest, Visual Studio 2017 Update 4 or higher is needed.

The file paths are relative to the search folder. Supports multiple lines of minimatch patterns. [More information](https://aka.ms/minimatchexamples)

inputs.name: testPlan
inputs.label: Test plan
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a test plan containing test suites with automated test cases.

inputs.name: testSuite
inputs.label: Test suite
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select one or more test suites containing automated test cases. Test case work items must be associated with an automated test method. [Learn more.](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=847773

inputs.name: testConfiguration
inputs.label: Test configuration
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select Test Configuration.

inputs.name: tcmTestRun
inputs.label: Test Run
inputs.helpMarkDown: Test run based selection is used when triggering automated test runs from the test hub. This option cannot be used for running tests in the CI/CD pipeline.

inputs.name: searchFolder
inputs.label: Search folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Folder to search for the test assemblies.

inputs.name: resultsFolder
inputs.label: Test results folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Folder to store test results. When this input is not specified, results are stored in $(Agent.TempDirectory)/TestResults by default, which is cleaned at the end of a pipeline run. The results directory will always be cleaned up at the start of the vstest task before the tests are run. Relative folder path if provided will be considered relative to $(Agent.TempDirectory)

inputs.name: testFiltercriteria
inputs.label: Test filter criteria
inputs.helpMarkDown: Additional criteria to filter tests from Test assemblies. For example: `Priority=1|Name=MyTestMethod`. [More information](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/jj155796.aspx)

inputs.name: runOnlyImpactedTests
inputs.label: Run only impacted tests
inputs.helpMarkDown: Automatically select, and run only the tests needed to validate the code change. [More information](https://aka.ms/tialearnmore)

inputs.name: runAllTestsAfterXBuilds
inputs.label: Number of builds after which all tests should be run
inputs.helpMarkDown: Number of builds after which to automatically run all tests. Test Impact Analysis stores the mapping between test cases and source code. It is recommended to regenerate the mapping by running all tests, on a regular basis.

inputs.name: uiTests
inputs.label: Test mix contains UI tests
inputs.helpMarkDown:
To run UI tests, ensure that the agent is set to run in interactive mode. Setting up an agent to run interactively must be done before queueing the build / release. Checking this box does not configure the agent in interactive mode automatically. This option in the task is to only serve as a reminder to configure agent appropriately to avoid failures.

Hosted Windows agents from the VS 2015 and 2017 pools can be used to run UI tests.
[More information](https://aka.ms/uitestmoreinfo).

inputs.name: vsTestVersion
inputs.label: Test platform version
inputs.helpMarkDown: The version of Visual Studio test to use. If latest is specified it chooses latest Visual Studio version starting from VS2022 followed by VS2019, VS2017 and VS2015 depending on what is installed. Visual Studio 2013 is not supported. To run tests without needing Visual Studio on the agent, use the ‘Installed by tools installer’ option. Be sure to include the ‘Visual Studio Test Platform Installer’ task to acquire the test platform from nuget.

inputs.name: vstestLocation
inputs.label: Path to vstest.console.exe
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optionally supply the path to VSTest.

inputs.name: runSettingsFile
inputs.label: Settings file
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to runsettings or testsettings file to use with the tests.

inputs.name: overrideTestrunParameters
inputs.label: Override test run parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Override parameters defined in the `TestRunParameters` section of runsettings file or `Properties` section of testsettings file. For example: `-key1 value1 -key2 value2`. Note: Properties specified in testsettings file can be accessed via the TestContext using Visual Studio 2017 Update 4 or higher

inputs.name: pathtoCustomTestAdapters
inputs.label: Path to custom test adapters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Directory path to custom test adapters. Adapters residing in the same folder as the test assemblies are automatically discovered.

inputs.name: runInParallel
inputs.label: Run tests in parallel on multi-core machines
inputs.helpMarkDown: If set, tests will run in parallel leveraging available cores of the machine. This will override the MaxCpuCount if specified in your runsettings file. [Click here](https://aka.ms/paralleltestexecution) to learn more about how tests are run in parallel.

inputs.name: runTestsInIsolation
inputs.label: Run tests in isolation
inputs.helpMarkDown: Runs the tests in an isolated process. This makes vstest.console.exe process less likely to be stopped on an error in the tests, but tests might run slower. This option currently cannot be used when running with the multi-agent job setting.

inputs.name: codeCoverageEnabled
inputs.label: Code coverage enabled
inputs.helpMarkDown: Collect code coverage information from the test run.

inputs.name: otherConsoleOptions
inputs.label: Other console options
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Other console options that can be passed to vstest.console.exe, as documented here.

These options are not supported and will be ignored when running tests using the ‘Multi agent’ parallel setting of an agent job or when running tests using ‘Test plan’ or 'Test run' option or when a custom batching option is selected. The options can be specified using a settings file instead.

options.basedOnTestCases: Based on number of tests and agents
options.basedOnExecutionTime: Based on past running time of tests

inputs.name: distributionBatchType
inputs.label: Batch tests
inputs.helpMarkDown:
A batch is a group of tests. A batch of tests runs its tests at the same time and results are published for the batch. If the job in which the task runs is set to use multiple agents, each agent picks up any available batches of tests to run in parallel.

Based on the number of tests and agents: Simple batching based on the number of tests and agents participating in the test run.

Based on past running time of tests: This batching considers past running time to create batches of tests such that each batch has approximately equal running time.

Based on test assemblies: Tests from an assembly are batched together.

inputs.name: batchingBasedOnAgentsOption
inputs.label: Batch options
inputs.helpMarkDown: Simple batching based on the number of tests and agents participating in the test run. When the batch size is automatically determined, each batch contains `(total number of tests / number of agents)` tests. If a batch size is specified, each batch will contain the specified number of tests.

inputs.name: customBatchSizeValue
inputs.label: Number of tests per batch
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify batch size

inputs.name: batchingBasedOnExecutionTimeOption
inputs.label: Batch options
inputs.helpMarkDown: This batching considers past running time to create batches of tests such that each batch has approximately equal running time. Quick running tests will be batched together, while longer running tests may belong to a separate batch. When this option is used with the multi-agent job setting, total test time is reduced to a minimum.

inputs.name: customRunTimePerBatchValue
inputs.label: Running time (sec) per batch
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the running time (sec) per batch

inputs.name: dontDistribute
inputs.label: Replicate tests instead of distributing when multiple agents are used in the job
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Choosing this option will not distribute tests across agents when the task is running in a multi-agent job.
Each of the selected test(s) will be repeated on each agent.
The option is not applicable when the agent job is configured to run with no parallelism or with the multi-config option.

inputs.name: testRunTitle
inputs.label: Test run title
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a name for the test run.

inputs.name: platform
inputs.label: Build platform
inputs.helpMarkDown: Build platform against which the tests should be reported. If you have defined a variable for platform in your build task, use that here.

inputs.name: configuration
inputs.label: Build configuration
inputs.helpMarkDown: Build configuration against which the tests should be reported. If you have defined a variable for configuration in your build task, use that here.

inputs.name: customLoggerConfig
inputs.label: Custom Logger Configuration
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use this option if you have a custom logger. To use, provide the logger name along with its parameters in the following format: 'friendlyName;key1=value1;key2=value2;....'

inputs.name: publishRunAttachments
inputs.label: Upload test attachments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Opt in/out of publishing run level attachments.

inputs.name: donotPublishTestResults
inputs.label: Disable publishing test results
inputs.helpMarkDown: If this option is turned on, test results won't be published as part of this task. Use Publish Test Results task instead

inputs.name: failOnMinTestsNotRun
inputs.label: Fail the task if a minimum number of tests are not run.
inputs.helpMarkDown: Selecting this option will fail the task if specified minimum number of tests is not run.

inputs.name: minimumExpectedTests

inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the minimum # of tests that should be run for the task to succeed. Total tests executed is calculated as the sum of passed, failed and aborted tests.

inputs.name: diagnosticsEnabled
inputs.label: Collect advanced diagnostics in case of catastrophic failures
inputs.helpMarkDown: Collect advanced diagnostics in case of catastrophic failures.

inputs.name: collectDumpOn
inputs.label: Collect process dump and attach to test run report
inputs.helpMarkDown: Collect process dump and attach to test run report.

inputs.name: rerunFailedTests
inputs.label: Rerun failed tests
inputs.helpMarkDown: Selecting this option will rerun any failed tests until they pass or the maximum # of attempts is reached.

inputs.name: rerunType
inputs.label: Do not rerun if test failures exceed specified threshold
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Use this option to avoid rerunning tests when failure rate crosses the specified threshold. This is applicable if any environment issues leads to massive failures.
You can specify % failures or # of failed tests as a threshold.

inputs.name: rerunFailedThreshold
inputs.label: % failure
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use this option to avoid rerunning tests when failure rate crosses the specified threshold. This is applicable if any environment issues leads to massive failures.

inputs.name: rerunFailedTestCasesMaxLimit
inputs.label: # of failed tests
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use this option to avoid rerunning tests when number of failed test cases crosses specified limit. This is applicable if any environment issues leads to massive failures.

inputs.name: rerunMaxAttempts

inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the maximum # of times a failed test should be retried. If a test passes before the maximum # of attempts is reached, it will not be rerun further.

tasks.name: ManualValidation
tasks.description: Pause a pipeline run to wait for manual interaction. Works only with YAML pipelines.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: notifyUsers
inputs.label: Notify users
inputs.helpMarkDown: Send a manual validation pending email to specific users (or groups). Only users with queue build permission can act on a manual validation.

inputs.name: instructions
inputs.label: Instructions
inputs.helpMarkDown: These instructions will be shown to the user for resuming or rejecting the manual validation. Based on these instructions the user will take an informed decision about this manual validation.

inputs.name: onTimeout

inputs.helpMarkDown: Reject or resume this manual validation automatically after it is pending for the specified timeout or 30 days, whichever is earlier.

inputs.name: allowApproversToApproveTheirOwnRuns

tasks.name: Ant
tasks.description: Build with Apache Ant
tasks.helpMarkDown: [Learn more about this task](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=613718) or [see the Ant documentation](http://ant.apache.org/)
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: antBuildFile
inputs.label: Ant build file
inputs.helpMarkDown: Relative path from the repository root to the Ant build file.

inputs.name: options
inputs.label: Options
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide any options to pass to the Ant command line. You can provide your own properties (for example, ***-DmyProperty=myPropertyValue***) and also use built-in variables (for example, ***-DcollectionId=$(system.collectionId)***). Alternatively, the built-in variables are already set as environment variables during the build and can be passed directly (for example, ***-DcollectionIdAsEnvVar=%SYSTEM_COLLECTIONID%***).

inputs.name: targets
inputs.label: Target(s)
inputs.helpMarkDown: An optional, space-separated list of targets to build. If not specified, the `default` target will be used. If no `default` target is defined, Ant 1.6.0 and later will build all top-level tasks.

inputs.name: publishJUnitResults
inputs.label: Publish to Azure Pipelines
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select this option to publish JUnit test results produced by the Ant build to Azure Pipelines. Each test results file matching `Test Results Files` will be published as a test run in Azure Pipelines.

inputs.name: testResultsFiles
inputs.label: Test results files
inputs.helpMarkDown: Test results files path. Wildcards can be used ([more information](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=856077)). For example, `**/TEST-*.xml` for all XML files whose name starts with TEST-.

inputs.name: testRunTitle
inputs.label: Test run title
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a name for the test run.

inputs.name: codeCoverageTool
inputs.label: Code coverage tool
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the code coverage tool. For on-premises agent support, refer to the `More Information` link below.

inputs.name: classFilesDirectories
inputs.label: Class files directories
inputs.helpMarkDown: Comma-separated list of relative paths from the Ant build file to directories containing class files and archive files (JAR, WAR, etc.). Code coverage is reported for class files in these directories. For example: target/classes,target/testClasses.

inputs.name: classFilter
inputs.label: Class inclusion/exclusion filters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Comma-separated list of filters to include or exclude classes from collecting code coverage. For example: +:com.*,+:org.*,-:my.app*.*.

inputs.name: srcDirectories
inputs.label: Source files directories
inputs.helpMarkDown: Comma-separated list of relative paths from the Ant build file to source code directories. Code coverage reports will use these to highlight source code. For example: src/java,src/Test.

inputs.name: failIfCoverageEmpty
inputs.label: Fail when code coverage results are missing
inputs.helpMarkDown: Fail the build if code coverage did not produce any results to publish.

inputs.name: antHomeUserInputPath
inputs.label: Set ANT_HOME path
inputs.helpMarkDown: If set, overrides any existing ANT_HOME environment variable with the given path.

inputs.name: javaHomeSelection
inputs.label: Set JAVA_HOME by
inputs.helpMarkDown: Sets JAVA_HOME either by selecting a JDK version that will be discovered during builds or by manually entering a JDK path.

inputs.name: jdkVersion
inputs.label: JDK version
inputs.helpMarkDown: Will attempt to discover the path to the selected JDK version and set JAVA_HOME accordingly.

inputs.name: jdkUserInputPath
inputs.label: JDK path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Sets JAVA_HOME to the given path.

inputs.name: jdkArchitecture
inputs.label: JDK architecture
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optionally supply the architecture (x86, x64) of the JDK.

tasks.name: DeployVisualStudioTestAgent
tasks.description: Deprecated: Instead, use the 'Visual Studio Test' task to run unit and functional tests
tasks.releaseNotes:
• Support for Visual Studio Test Agent 2017: You can now deploy and run tests using multiple versions of Visual Studio Test Agent. Versions 2015 and 2017 are supported.
  • Machine groups created from the Test hub are no longer supported. You can continue to use a list of machines or Azure resource groups.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: testMachines
inputs.label: Machines
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a comma separated list of machine IP addresses or FQDNs along with ports. Port is defaulted based on the selected protocol. Eg: `dbserver.fabrikam.com,dbserver_int.fabrikam.com:5986,192.168.12.34:5986` Or provide output variable of other tasks. Eg: `$(variableName)`. If you are using HTTPS, name/IP of machine should match the CN in the certificate.

inputs.name: adminUserName
inputs.label: Admin login
inputs.helpMarkDown: Administrator login for the target machines.

inputs.name: adminPassword
inputs.label: Admin password
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Administrator password for the target machines.
It can accept variable defined in build or release pipelines as `$(passwordVariable)`.
You may mark a variable as 'secret' to secure it.

inputs.name: winRmProtocol
inputs.label: Protocol
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the protocol to use for the WinRM service connection with the machine(s). Default is `HTTP`.

inputs.name: testCertificate
inputs.label: Test Certificate
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to skip validating the authenticity of the machine's certificate by a trusted certification authority. The parameter is required for the WinRM HTTPS protocol.

inputs.name: machineUserName
inputs.label: Username
inputs.helpMarkDown: Username with which test agent needs to run.

inputs.name: machinePassword
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown: Password for the username given above.

inputs.name: runAsProcess
inputs.label: Run UI tests
inputs.helpMarkDown: Denotes if test agent needs to run as an interactive process, needed for Coded UI Tests.

inputs.name: isDataCollectionOnly
inputs.label: Enable data collection only
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optionally specify if test agent needs to be used only for data collection and not for running tests. Typically done on application under test(AUT) machine group.

inputs.name: testPlatform
inputs.label: Test agent version
inputs.helpMarkDown: The version of Visual Studio test agent to use. Pick an appropriate version to match the VS version using which test binaries were built.

inputs.name: agentLocation
inputs.label: Test agent location
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optionally supply the path to vstf_testagent.exe from network or local location. If no path is provided, it will be automatically downloaded from the Download Center. Installer for Test Agent 2015 Update 3 from `https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=827840`. Installer for Test Agent 2017 from `https://aka.ms/vs/15/release/vs_TestAgent.exe`. Refer to `https://aka.ms/testagentlocation` for details on how to use offline installers.

inputs.name: updateTestAgent
inputs.label: Update test agent
inputs.helpMarkDown: If Test Agent is already deployed on a machine, this option checks to see if an update is available for that version of the Test Agent.

For Azure Resource Group provide the VM Host Name for the machine name. The default is to deploy agent on all machines represented in the Machines field.

tasks.name: BatchScript
tasks.description: Run a Windows command or batch script and optionally allow it to change the environment
tasks.helpMarkDown:
[Learn more about this task](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=613733).

Please note: this task is not compatible with Windows containers. If you need to run a batch script on a Windows container, use the [CmdLine task](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=613735) instead.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: filename
inputs.label: Path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path of the cmd or bat script to execute. Should be fully qualified path or relative to the default working directory (please note that working directory could differ from 'workingFolder' which could be specified for this task).

inputs.name: arguments
inputs.label: Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Arguments passed to the cmd or bat script

inputs.name: modifyEnvironment
inputs.label: Modify Environment
inputs.helpMarkDown: Determines whether environment variable modifications will affect subsequent tasks.

inputs.name: workingFolder
inputs.label: Working folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Current working directory when script is run.  Defaults to the folder where the script is located.

tasks.name: DotNetCoreInstaller
tasks.description: Acquire a specific version of the .NET Core SDK from the internet or local cache and add it to the PATH
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: packageType
inputs.label: Package to install
inputs.helpMarkDown: Please select whether to install only runtime or full SDK.

inputs.name: version
inputs.label: Version
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specify exact version of .NET Core SDK or runtime to install.
Find the value of `version-sdk` for installing SDK, or `version-runtime` for installing Runtime from any releases [here](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/DotNetCoreInstallerV0/externals/releases.json). **NOTE: the task will not work with new versions of .NET Core. Kindly upgrade to 2.\* version of the task to download latest versions od .NET Core.**

tasks.name: DotNetCoreInstaller
tasks.description: Acquire a specific version of the .NET Core SDK from the internet or local cache and add it to the PATH
tasks.releaseNotes:
• Support for installing multiple versions side by side.
  • Support for patterns in version to fetch latest in minor/major version.
  • Restrict Multi-level lookup
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: packageType
inputs.label: Package to install
inputs.helpMarkDown: Please select whether to install only runtime or SDK.

inputs.name: version
inputs.label: Version
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specify version of .NET Core SDK or runtime to install.
Versions can be given in the following formats
  • 2.x => Install latest in major version.
  • 2.2.x => Install latest in major and minor version
  • 2.2.104 => Install exact version

    • Find the value of `version` for installing SDK/Runtime, from the releases.json. The link to releases.json of that major.minor version can be found in [**releases-index file.**](https://builds.dotnet.microsoft.com/dotnet/release-metadata/releases-index.json). Like link to releases.json for 2.2 version is https://builds.dotnet.microsoft.com/dotnet/release-metadata/2.2/releases.json

inputs.name: includePreviewVersions
inputs.label: Include Preview Versions
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select if you want preview versions to be included while searching for latest versions, such as while searching 2.2.x. This setting is ignored if you specify an exact version, such as: 3.0.100-preview3-010431

inputs.name: installationPath
inputs.label: Path To Install .Net Core
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specify where .Net Core SDK/Runtime should be installed. Different paths can have the following impact on .Net's behavior.
  • $(Agent.ToolsDirectory): This makes the version to be cached on the agent since this directory is not cleanup up across pipelines. All pipelines running on the agent, would have access to the versions installed previously using the agent.
  • $(Agent.TempDirectory): This can ensure that a pipeline doesn't use any cached version of .Net core since this folder is cleaned up after each pipeline.
  • Any other path: You can configure any other path given the agent process has access to the path. This will change the state of the machine and impact all processes running on it.
    Note that you can also configure Multi-Level Lookup setting which can configure .Net host's probing for a suitable version.

inputs.name: performMultiLevelLookup
inputs.label: Perform Multi Level Lookup
inputs.helpMarkDown:
This input is only applicable to Windows based agents. This configures the behavior of .Net host process for looking up a suitable shared framework.
  • unchecked: Only versions present in the folder specified in this task would be looked by the host process.
  • checked: The host will attempt to look in pre-defined global locations using multi-level lookup.
    The default global locations are:
    For Windows:
    C:\Program Files\dotnet (64-bit processes)
    C:\Program Files (x86)\dotnet (32-bit process)
    • You can read more about it [**HERE**](https://github.com/dotnet/core-setup/blob/master/Documentation/design-docs/multilevel-sharedfx-lookup.md).

tasks.name: UseDotNet
tasks.description: Acquires a specific version of the .NET Core SDK from the internet or the local cache and adds it to the PATH. Use this task to change the version of .NET Core used in subsequent tasks. Additionally provides proxy support.
tasks.releaseNotes:
• Support for installing multiple versions side by side.
  • Support for patterns in version to fetch latest in minor/major version.
  • Restrict Multi-level lookup
  • Installs NuGet and provides proxy support.
  • Installs sdk versions from `global.json` file(s)
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: packageType
inputs.label: Package to install
inputs.helpMarkDown: Please select whether to install only runtime or SDK.

inputs.name: useGlobalJson
inputs.label: Use global json
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select this option to install all SDKs from global.json files. These files are searched from system.DefaultWorkingDirectory. You can change the search root path by setting working directory input.

inputs.name: workingDirectory
inputs.label: Working Directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify path from where global.json files should be searched when using `Use global json`. If empty, `system.DefaultWorkingDirectory` will be considered as the root path.

inputs.name: version
inputs.label: Version
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specify version of .NET Core SDK or runtime to install.
Versions can be given in the following formats
  • 2.x => Install latest in major version.
  • 2.2.x => Install latest in major and minor version
  • 2.2.104 => Install exact version

    • Find the value of `version` for installing SDK/Runtime, from the releases.json. The link to releases.json of that major.minor version can be found in [**releases-index file.**](https://builds.dotnet.microsoft.com/dotnet/release-metadata/releases-index.json). Like link to releases.json for 2.2 version is https://builds.dotnet.microsoft.com/dotnet/release-metadata/2.2/releases.json

The link to releases.json of that major.minor version can be found in [**releases-index file.**](https://builds.dotnet.microsoft.com/dotnet/release-metadata/releases-index.json)

inputs.name: includePreviewVersions
inputs.label: Include Preview Versions
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select if you want preview versions to be included while searching for latest versions, such as while searching 2.2.x. This setting is ignored if you specify an exact version, such as: 3.0.100-preview3-010431

inputs.name: installationPath
inputs.label: Path To Install .Net Core
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specify where .Net Core SDK/Runtime should be installed. Different paths can have the following impact on .Net's behavior.
  • $(Agent.ToolsDirectory): This makes the version to be cached on the agent since this directory is not cleanup up across pipelines. All pipelines running on the agent, would have access to the versions installed previously using the agent.
  • $(Agent.TempDirectory): This can ensure that a pipeline doesn't use any cached version of .Net core since this folder is cleaned up after each pipeline.
  • Any other path: You can configure any other path given the agent process has access to the path. This will change the state of the machine and impact all processes running on it.
    Note that you can also configure Multi-Level Lookup setting which can configure .Net host's probing for a suitable version.

inputs.name: performMultiLevelLookup
inputs.label: Perform Multi Level Lookup
inputs.helpMarkDown:
This input is only applicable to Windows based agents. This configures the behavior of .Net host process for looking up a suitable shared framework.
  • unchecked: Only versions present in the folder specified in this task would be looked by the host process.
  • checked: The host will attempt to look in pre-defined global locations using multi-level lookup.
    The default global locations are:
    For Windows:
    C:\Program Files\dotnet (64-bit processes)
    C:\Program Files (x86)\dotnet (32-bit process)
    • You can read more about it [**HERE**](https://github.com/dotnet/core-setup/blob/master/Documentation/design-docs/multilevel-sharedfx-lookup.md).

inputs.name: requestTimeout
inputs.label: Set timeout for package download request
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a timeout value for HTTP requests that the task makes to obtain the .NET package. The value is in milliseconds. Default is 300000 milliseconds (5 minutes). Cannot be more than 600000 milliseconds (10 minutes).

tasks.name: AzureAppConfigurationImport
tasks.description: Import settings from configuration files into Azure App Configuration through build or deployment pipelines
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: ConnectedServiceName
inputs.label: Azure subscription
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the Azure Subscription for the Azure App Configuration instance.

inputs.label: App Configuration Endpoint
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the endpoint of an existing [Azure App Configuration](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-app-configuration/concept-key-value).

validation.message: Provide a valid app configuration endpoint.

inputs.name: ConfigurationFile
inputs.label: Configuration File Path
inputs.helpMarkDown: the path to the configuration file (supported: yaml, json, properties)

inputs.name: UseFilePathExtension
inputs.label: Use the file path extension to determine the file format
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies whether or not to use the file path extension to determine the file format

inputs.name: FileFormat
inputs.label: File Format
inputs.helpMarkDown: The configuration file format. If no format is provided, then the format defaults to the file extension of the configuration file provided.

validation.message: Supported file formats are: Yaml, Json, and Properties

inputs.name: FileContentProfile
inputs.label: File Content Profile
inputs.helpMarkDown: The configuration file's [content profile](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/azure-app-configuration/concept-config-file)

inputs.name: Separator
inputs.label: Separator
inputs.helpMarkDown: Separator used to flatten the configuration file (json & yaml files). It is required when the depth provided is greater than 1

inputs.name: Depth
inputs.label: Depth
inputs.helpMarkDown: max depth to flatten to in configuration file (json and yaml files)

inputs.name: Prefix
inputs.label: Prefix
inputs.helpMarkDown: a prefix to append to all keys in the configuration file

inputs.name: Label
inputs.label: Label
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies which label should be used when selecting key-values from App Configuration. If no label is provided then key-values with the _null_ label will be retrieved. The following characters are not allowed: `,` `*`.

inputs.name: ContentType
inputs.label: Content Type
inputs.helpMarkDown: a content type to append to all keys in the configuration file

inputs.name: Tags
inputs.label: Tags
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies one or more tag that should be added to key-value settings being imported to App Configuration. Tags should be of a valid JSON format and can span multiple lines. Example: {"tag1": "value1", "tag2": "value2"}

inputs.name: ExcludeFeatureFlags
inputs.label: Exclude feature flags
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies whether or not any feature flags provided in the configuration file will be imported to App Configuration.

inputs.name: Strict
inputs.label: Delete key-values that are not included in the configuration file
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The behavior of this option depends on the configuration file's content profile.
 'Default': Any key-values in the store with the specified prefix and label that are not included in the configuration file will be deleted. 
'KVSet': Any key-values in the store that are not included in the configuration file will be deleted.

inputs.name: DryRun
inputs.label: Dry run
inputs.helpMarkDown: When dry run is enabled, this task will not perform any updates to App Configuration. Instead, any updates that would have been performed in a normal run will be printed to the console for review

inputs.name: ImportMode
inputs.label: Import Mode
inputs.helpMarkDown: Determines the behavior when importing key-values. The default value, 'All' will import all key-values in the input file to App Configuration. 'Ignore-Match' will only import settings that have no matching key-value in App Configuration.

tasks.name: FileTransform
tasks.description: Replace tokens with variable values in XML or JSON configuration files
tasks.helpMarkDown:
File transformation and variable substitution task: Update tokens in your XML based configuration files and then replaces those tokens with variable values.
Currently only XML, JSON file formats are supported for variable substitution.
[Learn more about this task](https://aka.ms/AA5xp1v)
tasks.releaseNotes: More optimized task fields that allow users to enable any/all of the transformation (XML), variable substitution (JSON and XML) features in a single task instance.</br>Task fails when any of the configured transformation/substitution is NOT applied or when the task is no-op.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: folderPath
inputs.label: Package or folder
inputs.helpMarkDown:
File path to the package or a folder.
Variables ( [Build](https://docs.microsoft.com/vsts/pipelines/build/variables) | [Release](https://docs.microsoft.com/vsts/pipelines/release/variables#default-variables)), wildcards are supported.
For example, $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/\*\*/\*.zip.

inputs.name: enableXmlTransform
inputs.label: XML transformation
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Config transforms will be run prior to the Variable Substitution.
XML transformations are supported only for Windows platform.

inputs.name: xmlTransformationRules
inputs.label: XML Transformation rules
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide new line separated list of transformation file rules using the syntax:
-transform -xml

inputs.name: jsonTargetFiles
inputs.label: JSON target files
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide new line separated list of files to substitute the variable values. Files names are to be provided relative to the root folder.

For example, to replace the value of ‘ConnectionString’ in the sample below, you need to define a variable as ‘Data.DefaultConnection.ConnectionString’ in the build or release pipeline (or release pipeline's environment).
{
  "Data": {
    "DefaultConnection": {
      "ConnectionString": "Server=(localdb)\SQLEXPRESS;Database=MyDB;Trusted_Connection=True"
    }
  }
}
Variable Substitution is run after configuration transforms.

Note: Only custom variables defined in build/release pipelines are used in substitution. Default/system defined pipeline variables are excluded.
Note: If same variables are defined in the release pipeline and in the stage, then the stage variables will supersede the release pipeline variables.

inputs.name: xmlTargetFiles
inputs.label: XML target files
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide new line separated list of files to substitute the variable values. Files names are to be provided relative to the root folder.
For XML, Variables defined in the build or release pipelines will be matched against the 'key' or 'name' entries in the appSettings, applicationSettings, and connectionStrings sections of any config file and parameters.xml.
Variable Substitution is run after configuration transforms.
Note: Only custom variables defined in build/release pipelines are used in substitution. Default/system defined pipeline variables are excluded.
Note: If same variables are defined in the release pipeline and in the stage, then the stage variables will supersede the release pipeline variables.
Note: We are replacing double quotes with single quotes in the XML to avoid escaping issues that can occur in XML.

inputs.name: errorOnInvalidSubstitution
inputs.label: Error on empty files and invalid substitution.
inputs.helpMarkDown: If selected, the pipeline fails if the target files are empty or if the substitution fails.

tasks.name: FileTransform
tasks.description: Replace tokens with variable values in XML or JSON configuration files
tasks.helpMarkDown:
File transformation and variable substitution task: Update tokens in your XML based configuration files and then replaces those tokens with variable values.
Currently only XML, JSON file formats are supported for variable substitution.
[Learn more about this task](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/utility/file-transform)
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: folderPath
inputs.label: Package or folder
inputs.helpMarkDown:
File path to the package or a folder.
Variables ( [Build](https://docs.microsoft.com/vsts/pipelines/build/variables) | [Release](https://docs.microsoft.com/vsts/pipelines/release/variables#default-variables)), wildcards are supported.
For example, $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/\*\*/\*.zip.

inputs.name: enableXmlTransform
inputs.label: XML transformation
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Config transforms will be run prior to the Variable Substitution.
XML transformations are supported only for Windows platform.

inputs.name: xmlTransformationRules
inputs.label: Transformation rules
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide new line separated list of transformation file rules using the syntax:
-transform -xml

inputs.name: fileType
inputs.label: File format
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide file format on which substitution has to be performed
For XML, Variables defined in the build or release pipelines will be matched against the 'key' or 'name' entries in the appSettings, applicationSettings, and connectionStrings sections of any config file and parameters.xml. Variable Substitution is run after config transforms.
To substitute JSON variables that are nested or hierarchical, specify them using JSONPath expressions.

For example, to replace the value of ‘ConnectionString’ in the sample below, you need to define a variable as ‘Data.DefaultConnection.ConnectionString’ in the build or release pipeline (or release pipeline's environment).
{
  "Data": {
    "DefaultConnection": {
      "ConnectionString": "Server=(localdb)\SQLEXPRESS;Database=MyDB;Trusted_Connection=True"
    }
  }
}
Variable Substitution is run after configuration transforms.

Note: only custom variables defined in build/release pipelines are used in substitution. Default/system defined pipeline variables are excluded.
Note: If same variables are defined in the release pipeline and in the stage, then the stage variables will supersede the release pipeline variables.

inputs.name: targetFiles
inputs.label: Target files
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide new line separated list of files to substitute the variable values. Files names are to be provided relative to the root folder.

inputs.name: csmFile

inputs.label: Template Parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the path for the parameters file for the Azure Resource Manager Template.

inputs.name: overrideParameters
inputs.label: Override Template Parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specify the template parameters to override like,
-storageName fabrikam -adminUsername $(vmusername) -adminPassword (ConvertTo-SecureString -String '$(password)' -AsPlainText -Force) -azureKeyVaultName $(fabrikamFibre).
inputs.visibleRule: action = Create Or Update Resource Group

inputs.name: deploymentMode
inputs.label: Deployment Mode
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Incremental mode handles deployments as incremental updates to the resource group . It leaves unchanged resources that exist in the resource group but are not specified in the template. 

 Complete mode deletes resources that are not in your template. 

 Validate mode enables you to find problems with the template before creating actual resources. 

 By default, Incremental mode is used.
inputs.visibleRule: action = Create Or Update Resource Group

inputs.name: enableDeploymentPrerequisitesForCreate
inputs.label: Enable Deployment Prerequisites
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enabling this option configures Windows Remote Management (WinRM) listener over HTTPS protocol on port 5986, using a self-signed certificate. This configuration is required for performing deployment operation on Azure machines. If the target Virtual Machines are backed by a Load balancer, ensure Inbound NAT rules are configured for target port (5986).
inputs.visibleRule: action = Create Or Update Resource Group

inputs.name: enableDeploymentPrerequisitesForSelect
inputs.label: Enable Deployment Prerequisites
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enabling this option configures Windows Remote Management (WinRM) listener over HTTPS protocol on port 5986, using a self-signed certificate. This configuration is required for performing deployment operation on Azure machines. If the target Virtual Machines are backed by a Load balancer, ensure Inbound NAT rules are configured for target port (5986).

inputs.name: outputVariable
inputs.label: Resource Group
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide a name for the variable for the resource group. The variable can be used as $(variableName) to refer to the resource group in subsequent tasks like in the PowerShell on Target Machines task for deploying applications.
Valid only when the selected action is Create, Update or Select, and required when an existing resource group is selected.

tasks.name: AzureResourceGroupDeployment
tasks.description: Deploy an Azure Resource Manager (ARM) template to a resource group and manage virtual machines
tasks.releaseNotes:
-Works with cross-platform agents (Linux, macOS, or Windows)
- Supports Template JSONs located at any publicly accessible http/https URLs.
- Enhanced UX for Override parameters which can now be viewed/edited in a grid.
- NAT rule mapping for VMs which are backed by an Load balancer.
- "Resource group" field is now renamed as "VM details for  WinRM" and is included in the section "Advanced deployment options for virtual machines".
- Limitations: 
 - No support for Classic subscriptions. Only for ARM subscriptions are supported.
 - No support for PowerShell syntax as the task is now node.js based. Ensure the case sensitivity of the parameter names match, when you override the template parameters. Also, remove the PowerShell cmdlets like "ConvertTo-SecureString" when you migrate from version 1.0 to version 2.0.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

groups.name: Template
groups.visibleRule: action = Create Or Update Resource Group

groups.displayName: Advanced deployment options for virtual machines
groups.visibleRule: action = Create Or Update Resource Group || action = Select Resource Group

inputs.name: ConnectedServiceName
inputs.label: Azure subscription
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the Azure Resource Manager subscription for the deployment.

inputs.label: Action
inputs.helpMarkDown: Action to be performed on the Azure resources or resource group.

inputs.label: Resource group

inputs.name: csmFileLink
inputs.label: Template link
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specify the URL of the template file. Example: [https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Azure/...](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Azure/azure-quickstart-templates/master/101-vm-simple-windows/azuredeploy.json) 

To deploy a template stored in a private storage account, retrieve and include the shared access signature (SAS) token in the URL of the template. Example: `<blob_storage_url>/template.json?<SAStoken>` To upload a template file (or a linked template) to a storage account and generate a SAS token, you could use [Azure file copy](https://aka.ms/azurefilecopyreadme) task or follow the steps using [PowerShell](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=838080) or [Azure CLI](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=836911).

To  view the template parameters in a grid, click on “…” next to Override template parameters text box. This feature requires that CORS rules are enabled at the source. If templates are in Azure storage blob, refer to [this](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/storageservices/fileservices/Cross-Origin-Resource-Sharing--CORS--Support-for-the-Azure-Storage-Services?redirectedfrom=MSDN#understanding-cors-requests) to enable CORS.

inputs.name: csmParametersFileLink
inputs.label: Template parameters link
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specify the URL of the parameters file. Example: [https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Azure/...](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/Azure/azure-quickstart-templates/master/101-vm-simple-windows/azuredeploy.parameters.json) 

To use a file stored in a private storage account, retrieve and include the shared access signature (SAS) token in the URL of the template. Example: `<blob_storage_url>/template.json?<SAStoken>` To upload a parameters file to a storage account and generate a SAS token, you could use [Azure file copy](https://aka.ms/azurefilecopyreadme) task or follow the steps using [PowerShell](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=838080) or [Azure CLI](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=836911). 

To  view the template parameters in a grid, click on “…” next to Override template parameters text box. This feature requires that CORS rules are enabled at the source. If templates are in Azure storage blob, refer to [this](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/storageservices/fileservices/Cross-Origin-Resource-Sharing--CORS--Support-for-the-Azure-Storage-Services?redirectedfrom=MSDN#understanding-cors-requests) to enable CORS.

inputs.name: csmFile
inputs.label: Template
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the path or a pattern pointing to the Azure Resource Manager template. For more information about the templates see https://aka.ms/azuretemplates. To get started immediately use template https://aka.ms/sampletemplate.

inputs.name: csmParametersFile
inputs.label: Template parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the path or a pattern pointing for the parameters file for the Azure Resource Manager template.

inputs.name: overrideParameters
inputs.label: Override template parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown:
To view the template parameters in a grid, click on “…” next to Override Parameters textbox. This feature requires that CORS rules are enabled at the source. If templates are in Azure storage blob, refer to [this](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/rest/api/storageservices/fileservices/Cross-Origin-Resource-Sharing--CORS--Support-for-the-Azure-Storage-Services?redirectedfrom=MSDN#understanding-cors-requests) to enable CORS. Or type the template parameters to override in the textbox. Example,
–storageName fabrikam –adminUsername $(vmusername) -adminPassword $(password) –azureKeyVaultName $(fabrikamFibre).
If the parameter value you're using has multiple words, enclose them in quotes, even if you're passing them using variables. For example, -name "parameter value" -name2 "$(var)"
To override object type parameters use stringified JSON objects. For example, -options ["option1"] -map {"key1": "value1" }.

inputs.name: deploymentMode
inputs.label: Deployment mode
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Refer to [this](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/deployment-modes) for more details. 

 Incremental mode handles deployments as incremental updates to the resource group. It leaves unchanged resources that exist in the resource group but are not specified in the template. 

 Complete mode deletes resources that are not in your template. Complete mode takes relatively more time than incremental mode. If the task times out, consider increasing the timeout, or changing the mode to 'Incremental'. 
 **[Warning] Complete mode will delete all the existing resources in the resource group that are not specified in the template. Do review if the resource group you're deploying to doesn't contain any necessary resources that are not specified in the template.** 

 Validate mode enables you to find problems with the template before creating actual resources. Validate mode enables you to find problems with the template before creating actual resources. Please note that this mode will anyways create a resource group even if it does not deploy any resource.

 By default, Incremental mode is used.

inputs.name: enableDeploymentPrerequisites
inputs.label: Enable prerequisites
inputs.helpMarkDown:
These options would be applicable only when the Resource group contains virtual machines.

Choosing Deployment Group option would configure Deployment Group agent on each of the virtual machines.

Selecting WinRM option configures Windows Remote Management (WinRM) listener over HTTPS protocol on port 5986, using a self-signed certificate. This configuration is required for performing deployment operation on Azure machines. If the target Virtual Machines are backed by a Load balancer, ensure Inbound NAT rules are configured for target port (5986).

inputs.name: deploymentGroupEndpoint
inputs.label: Azure Pipelines service connection
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specify the service connection to connect to an Azure DevOps organization or collection for agent registration.

You can create a service connection using "+New", and select "Token-based authentication". You need a [personal access token(PAT)](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/vsts/accounts/use-personal-access-tokens-to-authenticate?view=vsts) to setup a service connection.

​Click "Manage" to update the service connection details.

inputs.name: project
inputs.label: Team project
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the Team Project which has the Deployment Group defined in it​

inputs.name: deploymentGroupName
inputs.label: Deployment Group
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the Deployment Group against which the agent(s) will be registered. For more guidance, refer to [Deployment Groups](https://aka.ms/832442)

inputs.name: copyAzureVMTags
inputs.label: Copy Azure VM tags to agents
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Choose if the tags configured on the Azure VM need to be copied to the corresponding Deployment Group agent.

​By default all Azure tags will be copied following the format “Key: Value”. Example: An Azure Tag “Role : Web” would be copied as-is to the Agent machine.

For more information on how tag Azure resources refer to [link](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/azure-resource-manager/resource-group-using-tags​)

inputs.name: runAgentServiceAsUser
inputs.label: Run agent service as a user
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Decide whether to run the agent service as a user other than the default.
The default user is "NT AUTHORITY\SYSTEM" in Windows and "root" in Linux.

inputs.name: userName
inputs.label: User name
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The username to run the agent service on the virtual machines.
For domain users, please enter values as "domain\username" or "username@domain.com". For local users, please enter just the user name.
It is assumed that the same domain user\a local user with the same name, respectively, is present on all the virtual machines in the resource group.

inputs.name: password
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The password for the user to run the agent service on the Windows VMs.
It is assumed that the password is the same for the specified user on all the VMs.
It can accept variable defined in build or release pipelines as '$(passwordVariable)'. You may mark variable as 'secret' to secure it.
For linux VMs, a password is not required and will be ignored.

inputs.name: outputVariable
inputs.label: VM details for WinRM
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide a name for the variable for the resource group. The variable can be used as $(variableName) to refer to the resource group in subsequent tasks like in the PowerShell on Target Machines task for deploying applications.
Valid only when the selected action is Create, Update or Select, and required when an existing resource group is selected.

inputs.name: deploymentName
inputs.label: Deployment name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies the name of the resource group deployment to create.

inputs.name: deploymentOutputs
inputs.label: Deployment outputs
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a name for the variable for the output variable which will contain the outputs section of the current deployment object in string format. You can use the “ConvertFrom-Json” PowerShell cmdlet to parse the JSON object and access the individual output values. For more details refer to [this](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/AzureResourceGroupDeploymentV2#deployment-outputs)

inputs.name: addSpnToEnvironment
inputs.label: Access service principal details in override parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Adds service principal id and key of the Azure endpoint you chose to the script's execution environment. You can use these variables: `$servicePrincipalId` and `$servicePrincipalKey` in your override parameters like `-key $servicePrincipalKey`

inputs.name: useWithoutJSON
inputs.label: Use individual output values without JSON.Stringify applied
inputs.helpMarkDown: Individual output values are being converted via JSON.Stringify by default. If you want to use the output values as it is without converting them via JSON.Stringify, enable this option. For more details refer to [this](https://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/tree/master/Tasks/AzureResourceGroupDeploymentV2#deployment-outputs)

tasks.name: InvokeRESTAPI
tasks.description: Invoke REST API as a part of your process.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: connectedServiceName
inputs.label: Generic endpoint
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a generic endpoint that should be used to pick the url and construct authorization header for the http request.

inputs.name: method
inputs.label: Method
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the http method with which the API should be invoked with.

inputs.name: headers
inputs.label: Headers
inputs.helpMarkDown: Define header in JSON format. The header shall be attached with request to be sent.

inputs.name: urlSuffix
inputs.label: Url suffix string
inputs.helpMarkDown: Given string append to the url. Example: If endpoint url is https:...TestProj/_apis/Release/releases and url suffix is /2/environments/1, endpoint url becomes https:.../TestProj/_apis/Release/releases/2/environments/1. If url suffix is ?definitionId=1&releaseCount=1 then endpoint url becomes https//...TestProj/_apis/Release/releases?definitionId=1&releaseCount=1.

inputs.name: waitForCompletion
inputs.label: Complete based on
inputs.helpMarkDown: Default value "ApiResponse". Available values :  "ApiResponse", "Callback" call where the REST API calls back to update the timeline record​.

inputs.name: successCriteria
inputs.label: Success criteria
inputs.helpMarkDown: Criteria which defines when to pass the task. No criteria means response content does not influence the result. Example:- For response {"status" : "successful"}, the expression can be eq(root['status'], 'successful'). [More Information](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=842996)​

tasks.name: InvokeRESTAPI

inputs.name: connectedServiceNameSelector
inputs.label: Connection type
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the service connection type to use to invoke the REST API.

inputs.name: connectedServiceName

inputs.name: connectedServiceNameARM

inputs.name: method

inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the HTTP method with which the API should be invoked.

inputs.name: headers
inputs.label: Headers
inputs.helpMarkDown: Define header in JSON format. The header shall be attached with request to be sent.

inputs.name: urlSuffix
inputs.label: URL suffix and parameters
inputs.helpMarkDown: Given string append to the URL. Example: If the service connection URL is https:...TestProj/_apis/Release/releases and the URL suffix is /2/environments/1, the service connection URL becomes https:.../TestProj/_apis/Release/releases/2/environments/1. If the URL suffix is ?definitionId=1&releaseCount=1 then the service connection URL becomes https//...TestProj/_apis/Release/releases?definitionId=1&releaseCount=1.

inputs.name: waitForCompletion
inputs.label: Completion event
inputs.helpMarkDown: Default value "ApiResponse". Available values :  "ApiResponse", "Callback" call where the REST API calls back to update the timeline record​.

inputs.name: successCriteria
inputs.label: Success criteria
inputs.helpMarkDown: Criteria which defines when to pass the task. No criteria means response content does not influence the result. Example:- For response {"status" : "successful"}, the expression can be eq(root['status'], 'successful'). [More information](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=842996)​

tasks.name: ArchiveFiles
tasks.description: Archive files using compression formats such as .7z, .rar, .tar.gz, and .zip.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: rootFolder
inputs.label: Root folder (or file) to archive
inputs.helpMarkDown: The root folder to add to the archive.  Everything under this folder will be added to the resulting archive.

inputs.name: includeRootFolder
inputs.label: Prefix root folder name to archive paths
inputs.helpMarkDown:
If selected, the root folder name will be prefixed to file paths within the archive. Otherwise, all file paths will start one level lower.

For example, suppose the selected root folder is: `/home/user/output/classes/`, and contains: `com/acme/Main.class`.

  • If selected, the resulting archive would contain: `classes/com/acme/Main.class`.
  • Otherwise, the resulting archive would contain: `com/acme/Main.class`.

inputs.name: archiveType
inputs.label: Archive type
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the compression scheme used. To create `foo.jar`, for example, choose `zip` for the compression, and specify `foo.jar` as the archive file to create. For all tar files (including compressed ones), choose `tar`.

inputs.name: tarCompression
inputs.label: Tar compression
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optionally choose a compression scheme, or choose `None` to create an uncompressed tar file.

inputs.name: archiveFile
inputs.label: Archive file to create
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the name of the archive file to create. For example, to create `foo.tgz`, select the `tar` archive type and `gz` for tar compression.

inputs.name: replaceExistingArchive
inputs.label: Replace existing archive
inputs.helpMarkDown: If an existing archive exists, specify whether to overwrite it.  Otherwise, files will be added to it.

tasks.name: CopyFiles

tasks.releaseNotes: Match pattern consistency.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: SourceFolder
inputs.label: Source Folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: The source folder that the copy pattern(s) will be run from.  Empty is the root of the repo.  Use [variables](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=550988) if files are not in the repo. Example: $(agent.builddirectory)

inputs.name: Contents
inputs.label: Contents
inputs.helpMarkDown: File paths to include as part of the copy. Supports multiple lines of match patterns. [More Information](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=708389)

inputs.name: TargetFolder
inputs.label: Target Folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Target folder or UNC path files will copy to. You can use [variables](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=550988). Example: $(build.artifactstagingdirectory)

inputs.name: CleanTargetFolder
inputs.label: Clean Target Folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Delete all existing files in target folder before copy

inputs.name: OverWrite
inputs.label: Overwrite
inputs.helpMarkDown: Replace existing file in target folder

inputs.name: flattenFolders
inputs.label: Flatten Folders
inputs.helpMarkDown: Flatten the folder structure and copy all files into the specified target folder.

inputs.name: preserveTimestamp
inputs.label: Preserve Target Timestamp
inputs.helpMarkDown: Using the original source file, preserve the target file timestamp.

inputs.name: retryCount
inputs.label: Retry count to copy the file
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the retry count to copy the file. It might help to resolve intermittent issues e.g. with UNC target paths on a remote host.

inputs.name: delayBetweenRetries
inputs.label: Delay between two retries.
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the delay between two retries. It might help to be more resilient to intermittent issues e.g. with UNC target paths on a remote host.

inputs.name: ignoreMakeDirErrors
inputs.label: Ignore errors during creation of target folder.
inputs.helpMarkDown: Ignore errors which happen during creation of target folder. This could be useful to avoid issues with parallel execution of task by several agents with one target folder.
