tasks.name: AzureMysqlDeployment
tasks.description: Run your scripts and make changes to your Azure Database for MySQL
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: ConnectedServiceName
inputs.label: Azure Subscription
inputs.helpMarkDown:
This is needed to connect to your Azure account.
To configure new service connection, select the Azure subscription from the list and click 'Authorize'.
If your subscription is not listed or if you want to use an existing Service Principal, you can setup an Azure service connection using 'Add' or 'Manage' button.

inputs.name: ServerName
inputs.label: Host Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Server name of 'Azure Database for MySQL'.Example: fabrikam.mysql.database.azure.com. When you connect using MySQL Workbench, this is the same value that is used for 'Hostname' in 'Parameters'

inputs.name: DatabaseName
inputs.label: Database Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of database, if you already have one, on which the below script is needed to be run, else the script itself can be used to create the database.

inputs.name: SqlUsername
inputs.label: Server Admin Login
inputs.helpMarkDown: Azure Database for MySQL server supports native MySQL authentication. You can connect and authenticate to a server with the server's admin login. Example:  bbo1@fabrikam. When you connect using MySQL Workbench, this is the same value that is used for 'Username' in 'Parameters'.

inputs.name: SqlPassword
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Administrator password for Azure Database for MySQL. In case you don’t recall the password you can change the password from [Azure portal](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/mysql/howto-create-manage-server-portal).
It can be variable defined in the pipeline. Example : $(password).
Also, you may mark the variable type as 'secret' to secure it.

inputs.name: TaskNameSelector
inputs.label: Type
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select one of the options between Script File & Inline Script.

inputs.name: SqlFile
inputs.label: MySQL Script
inputs.helpMarkDown: Full path of the script file on the automation agent or on a UNC path accessible to the automation agent like,  \\\\BudgetIT\DeployBuilds\script.sql. Also, predefined system variables like, $(agent.releaseDirectory) can also be used here. A file containing SQL statements can be used here.​

inputs.name: SqlInline
inputs.label: Inline MySQL Script
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter the MySQL script to execute on the Database selected above.

inputs.name: SqlAdditionalArguments
inputs.label: Additional MySQL Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Additional options supported by MySQL simple SQL shell. These options will be applied when executing the given file on the Azure Database for MySQL.​
Example: You can change to default tab separated output format to HTML or even XML format. Or if you have problems due to insufficient memory for large result sets, use the --quick option.​

inputs.name: IpDetectionMethod
inputs.label: Specify Firewall Rules Using
inputs.helpMarkDown:
For successful execution of the task, we need to enable administrators to access the Azure Database for MySQL Server from the IP Address of the automation agent.
By selecting auto-detect you can automatically add firewall exception for range of possible IP Address of automation agent ​or else you can specify the range explicitly.

inputs.name: StartIpAddress
inputs.label: Start IP Address
inputs.helpMarkDown: The starting IP Address of the automation agent machine pool like 196.21.30.50 .

inputs.name: EndIpAddress
inputs.label: End IP Address
inputs.helpMarkDown: The ending IP Address of the automation agent machine pool like 196.21.30.65 .

inputs.name: DeleteFirewallRule
inputs.label: Delete Rule After Task Ends
inputs.helpMarkDown: If selected, the added exception for IP addresses of the automation agent will be removed for corresponding Azure Database for MySQL.

tasks.name: Npm

inputs.name: cwd

inputs.name: arguments

tasks.name: Npm

groups.name: customRegistries

inputs.name: command

The command and arguments which will be passed to npm for execution.

If your arguments contain double quotes ("), escape them with a slash (\\), and surround the escaped string with double quotes (").

inputs.name: workingDir
inputs.label: Working folder that contains package.json
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to the folder containing the target package.json and .npmrc files. Select the folder, not the file e.g. "/packages/mypackage".

inputs.name: verbose
inputs.label: Verbose logging
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select to print more information to the console on run

inputs.name: customCommand

inputs.helpMarkDown: Custom command to run, e.g. "dist-tag ls mypackage".

inputs.name: customRegistry
inputs.label: Registries to use
inputs.helpMarkDown: You can either commit a .npmrc file to your source code repository and set its path here or select a registry from Azure Artifacts here.

inputs.name: customFeed
inputs.label: Use packages from this Azure Artifacts/TFS registry
inputs.helpMarkDown: Include the selected feed in the generated .npmrc.

inputs.name: customEndpoint
inputs.label: Credentials for registries outside this organization/collection
inputs.helpMarkDown: Credentials to use for external registries located in the project's .npmrc. For registries in this organization/collection, leave this blank; the build’s credentials are used automatically.

inputs.name: publishRegistry
inputs.label: Registry location
inputs.helpMarkDown: Registry the command will target.

inputs.name: publishFeed
inputs.label: Target registry
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a registry hosted in this account. You must have Azure Artifacts installed and licensed to select a registry here.

inputs.name: publishPackageMetadata
inputs.label: Publish pipeline metadata
inputs.helpMarkDown: Associate this build/release pipeline’s metadata (run #, source code information) with the package

inputs.name: publishEndpoint
inputs.label: External Registry
inputs.helpMarkDown: Credentials to use for publishing to an external registry.

tasks.name: NodeTool
tasks.description: Finds or downloads and caches the specified version spec of Node.js and adds it to the PATH
tasks.helpMarkDown: [Learn more about this task](https://docs.microsoft.com/azure/devops/pipelines/tasks/tool/node-js) or [see the Node documentation](https://nodejs.org/docs/latest/api/documentation.html)

inputs.name: versionSpec

inputs.name: versionFilePath
inputs.label: Path to the .nvmrc file
inputs.helpMarkDown: File path to get version.  Example: src/.nvmrc

inputs.name: checkLatest
inputs.label: Check for Latest Version
inputs.helpMarkDown: Always checks online for the latest available version that satisfies the version spec. This is typically false unless you have a specific scenario to always get latest. This will cause it to incur download costs when potentially not necessary, especially with the hosted build pool.

inputs.name: force32bit
inputs.label: Use 32 bit version on x64 agents
inputs.helpMarkDown: Installs the x86 version of Node regardless of the CPU architecture of the agent.

inputs.name: nodejsMirror
inputs.label: Set source for Node.js binaries
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use an alternative installation mirror when sourcing the Node.js binaries.

inputs.name: retryCountOnDownloadFails
inputs.label: Set retry count when nodes downloads failed
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use this option when the task failed to download node binaries from the mirror. The task will retry to download the binaries for the specified times.

inputs.name: delayBetweenRetries
inputs.label: Set delay between retries
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use this option to set the delay between retries in milliseconds. The default value is 1000 milliseconds.

tasks.name: UseNode

inputs.name: version
inputs.label: Version

inputs.name: checkLatest

inputs.helpMarkDown: Always checks online for the latest available version that satisfies the version spec. This is typically false unless you have a specific scenario to always get latest. This will cause it to incur download costs when potentially not necessary, especially with the hosted build pool.

inputs.name: force32bit
inputs.label: Use 32 bit version on x64 agents
inputs.helpMarkDown: Installs the x86 version of Node regardless of the CPU architecture of the agent.

inputs.name: retryCountOnDownloadFails

inputs.name: delayBetweenRetries

tasks.name: SqlServerDacpacDeployment
tasks.description: Deploy a SQL Server database using DACPAC
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: EnvironmentName
inputs.label: Machines
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide a comma separated list of machine IP addresses or FQDNs along with ports. Port is defaulted based on the selected protocol.
Eg: dbserver.fabrikam.com,dbserver_int.fabrikam.com:5986,192.168.12.34:5986
Or provide output variable of other tasks. Eg: $(variableName)

inputs.name: AdminUserName
inputs.label: Admin Login
inputs.helpMarkDown: Administrator login for the target machines.

inputs.name: AdminPassword
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Administrator password for the target machines.
It can accept variable defined in Build/Release definitions as '$(passwordVariable)'.
You may mark variable type as 'secret' to secure it.

inputs.name: Protocol
inputs.label: Protocol
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the protocol to use for the WinRM connection with the machine(s). Default is HTTPS.

inputs.name: TestCertificate
inputs.label: Test Certificate
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to skip validating the authenticity of the machine's certificate by a trusted certification authority. The parameter is required for the WinRM HTTPS protocol.

inputs.name: DacpacFile
inputs.label: DACPAC File
inputs.helpMarkDown: Location of the DACPAC file on the target machines or on a UNC path like, \\\\BudgetIT\Web\Deploy\FabrikamDB.dacpac. The UNC path should be accessible to the machine's administrator account. Environment variables are also supported like $env:windir, $env:systemroot, like, $env:windir\FabrikamFibre\Web.

inputs.name: TargetMethod
inputs.label: Specify SQL Using
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to connect to the target SQL Server Database. The options are to provide SQL Server Database details, or a SQL Server connection string, or a Publish profile XML file.

inputs.name: ServerName
inputs.label: Server Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the SQL Server name like, machinename\FabriakmSQL,1433 or localhost or .\SQL2012R2. Specifying localhost will connect to the Default SQL Server instance on the machine.

inputs.name: DatabaseName
inputs.label: Database Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the name of the SQL Server database.

inputs.name: SqlUsername
inputs.label: SQL Username
inputs.helpMarkDown: If the SQL Server login is specified, it will be used to connect to the SQL Server. The default is Integrated Authentication and uses the machine administrator's credentials.

inputs.name: SqlPassword
inputs.label: SQL Password
inputs.helpMarkDown: If SQL Server login user name is specified, then provide the SQL Server password. The default is Integrated Authentication and uses the machine administrator's credentials.

inputs.name: ConnectionString
inputs.label: Connection String
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the SQL Server connection string like "Server=localhost;Database=Fabrikam;User ID=sqluser;Password=password;".

inputs.name: PublishProfile
inputs.label: Publish Profile
inputs.helpMarkDown: Publish profile provide fine-grained control over SQL Server database creation or upgrades. Specify the path to the Publish profile XML file on the target machine or on a UNC share that is accessible by the machine administrator's credentials.

inputs.name: AdditionalArguments
inputs.label: Additional Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Additional SqlPackage.exe arguments that will be applied when creating or updating the SQL Server database like, /p:IgnoreAnsiNulls=True /p:IgnoreComments=True. These arguments will override the settings in the Publish profile XML file (if provided).

inputs.name: DeployInParallel
inputs.label: Deploy in Parallel
inputs.helpMarkDown: Setting it to true will run the database deployment task in-parallel on the target machines.

inputs.name: ResourceFilteringMethod
inputs.label: Select Machines By
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optionally, select a subset of machines either by providing machine names or tags.

inputs.name: MachineFilter
inputs.label: Deploy to Machines
inputs.helpMarkDown: This input is valid only for machine groups and is not supported for flat list of machines or output variables yet. Provide a list of machines like, dbserver.fabrikam.com, webserver.fabrikam.com, 192.168.12.34, or tags like, Role:DB; OS:Win8.1. If multiple tags are provided, then the task will run in all the machines with the specified tags. For Azure Resource Groups, provide the virtual machine's name like, ffweb, ffdb. The default is to run the task in all machines.

tasks.name: VisualStudioTestPlatformInstaller
tasks.description: Acquire the test platform from nuget.org or the tool cache. Satisfies the ‘vstest’ demand and can be used for running tests and collecting diagnostic data using the Visual Studio Test task.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: packageFeedSelector
inputs.label: Package Feed
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the feed from which the Visual Studio Test Platform nuget packge should be fetched.

inputs.name: versionSelector
inputs.label: Version
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Pick whether to install the latest version or a specific version of the Visual Studio Test Platform.
If you use the test platform installer to run Coded UI tests, ensure that the version you choose matches the major version of Visual Studio with which the test binaries were built. For e.g., if the Coded UI test project was built using Visual Studio 2017 (version 15.x), you must use test platform version 15.x.

inputs.name: testPlatformVersion
inputs.label: Test Platform Version
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the version of Visual Studio Test Platform to install on the agent. Available versions can be viewed on nuget.

inputs.name: customFeed
inputs.label: Package Source
inputs.helpMarkDown: Fetch the testplatform package from the specified package feed. Can be a public or a private feed.

inputs.name: username
inputs.label: User Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: User name for authenticating against the specified feed. If providing a PAT token as password, username is optional.

inputs.name: password

tasks.name: DownloadBuildArtifacts
tasks.description: Download files that were saved as artifacts of a completed build
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: buildType
inputs.label: Download artifacts produced by
inputs.helpMarkDown: Download artifacts produced by the current build, or from a specific build.

inputs.name: project
inputs.label: Project
inputs.helpMarkDown: The project from which to download the build artifacts

inputs.name: definition
inputs.label: Build pipeline
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the build pipeline name

inputs.name: specificBuildWithTriggering
inputs.label: When appropriate, download artifacts from the triggering build.
inputs.helpMarkDown: If checked, this build task will try to download artifacts from the triggering build. If there is no triggering build from the specified pipeline, it will download artifacts from the build specified in the options below.

options.latestFromBranch: Latest from specific branch and specified Build Tags

inputs.name: allowPartiallySucceededBuilds
inputs.label: Download artifacts even from partially succeeded builds.
inputs.helpMarkDown: If checked, this build task will try to download artifacts whether the build is succeeded or partially succeeded.

inputs.name: branchName
inputs.label: Branch name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify to filter on branch/ref name, for example: ```refs/heads/develop```.

inputs.name: buildId
inputs.label: Build
inputs.helpMarkDown: The build from which to download the artifacts

inputs.name: tags
inputs.label: Build Tags
inputs.helpMarkDown: A comma-delimited list of tags. Only builds with these tags will be returned.

inputs.name: downloadType
inputs.label: Download type
inputs.helpMarkDown: Download a specific artifact or specific files from the build.

inputs.name: artifactName
inputs.label: Artifact name
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the artifact to download

inputs.name: itemPattern
inputs.label: Matching pattern
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specify files to be downloaded as multi line minimatch pattern. [More Information](https://aka.ms/minimatchexamples)

The default pattern (\*\*) will download all files across all artifacts in the build if "Specific files" option is selected. To download all files within artifact drop use drop/**.

inputs.name: downloadPath
inputs.label: Destination directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path on the agent machine where the artifacts will be downloaded

inputs.name: cleanDestinationFolder
inputs.label: Clean destination folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Delete all existing files in destination folder before artifact download

inputs.name: parallelizationLimit
inputs.label: Parallelization limit
inputs.helpMarkDown: Number of files to download simultaneously

inputs.name: checkDownloadedFiles
inputs.label: Check downloaded files
inputs.helpMarkDown: If checked, this build task will check that all files are fully downloaded.

inputs.name: retryDownloadCount
inputs.label: Retry count
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optional number of times to retry downloading a build artifact if the download fails.

inputs.name: retryRedirectDownloadCount
inputs.label: Retry count for redirect download
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optional number of times to retry downloading a build artifact if the download based on redirect fails. If your network does not allow following the redirect, you can set this to -1 to always download streamed response from Azure DevOps instead.

inputs.name: extractTars
inputs.label: Extract all files that are stored inside tar archives
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enable this option to extract all downloaded files that have .tar extension. This is helpful because you need to pack your artifact files into tar if you want to preserve Unix file permissions. Enabling `StoreAsTar` option in PublishBuildArtifacts task will store artifacts as .tar files automatically.

tasks.name: AzureWebApp
tasks.description: Deploy an Azure Web App for Linux or Windows
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

groups.name: AdditionalDeploymentOptions
groups.visibleRule: appType != webAppLinux && appType != "" && package NotEndsWith .war && package NotEndsWith .jar

inputs.name: azureSubscription
inputs.label: Azure subscription
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the Azure Resource Manager subscription for the deployment.

inputs.name: appName
inputs.label: App name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter or Select the name of an existing Azure App Service. App services based on selected app type will only be listed.

inputs.name: deployToSlotOrASE
inputs.label: Deploy to Slot or App Service Environment
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Select the option to deploy to an existing deployment slot or Azure App Service Environment.
For both the targets, the task needs Resource group name.
In case the deployment target is a slot, by default the deployment is done to the production slot. Any other existing slot name can also be provided.
In case the deployment target is an Azure App Service environment, leave the slot name as ‘production’ and just specify the Resource group name.

inputs.name: resourceGroupName
inputs.label: Resource group
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The Resource group name is required when the deployment target is either a deployment slot or an App Service Environment.
Enter or Select the Azure Resource group that contains the Azure App Service specified above.

inputs.name: slotName
inputs.label: Slot
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter or Select an existing Slot other than the Production slot.

inputs.name: package
inputs.label: Package or folder
inputs.helpMarkDown:
File path to the package or a folder containing app service contents generated by MSBuild or a compressed zip or war file.
Variables ( [Build](https://docs.microsoft.com/vsts/pipelines/build/variables) | [Release](https://docs.microsoft.com/vsts/pipelines/release/variables#default-variables)), wildcards are supported.
For example, $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/\*\*/\*.zip or $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/\*\*/\*.war.

inputs.name: customDeployFolder
inputs.label: Custom Deploy Folder
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Specify custom folder name you want to deploy to.
If the field is empty, package is deployed to .azurewebsites.net/
If ROOT is entered, package is deployed to .azurewebsited.net
else it is deployed to .azurewebsited.net/

inputs.name: startUpCommand
inputs.label: Startup command
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Enter the start up command. For ex.
dotnet exec filename.dll
dotnet filename.dll

inputs.name: customWebConfig
inputs.label: Generate web.config parameters for Python, Node.js, Go and Java apps
inputs.helpMarkDown: A standard Web.config will be generated and deployed to Azure App Service if the application does not have one. The values in web.config can be edited and vary based on the application framework. For example for node.js application, web.config will have startup file and iis_node module values. This edit feature is only for the generated web.config. [Learn more](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=843469).

inputs.name: appSettings
inputs.label: App settings
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Edit web app application settings following the syntax -key value . Value containing spaces should be enclosed in double quotes.
Example : -Port 5000 -RequestTimeout 5000
-WEBSITE_TIME_ZONE "Eastern Standard Time"

inputs.name: configurationStrings
inputs.label: Configuration settings
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Edit web app configuration settings following the syntax -key value. Value containing spaces should be enclosed in double quotes.
Example : -phpVersion 5.6 -linuxFxVersion: node|6.11

inputs.name: deploymentMethod
inputs.label: Deployment method
inputs.helpMarkDown: Choose the deployment method for the app.

tasks.name: AzureCLI
tasks.description: Run Azure CLI commands against an Azure subscription in a Shell script when running on Linux agent or Batch script when running on Windows agent.
tasks.helpMarkDown: [Learn more about this task](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=827160) or [see the Azure CLI documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/cli/azure/)
tasks.releaseNotes:
What's new in Version 1.0:
- Supports the new Azure CLI 2.0 which is Python based
- Works with cross-platform agents (Linux, macOS, or Windows)
- For working with Azure CLI 1.0 (node.js-based), switch to task version 0.0
- Limitations:
 - No support for Azure Classic subscriptions. Azure CLI 2.0 supports only Azure Resource Manager (ARM) subscriptions.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: connectedServiceNameARM
inputs.label: Azure subscription
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select an Azure resource manager subscription for the deployment

inputs.name: scriptLocation
inputs.label: Script Location
inputs.helpMarkDown: Type of script: File path or Inline script

inputs.name: scriptPath
inputs.label: Script Path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Fully qualified path of the script(.bat or .cmd when using Windows based agent and .sh when using linux based agent) or a path relative to the the default working directory

inputs.name: inlineScript
inputs.label: Inline Script
inputs.helpMarkDown:
You can write your scripts inline here. When using Windows agent, use batch scripting whereas use shell scripting when using Linux based agents. For batch script use the prefix "call" before every azure command. You can also pass predefined and custom variables to this script using arguments 

 example for shell: 
az --version 
az account show 

 example for batch:
call  az --version 
call az account show

inputs.name: args
inputs.label: Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Arguments passed to the script

inputs.name: addSpnToEnvironment
inputs.label: Access service principal details in script
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Adds service principal id and key of the Azure endpoint you chose to the script's execution environment. You can use these variables: `$servicePrincipalId`, `$servicePrincipalKey` and `$tenantId` in your script.

This is honored only when the Azure endpoint has Service Principal authentication scheme.

inputs.name: useGlobalConfig
inputs.label: Use global Azure CLI configuration
inputs.helpMarkDown: If this is false, this task will use its own separate [Azure CLI configuration directory](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/azure-cli-configuration?view=azure-cli-latest#cli-configuration-file). This can be used to run Azure CLI tasks in *parallel* releases

inputs.name: cwd
inputs.label: Working Directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Current working directory where the script is run.  Empty is the root of the repo (build) or artifacts (release), which is $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)

inputs.name: failOnStandardError
inputs.label: Fail on Standard Error
inputs.helpMarkDown: If this is true, this task will fail when any errors are written to the StandardError stream. Unselect the checkbox to ignore standard errors and rely on exit codes to determine the status

tasks.name: AzureCLI
tasks.description: Run Azure CLI commands against an Azure subscription in a PowerShell Core/Shell script when running on Linux agent or PowerShell/PowerShell Core/Batch script when running on Windows agent.
tasks.helpMarkDown: [Learn more about this task](http://github.com/microsoft/azure-pipelines-tasks/blob/master/Tasks/AzureCLIV2/Readme.md) or [see the Azure CLI documentation](https://docs.microsoft.com/cli/azure/)
tasks.releaseNotes:
What's new in Version 2.0:
- Support for PowerShell and PowerShell Core script. 
- PowerShell Core works with cross-platform agents (Linux, macOS, or Windows), make sure the agent has PowerShell version 6 or more. 
- Powershell script works with only Windows agent, make sure the agent has PowerShell version 5 or below.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: connectedServiceNameARM
inputs.label: Azure Resource Manager connection
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select an Azure Resource Manager service connection for the deployment

inputs.name: scriptType
inputs.label: Script Type
inputs.helpMarkDown: Type of script: PowerShell/PowerShell Core/Bat/Shell script. Select Shell/PowerShell Core script when running on Linux agent or Batch/PowerShell/PowerShell Core script when running on Windows agent. PowerShell Core script can run on cross-platform agents (Linux, macOS, or Windows).

inputs.name: scriptLocation
inputs.label: Script Location
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to script: File path or Inline script

inputs.name: scriptPath
inputs.label: Script Path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Fully qualified path of the script(.ps1 or .bat or .cmd when using Windows based agent else .ps1 or .sh when using linux based agent) or a path relative to the the default working directory

inputs.name: inlineScript
inputs.label: Inline Script
inputs.helpMarkDown:
You can write your scripts inline here. When using Windows agent, use PowerShell or PowerShell Core or batch scripting whereas use PowerShell Core or shell scripting when using Linux based agents. For batch files use the prefix "call" before every azure command. You can also pass predefined and custom variables to this script using arguments 

 example for PowerShell/PowerShellCore/shell: 
az --version 
az account show 

 example for batch:
call  az --version 
call az account show

inputs.name: scriptArguments
inputs.label: Script Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Arguments passed to the script

inputs.name: powerShellErrorActionPreference
inputs.label: ErrorActionPreference
inputs.helpMarkDown: Prepends the line `$ErrorActionPreference = 'VALUE'` at the top of your powershell/powershell core script.

inputs.name: addSpnToEnvironment
inputs.label: Access service principal details in script
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Adds service principal id, service principal key and tenant id of the Azure endpoint you chose to the script's execution environment. You can use variables: `servicePrincipalId`, `servicePrincipalKey` and `tenantId` in your script.

This is honored only when the Azure endpoint has Service Principal authentication scheme.

Syntax to access environment variables based on script type.

Powershell script: $env:servicePrincipalId

Batch script: %servicePrincipalId% 

Shell script: $servicePrincipalId

inputs.name: useGlobalConfig
inputs.label: Use global Azure CLI configuration
inputs.helpMarkDown: If this is false, this task will use its own separate [Azure CLI configuration directory](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cli/azure/azure-cli-configuration?view=azure-cli-latest#cli-configuration-file). This can be used to run Azure CLI tasks in *parallel* releases

inputs.name: cwd
inputs.label: Working Directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Current working directory where the script is run.  Empty is the root of the repo (build) or artifacts (release), which is $(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)

inputs.name: failOnStandardError
inputs.label: Fail on Standard Error
inputs.helpMarkDown: If this is true, this task will fail when any errors are written to the StandardError stream. Unselect the checkbox to ignore standard errors and rely on exit codes to determine the status

inputs.name: powerShellIgnoreLASTEXITCODE
inputs.label: Ignore $LASTEXITCODE
inputs.helpMarkDown: If this is false, the line `if ((Test-Path -LiteralPath variable:\LASTEXITCODE)) { exit $LASTEXITCODE }` is appended to the end of your script. This will cause the last exit code from an external command to be propagated as the exit code of powershell. Otherwise the line is not appended to the end of your script.

inputs.name: visibleAzLogin
inputs.label: az login output visibility
inputs.helpMarkDown: If this is set to true, az login command will output to the task. Setting it to false will suppress the az login output

inputs.name: keepAzSessionActive
inputs.label: [Experimental] Keep Azure CLI session active
inputs.helpMarkDown: When enabled, this task will continuously sign into Azure to avoid AADSTS700024 errors when requesting access tokens beyond the IdToken expiry date. Note that this feature is EXPERIMENTAL, may not work in all scenarios and you are using it without any guarantees. Valid only for service connections using the Workload Identity Federation authentication scheme.

tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

 example for shell: azure --version || azure account show 

 example for batch: call  azure --version || call azure account show

inputs.name: args
inputs.label: Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Arguments passed to the script

inputs.name: cwd
inputs.label: Working Directory

tasks.name: GitHubRelease
tasks.description: Create, edit, or delete a GitHub release
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: gitHubConnection
inputs.label: GitHub connection (OAuth or PAT)
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the name of the GitHub service connection to use to connect to the GitHub repository. The connection must be based on a GitHub user's OAuth or a GitHub personal access token. Learn more about service connections [here](https://aka.ms/AA3am5s).

inputs.name: repositoryName
inputs.label: Repository
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the name of the GitHub repository in which the GitHub release will be created, edited, or deleted.

inputs.name: action
inputs.label: Action
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the type of release operation to perform. This task can create, edit, or delete a GitHub release.

inputs.name: target
inputs.label: Target
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the commit SHA for which the GitHub release will be created. E.g. `48b11d8d6e92a22e3e9563a3f643699c16fd6e27`. You can also use a variable here. E.g. `$(myCommitSHA)`.

inputs.name: tagSource
inputs.label: Tag source
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the tag to be used for release creation. The 'Git tag' option automatically takes the tag which is associated with the Git commit. Use the 'User specified tag' option to manually provide a tag.

inputs.name: tagPattern
inputs.label: Tag Pattern
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the git tag pattern using regex(Eg. `release-v1.*`). GitHub release will be created only for commits that have matching git tag.

inputs.name: tag
inputs.label: Tag
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the tag for which to create, edit, or delete a release. You can also use a variable here. E.g. `$(myTagName)`.
inputs.visibleRule: action = edit || action = delete || tagSource = manual

inputs.name: title
inputs.label: Release title
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the title of the GitHub release. If left empty, the tag will be used as the release title.

inputs.name: releaseNotesSource
inputs.label: Release notes source
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the description of the GitHub release. Use the 'Release notes file' option to use the contents of a file as release notes. Use the 'Inline release notes' option to manually enter release notes.

inputs.name: releaseNotesFile
inputs.label: Release notes file path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the file which contains the release notes.

inputs.name: releaseNotes
inputs.label: Release notes
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter the release notes here. Markdown is supported.

inputs.name: assets
inputs.label: Assets
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the files to be uploaded as assets of the release. You can use wildcard characters to specify multiple files. E.g. For build pipelines, `$(Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory)/*.zip` or in case of release pipelines `$(System.DefaultWorkingDirectory)/*.zip`. You can also specify multiple patterns - one per line. By default, all files in the $(Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory) directory will be uploaded. To know more about the list of pre-defined variables available, see [build variables](https://aka.ms/AA4449z) and [release variables](https://aka.ms/AA43wws).

inputs.name: assetUploadMode
inputs.label: Asset upload mode
inputs.helpMarkDown: Use the 'Delete existing assets' option to first delete any existing assets in the release and then upload all assets. Use the 'Replace existing assets' option to replace any assets that have the same name.

inputs.name: isDraft
inputs.label: Draft release
inputs.helpMarkDown: Indicate whether the release should be saved as a draft (unpublished). If `false`, the release will be published.

inputs.name: isPreRelease
inputs.label: Pre-release
inputs.helpMarkDown: Indicate whether the release should be marked as a pre-release.

inputs.name: addChangeLog
inputs.label: Add changelog
inputs.helpMarkDown: If set to `true`, a list of changes (commits and issues) between this and the last published release will be generated and appended to the release notes.

inputs.name: changeLogCompareToRelease
inputs.label: Compare to
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Indicate which release we should compare with to generate the changelog: 
Last full release: Compares the current release with  the most recent non-draft release which is not marked as pre-release.
Last non-draft release: Compares the current release with the most recent non-draft release.
Last non-draft release by tag: Compares the current release with the last non-draft release matching the specified tag. You can also specify a regex instead of an exact tag.

inputs.name: changeLogCompareToReleaseTag
inputs.label: Release Tag
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the regex for release tag. Release matching this tag will be used as base for changelog computation.

inputs.name: changeLogType
inputs.label: Changelog type
inputs.helpMarkDown: Changelog can be commit based or issue based . Commit based changelog lists all commits included in a release where as Issue based changelog lists all the issues/pr included in the release.

inputs.name: changeLogLabels
inputs.label: Categories
inputs.helpMarkDown: Using this you can categorize changes based on the label associated with the issue/pr. For a label you can mention the display name for the category and the state of issue. E.g. `"[{ "label" : "bug", "displayName" : "Bugs", "state" : "closed" }]"` .In case a change has multiple labels on it, the first specified label takes priority. Leave this field empty, to see a flat list of issues/pr.

tasks.name: cURLUploader
tasks.description: Use cURL to upload files with FTP, FTPS, SFTP, HTTP, and more.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: files
inputs.label: Files
inputs.helpMarkDown: File(s) to be uploaded. Wildcards can be used. For example, `**\*.zip` for all ZIP files in all subfolders.

inputs.name: username
inputs.label: Username
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the username for server authentication.

inputs.name: password
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the password for server authentication. Use a new build variable with its lock enabled on the Variables tab to encrypt this value.

inputs.name: url
inputs.label: URL
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the URL to where the file(s) will be uploaded. The directory should end with a trailing slash. Possible URL protocols include `DICT://`, `FILE://`, `FTP://`, `FTPS://`, `GOPHER://`, `HTTP://`, `HTTPS://`, `IMAP://`, `IMAPS://`, `LDAP://`, `LDAPS://`, `POP3://`, `POP3S://`, `RTMP://`, `RTSP://`, `SCP://`, `SFTP://`, `SMTP://`, `SMTPS://`, `TELNET://` and `TFTP://`.

inputs.name: options
inputs.label: Optional Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Additional arguments that will be passed to cURL.

inputs.name: redirectStderr
inputs.label: Redirect Standard Error to Standard Out
inputs.helpMarkDown: Adds '--stderr -' as an argument to cURL. By default, cURL writes its progress bar to stderr, which is interpreted by the build as error output. Enabling this checkbox suppresses that behavior.

tasks.name: cURLUploader
tasks.description: Use cURL's supported protocols to upload files

tasks.name: AzureAppServiceSettings
tasks.description: Update/Add App settings an Azure Web App for Linux or Windows
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: ConnectedServiceName
inputs.label: Azure subscription
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the Azure Resource Manager subscription

inputs.name: appName
inputs.label: App Service name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter or Select the name of an existing Azure App Service

inputs.name: resourceGroupName
inputs.label: Resource group
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter or Select the Azure Resource Group that contains the Azure App Service specified above

inputs.name: slotName
inputs.label: Slot
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter or Select an existing Slot. If no slot is selected, changes will be made to production.

inputs.name: appSettings
inputs.label: App settings
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Add/Update App Service App Settings using the json syntax as follows:
[
   {
    "name": "key1",
    "value": "valueabcd",
    "slotSetting": false
   },
   {
    "name": "key2",
    "value": "valueefgh",
    "slotSetting": true
   }
]

inputs.name: generalSettings
inputs.label: General settings
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Add/Update App Service General Settings using the json syntax as follows:
[
   {
    "alwaysOn": true,
    "webSocketsEnabled": false
   }
]

inputs.name: connectionStrings
inputs.label: Connection Strings
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Add/Update App Service Connection strings using the json syntax as follows:
[
   {
    "name": "key1",
    "value": "valueabcd",
    "type": "MySql",
    "slotSetting": false
   },
   {
    "name": "key2",
    "value": "valueefgh",
    "type": "Custom",
    "slotSetting": true
   }
]

tasks.name: UniversalPackages

tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: command
inputs.label: Command
inputs.helpMarkDown: The Universal Package command to run.

inputs.name: downloadDirectory
inputs.label: Destination directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Folder path where the package's contents will be downloaded.

inputs.name: internalOrExternalDownload
inputs.label: Feed location
inputs.helpMarkDown: You can either select a feed from this collection or any other collection in Azure Artifacts.

inputs.name: externalEndpoint
inputs.label: organization/collection connection
inputs.helpMarkDown: Credentials to use for external feeds.

inputs.name: versionListDownload
inputs.label: Version
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the package version or use a variable containing the version to download. This can also be a wildcard expression such as * to get the highest version, 1.* to get the highest version with major version 1, or 1.2.* to get the highest patch release with major version 1 and minor version 2.

inputs.name: feedDownloadExternal
inputs.label: Feed (or Project/Feed if the feed was created in a project)
inputs.helpMarkDown: If the feed was created in a project, this should be Project/Feed where Project is project's name or ID and Feed is the feed's name. If not created in a project, this should be only the feed name.

inputs.name: packageDownloadExternal
inputs.label: Package name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Package name

inputs.name: versionDownloadExternal
inputs.label: Version
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the package version or use a variable containing the version to download. This can also be a wildcard expression such as * to get the highest version, 1.* to get the highest version with major version 1, or 1.2.* to get the highest patch release with major version 1 and minor version 2.

inputs.name: publishDirectory
inputs.label: Path to file(s) to publish
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specifies the path to list of files to be published.

inputs.name: internalOrExternalPublish
inputs.label: Feed location
inputs.helpMarkDown: You can either select a feed from this collection or any other collection in Azure Artifacts.

inputs.name: externalEndpoints
inputs.label: organization/collection connection
inputs.helpMarkDown: Credentials to use for external feeds.

inputs.name: publishPackageMetadata
inputs.label: Publish pipeline metadata
inputs.helpMarkDown: Associate this build/release pipeline’s metadata (run #, source code information) with the package

inputs.name: packageListPublish
inputs.label: Package name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a package ID to publish or type a new package ID if you've never published a version of this package before. Package names must be lower case and can only use letters, numbers, and dashes(-).

inputs.name: feedPublishExternal
inputs.label: Feed (or Project/Feed if the feed was created in a project)
inputs.helpMarkDown: If the feed was created in a project, this should be Project/Feed where Project is project's name or ID and Feed is the feed's name. If not created in a project, this should be only the feed name.

inputs.name: packagePublishExternal
inputs.label: Package name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Package name

inputs.name: versionPublishSelector

tasks.name: PublishBuildArtifacts
tasks.description: Publish build artifacts to Azure Pipelines or a Windows file share
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: PathtoPublish
inputs.label: Path to publish
inputs.helpMarkDown: The folder or file path to publish. This can be a fully-qualified path or a path relative to the root of the repository. Wildcards are not supported. [Variables](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=550988) are supported. Example: $(Build.ArtifactStagingDirectory)

inputs.name: ArtifactName
inputs.label: Artifact name
inputs.helpMarkDown: The name of the artifact to create in the publish location.

inputs.name: ArtifactType
inputs.label: Artifact publish location
inputs.helpMarkDown: Choose whether to store the artifact in Azure Pipelines, or to copy it to a file share that must be accessible from the build agent.

inputs.name: MaxArtifactSize
inputs.label: Max Artifact Size
inputs.helpMarkDown: Maximum limit on the size of artifacts to be published in bytes. Put 0 if you don't want to set any limit.

inputs.name: TargetPath
inputs.label: File share path
inputs.helpMarkDown: The file share to which the artifact files will be copied. This can include variables. Example: \\\\my\\share\\$(Build.DefinitionName)\\$(Build.BuildNumber). Publishing artifacts from a Linux or macOS agent to a file share is not supported.

inputs.name: Parallel
inputs.label: Parallel copy
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select whether to copy files in parallel using multiple threads for greater potential throughput. If this setting is not enabled, one thread will be used.

inputs.name: ParallelCount
inputs.label: Parallel count
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter the degree of parallelism, or number of threads used, to perform the copy. The value must be at least 1 and not greater than 128.

inputs.name: StoreAsTar
inputs.label: Tar the artifact before uploading
inputs.helpMarkDown: Add all files from the publish path to a tar archive before uploading. This allows you to preserve the UNIX file permissions. Use `extractTars` option of DownloadBuildArtifacts task to extract the downloaded items automatically.

tasks.name: AzureVmssDeployment
tasks.description: Deploy a virtual machine scale set image
tasks.releaseNotes: - Updates Azure Virtual Machine scale set with a custom machine image.
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

groups.name: StartupConfiguration
groups.visibleRule: action = Configure application startup || action = Update image || action = UpdateImage

inputs.name: ConnectedServiceName
inputs.label: Azure subscription
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the Azure Resource Manager subscription for the scale set.

options.Update image: Update VM Scale set by using an image
options.Configure application startup: Run Custom Script VM extension on VM scale set

inputs.name: action
inputs.label: Action
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Choose between updating a VM scale set by using a VHD image and/or by running deployment/install scripts using Custom Script VM extension.
The VHD image approach is better for scaling quickly and doing rollback. The extension approach is useful for post deployment configuration, software installation, or any other configuration / management task.
You can use a VHD image to update a VM scale set only when it was created by using a custom image, the update will fail if the VM Scale set was created by using a platform/gallery image available in Azure.
The Custom script VM extension approach can be used for VM scale set created by using either custom image or platform/gallery image.

inputs.name: vmssName
inputs.label: Virtual Machine scale set name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Name of VM scale set which you want to update by using either a VHD image or by using Custom script VM extension.

inputs.name: vmssOsType
inputs.label: OS type
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the operating system type of VM scale set.

inputs.name: imageUrl
inputs.label: Image URL
inputs.helpMarkDown: Specify the URL of VHD image. If it is an Azure storage blob URL, the storage account location should be same as scale set location.

inputs.name: customScriptsDirectory
inputs.label: Custom script directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Path to directory containing custom script(s) that will be run by using Custom Script VM extension. The extension approach is useful for post deployment configuration, application/software installation, or any other application configuration/management task. For example: the script can set a machine level environment variable which the application uses, like database connection string.

inputs.name: customScript
inputs.label: Command
inputs.helpMarkDown:
The script that will be run by using Custom Script VM extension. This script can invoke other scripts in the directory. The script will be invoked with arguments passed below.
This script in conjugation with such arguments can be used to execute commands. For example:
1. Update-DatabaseConnectionStrings.ps1 -clusterType dev -user $(dbUser) -password $(dbUserPwd) will update connection string in web.config of web application.
2. install-secrets.sh --key-vault-type prod -key serviceprincipalkey will create an encrypted file containing service principal key.

inputs.name: customScriptArguments
inputs.label: Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: The custom script will be invoked with arguments passed. Build/Release variables can be used which makes it easy to use secrets.

inputs.name: customScriptsStorageAccount
inputs.label: Azure storage account where custom scripts will be uploaded
inputs.helpMarkDown: The Custom Script Extension downloads and executes scripts provided by you on each virtual machines in the VM scale set. These scripts will be stored in the storage account specified here. Specify a pre-existing ARM storage account.

inputs.name: skipArchivingCustomScripts
inputs.label: Skip Archiving custom scripts
inputs.helpMarkDown: By default, this task creates a compressed archive of directory containing custom scripts. This improves performance and reliability while uploading to azure storage. If not selected, archiving will not be done and all files will be inidividually uploaded.

inputs.name: DiagnosticStorageAccountKeys
inputs.label: Diagnostic storage account keys
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide storage keys for diagnostics storage account in Role:Storagekey format. The diagnostics storage account name for each role will be obtained from diagnostics config file (.wadcfgx). If the .wadcfgx file for a role is not found, diagnostics extensions won’t be set for the role. If the storage account name is missing in the .wadcfgx file, the default storage account will be used for storing diagnostics results and the storage key parameters from deployment task will be ignored. It’s recommended to save as a secret variable unless there is no sensitive information in the diagnostics result for your environment.

For example,
WebRole: <WebRole_storage_account_key>
WorkerRole: <WorkerRole_stoarge_account_key>

inputs.name: NewServiceCustomCertificates
inputs.label: Custom certificates to import

inputs.helpMarkDown: Credentials to use for external registries located in the project's config.toml. For registries in this organization/collection, leave this blank; the build’s credentials are used automatically.

tasks.name: DeleteFiles
tasks.description: Delete folders, or files matching a pattern
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: SourceFolder
inputs.label: Source Folder
inputs.helpMarkDown: The source folder that the deletion(s) will be run from. Empty is the root of the repo. Use [variables](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=550988) if files are not in the repo. Example: $(agent.builddirectory)

inputs.name: Contents
inputs.label: Contents
inputs.helpMarkDown: File/folder paths to delete. Supports multiple lines of minimatch patterns. [More Information](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=722333)

inputs.name: RemoveSourceFolder
inputs.label: Remove SourceFolder
inputs.helpMarkDown: Attempt to remove the source folder as well.

inputs.name: RemoveDotFiles
inputs.label: Remove files starting with a dot
inputs.helpMarkDown: Delete files starting with a dot (.git, .dockerfile). Omits these files if it's not specified explicitly (for example, '/.*'). Please see this [link](https://github.com/isaacs/minimatch#dot) for more info

tasks.name: gulp
tasks.description: Run the gulp Node.js streaming task-based build system
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: gulpFile
inputs.label: gulp File Path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Relative path from repo root of the gulp file script file to run.

inputs.name: targets
inputs.label: gulp Task(s)
inputs.helpMarkDown: Optional.  Space delimited list of tasks to run.  If not specified, the default task will run.

inputs.name: arguments
inputs.label: Arguments
inputs.helpMarkDown: Additional arguments passed to gulp.  --gulpfile is not needed since already added via gulpFile input above.

inputs.name: cwd
inputs.label: Working Directory
inputs.helpMarkDown: Current working directory when script is run.  Defaults to the folder where the script is located.

inputs.name: gulpjs
inputs.label: gulp.js location
inputs.helpMarkDown: gulp.js to run when agent can't find global installed gulp.  Defaults to the gulp.js under node_modules folder of the working directory.

inputs.name: publishJUnitResults
inputs.label: Publish to Azure Pipelines
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select this option to publish JUnit test results produced by the gulp build to Azure Pipelines.

inputs.name: testResultsFiles
inputs.label: Test Results Files
inputs.helpMarkDown: Test results files path. Wildcards can be used. For example, `**/TEST-*.xml` for all XML files whose name starts with TEST-.

inputs.name: testRunTitle
inputs.label: Test Run Title
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide a name for the test run.

inputs.name: enableCodeCoverage
inputs.label: Enable code Coverage
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select this option to enable Code Coverage using Istanbul.

inputs.name: testFramework
inputs.label: Test Framework
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select your test framework.

inputs.name: srcFiles
inputs.label: Source Files
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the path to your source files which you want to hookRequire()

inputs.name: testFiles
inputs.label: Test Script Files
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the path to your test script files

tasks.name: QuickPerfTest
tasks.description: Run a quick web performance test in the cloud with Azure Pipelines
tasks.helpMarkDown: Triggers a cloud-based load test using Azure Pipelines. [Learn more](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?linkid=613203)
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

inputs.name: connectedServiceName
inputs.label: Azure Pipelines Connection
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select a previously registered service connection to talk to the cloud-based load test service. Choose 'Manage' to register a new service connection.

inputs.name: websiteUrl
inputs.label: Website URL
inputs.helpMarkDown: Enter your application website URL as http://www.your.app/home.html

inputs.name: testName
inputs.label: Test Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Name the load test for tracking and correlation.

inputs.name: vuLoad
inputs.label: User Load
inputs.helpMarkDown: Maximum virtual users concurrently accessing the website.

inputs.name: runDuration
inputs.label: Run Duration (sec)
inputs.helpMarkDown: Load test run duration in seconds.

inputs.name: geoLocation
inputs.label: Load Location
inputs.helpMarkDown: Geographical region to generate the load from.

inputs.name: resourceGroupName
inputs.label: Resource group rig
inputs.helpMarkDown: Name of Resource group hosting the self-provisioned rig of load test agents.

inputs.name: numOfSelfProvisionedAgents
inputs.label: No. of agents to use
inputs.helpMarkDown: Number of self provisioned agents to use for this test.

inputs.name: avgResponseTimeThreshold
inputs.label: Fail test if Avg.Response Time(ms) exceeds
inputs.helpMarkDown: Average response time above which the load test outcome is considered unsuccessful.

tasks.name: IISWebAppManagementOnMachineGroup
tasks.description: Create or update websites, web apps, virtual directories, or application pools
tasks.author: Microsoft Corporation

groups.name: IISBindings
groups.visibleRule: IISDeploymentType = IISWebsite && ActionIISWebsite = CreateOrUpdateWebsite && AddBinding = true

groups.name: ApplicationPoolForWebsite
groups.visibleRule: IISDeploymentType = IISWebsite && ActionIISWebsite = CreateOrUpdateWebsite && CreateOrUpdateAppPoolForWebsite = true

groups.name: IISWebsiteAuthentication
groups.visibleRule: IISDeploymentType = IISWebsite && ActionIISWebsite = CreateOrUpdateWebsite && ConfigureAuthenticationForWebsite = true

inputs.name: EnableIIS
inputs.label: Enable IIS
inputs.helpMarkDown: Check this if you want to install IIS on the machine.

inputs.name: IISDeploymentType
inputs.label: Configuration type
inputs.helpMarkDown: You can create or update sites, applications, virtual directories, and application pools.

inputs.name: ActionIISWebsite
inputs.label: Action
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Select the appropriate action that you want to perform on an IIS website. 

"Create Or Update" will create a website or update an existing website.

 Start, Stop will start or stop the website respectively.

inputs.name: ActionIISApplicationPool
inputs.label: Action
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Select the appropriate action that you want to perform on an IIS Application Pool. 

"Create Or Update" will create app-pool or update an existing one.

Start, Stop, Recycle will start, stop or recycle the application pool respectively.

inputs.name: StartStopWebsiteName
inputs.label: Website name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the name of the IIS website.

inputs.name: WebsiteName
inputs.label: Website name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the name of the IIS website to create or update.

inputs.name: WebsitePhysicalPath
inputs.label: Physical path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the physical path where the website content will be stored. The content can reside on the local Computer, or in a remote directory, or on a network share, like C:\Fabrikam or \\\\ContentShare\Fabrikam.

inputs.name: WebsitePhysicalPathAuth
inputs.label: Physical path authentication
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the authentication mechanism that will be used to access the physical path of the website.

inputs.name: WebsiteAuthUserName
inputs.label: Username
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the user name that will be used to access the website's physical path.

inputs.name: WebsiteAuthUserPassword
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide the user's password that will be used to access the website's physical path.
The best practice is to create a variable in the build or release pipeline, and mark it as 'Secret' to secure it, and then use it here, like '$(userCredentials)'.
Note: Special characters in password are interpreted as per command-line arguments

inputs.name: AddBinding
inputs.label: Add binding
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to add port binding for the website.

inputs.name: Protocol
inputs.label: Protocol
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select HTTP for the website to have an HTTP binding, or select HTTPS for the website to have a Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) binding.

inputs.name: IPAddress
inputs.label: IP address
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide an IP address that end-users can use to access this website.
If 'All Unassigned' is selected, then the website will respond to requests for all IP addresses on the port and for the host name, unless another website on the server has a binding on the same port but with a specific IP address.

inputs.name: Port
inputs.label: Port
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the port, where the Hypertext Transfer Protocol Stack (HTTP.sys) will listen to the website requests.

inputs.name: ServerNameIndication
inputs.label: Server Name Indication required
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Select the option to set the Server Name Indication (SNI) for the website.
SNI extends the SSL and TLS protocols to indicate the host name that the clients are attempting to connect to. It allows, multiple secure websites with different certificates, to use the same IP address.

inputs.name: HostNameWithOutSNI
inputs.label: Host name
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Enter a host name (or domain name) for the website.
If a host name is specified, then the clients must use the host name instead of the IP address to access the website.

inputs.name: HostNameWithHttp
inputs.label: Host name
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Enter a host name (or domain name) for the website.
If a host name is specified, then the clients must use the host name instead of the IP address to access the website.

inputs.name: HostNameWithSNI
inputs.label: Host name
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Enter a host name (or domain name) for the website.
If a host name is specified, then the clients must use the host name instead of the IP address to access the website.

inputs.name: SSLCertThumbPrint
inputs.label: SSL certificate thumbprint
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the thumb-print of the Secure Socket Layer certificate that the website is going to use for the HTTPS communication as a 40 character long hexadecimal string. The SSL certificate should be already installed on the Computer, at Local Computer, Personal store.

inputs.name: Bindings
inputs.label: Add bindings
inputs.helpMarkDown: Click on the extension [...] button to add bindings for the website.

inputs.name: CreateOrUpdateAppPoolForWebsite
inputs.label: Create or update app pool
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to create or update an application pool. If checked, the website will be created in the specified app pool.

inputs.name: ConfigureAuthenticationForWebsite
inputs.label: Configure authentication
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to configure authentication for website.

inputs.name: AppPoolNameForWebsite
inputs.label: Name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the name of the IIS application pool to create or update.

inputs.name: DotNetVersionForWebsite
inputs.label: .NET version
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Select the version of the .NET Framework that is loaded by the application pool.
If the applications assigned to this application pool do not contain managed code, then select the 'No Managed Code' option from the list.

inputs.name: PipeLineModeForWebsite
inputs.label: Managed pipeline mode
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the managed pipeline mode that specifies how IIS processes requests for managed content. Use classic mode only when the applications in the application pool cannot run in the Integrated mode.

inputs.name: AppPoolIdentityForWebsite
inputs.label: Identity
inputs.helpMarkDown: Configure the account under which an application pool's worker process runs. Select one of the predefined security accounts or configure a custom account.

inputs.name: AppPoolUsernameForWebsite
inputs.label: Username
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the username of the custom account that you want to use.

inputs.name: AppPoolPasswordForWebsite
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide the password for custom account.
The best practice is to create a variable in the build or release pipeline, and mark it as 'Secret' to secure it, and then use it here, like '$(userCredentials)'.
Note: Special characters in password are interpreted as per command-line arguments

inputs.name: AnonymousAuthenticationForWebsite
inputs.label: Anonymous authentication
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to enable anonymous authentication for website.

inputs.name: BasicAuthenticationForWebsite
inputs.label: Basic authentication
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to enable basic authentication for website.

inputs.name: WindowsAuthenticationForWebsite
inputs.label: Windows authentication
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to enable windows authentication for website.

inputs.name: ParentWebsiteNameForVD
inputs.label: Parent website name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the name of the parent Website of the virtual directory.

inputs.name: VirtualPathForVD
inputs.label: Virtual path
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide the virtual path of the virtual directory. 

Example: To create a virtual directory Site/Application/VDir enter /Application/Vdir. The parent website and application should be already existing.

inputs.name: PhysicalPathForVD
inputs.label: Physical path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the physical path where the virtual directory's content will be stored. The content can reside on the local Computer, or in a remote directory, or on a network share, like C:\Fabrikam or \\\\ContentShare\Fabrikam.

inputs.name: VDPhysicalPathAuth
inputs.label: Physical path authentication
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the authentication mechanism that will be used to access the physical path of the virtual directory.

inputs.name: VDAuthUserName
inputs.label: Username
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the user name that will be used to access the virtual directory's physical path.

inputs.name: VDAuthUserPassword
inputs.label: Password
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide the user's password that will be used to access the virtual directory's physical path.
The best practice is to create a variable in the build or release pipeline, and mark it as 'Secret' to secure it, and then use it here, like '$(userCredentials)'.
Note: Special characters in password are interpreted as per command-line arguments

inputs.name: ParentWebsiteNameForApplication
inputs.label: Parent website name
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the name of the parent Website under which the application will be created or updated.

inputs.name: VirtualPathForApplication
inputs.label: Virtual path
inputs.helpMarkDown:
Provide the virtual path of the application. 

Example: To create an application Site/Application enter /Application. The parent website should be already existing.

inputs.name: PhysicalPathForApplication
inputs.label: Physical path
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the physical path where the application's content will be stored. The content can reside on the local Computer, or in a remote directory, or on a network share, like C:\Fabrikam or \\\\ContentShare\Fabrikam.

inputs.name: ApplicationPhysicalPathAuth
inputs.label: Physical path authentication
inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the authentication mechanism that will be used to access the physical path of the application.

inputs.name: ApplicationAuthUserName
inputs.label: Username
inputs.helpMarkDown: Provide the user name that will be used to access the application's physical path.

inputs.name: ApplicationAuthUserPassword

Provide the user's password that will be used to access the application's physical path.
The best practice is to create a variable in the build or release pipeline, and mark it as 'Secret' to secure it, and then use it here, like '$(userCredentials)'.
Note: Special characters in password are interpreted as per command-line arguments

inputs.helpMarkDown: Select the option to create or update an application pool. If checked, the application will be created in the specified app pool.
